[Melanie McLaughlin]: Hello, my name is Melanie McLaughlin and Austin street and men for mass Thank you Councilors for hearing us tonight and.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you to Trish and to the parents who are really organizing a lot of this.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It's great to see the energy.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And as we think about our children and young adults in this community, I have to say that you can tell immediately people who have experience with people with disabilities, because they know how to talk to them, they know how to

[Melanie McLaughlin]: interact with them and they appreciate and see them as human beings.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And Councilor Leming and school committee member Olapade did that recently at the library event.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It was really wonderful to see them playing Uno with a number of our children and getting involved.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I'll tell you, I have a seven, I can't believe she's 17, I have a 17 year old daughter with Down syndrome, excuse my hoarseness, I have a cold, with Down syndrome, who is also legally blind and,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: You know, she's the best thing that ever happened to us she's taught us so much about compassion and kindness and so many things, and I think when other people get to meet people with disabilities, they learn that lesson themselves, and not that our kids are here to teach the rest of us about humanity but that's just who they are and it is what they do.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And, you know, a community that misses out on that misses out on quite a lot.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: and I wouldn't change anything.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I do have to say though, in terms of adaptive and other programming, I just wanna put a bug in everybody's ear too.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: As you're thinking about inclusion, adaptive is great and we want, that's the other thing is you have to have programs with support, right?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It's not just, oh yeah, you're all welcome here, which has often been the case, which is really nice, it's nice to be welcome.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But if you're welcome and there's no support and then it doesn't go well, then you're really not welcome and it's setting up our kids for failure.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So having the support to make sure that it's actually a welcoming community and an inclusive community, not just, you know, in, in theory only because it takes support it takes skill, and not from parents from people who have skill you know that been experience over the time where in the interaction with parents around skill I remember, I remember our daughter having a swim lessons in the,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And the schools and young teenagers are working with our kids a lot and they're not really getting trained to be able to have that experience and seeing my daughter in the pool and just teaching something as simple as first then right first let's do the swimming the lab, then you'll get to go, you know, do whatever it's a really simple lesson, but if you don't know it you don't know it and so just being able to learn the basics is really important.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And as we think about the training and being able to see not just recreation, being able to see our children, again, use the library, use the coffee shops, feel welcome, feel included, and feel part of.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I mean, I can't say enough about Amici's and West Medford.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: They are the most inclusive business I've experienced in Medford.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Mario and his team make us feel right at home, make Gracie feel right at home.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And Amici means friend.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And he was teaching Gracie that the other day and I thought that was really beautiful.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I hope that you guys get the chance to meet all these wonderful young adults and people in our community, beyond just the schools and the students and you know the schools are required by law just to provide all of the extracurricular activities that any other student is entitled to.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: to every student.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so again, you know, we did ask when I was on the school committee to include a statement that if you need accommodations for any of these experiences please contact and we had a specific contact around what accommodations needed to be available and how parents could, you know, reach out and let folks know that they need accommodations.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Some parents don't even want to do that because it feels like a lot for them.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So it's important to continue to reach out as well.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But that's something to consider, that how can we collaborate to make sure that the accommodations are helpful and real.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I have to say this, if you've never been to a dance with people with disabilities, you're really missing out because they really dance like nobody's watching.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So thank you very much.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Yeah, thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Rick McLaughlin, 87 West Street.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I'm compelled to speak with you today for three reasons.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: The first is as the father of an alumna who was in the marching band, I've seen other things, the same things that the students have already spoken about and what other parents have spoken about.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I'm not gonna, I'll just say yes to what they've said.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: The second reason is I'm the son of a career music educator, taught music in public schools for 40 years.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And he told me in the 1970s that this would happen.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I'm going to tell you about that in a second.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: The third reason is because as a professional musician myself and professor at the most influential school of music in the world, I've seen the power of music on four continents, both as a performer and as a clinician.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So my dad, he taught music in public schools for 40 years.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I remember in the 1970s, he told me that one day what would happen is the school committee or principals or whoever was actually managing money would cut the music program enough

[Melanie McLaughlin]: that it just, it wouldn't cut it completely, just enough to let it die, which is what is happening.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: You say that you're going to still support the arts, that's not true.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: The impact that other people have already discussed, you should take to heart because it's very important.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But there's another element that's very important, which is the mission of the Medford Public Schools is to provide a supportive and effective educational environment that helps students successfully meet their individualized goals.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: This will no longer be true when you cut Ms.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Ferrello's position.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: By cutting her position, you will make it so that

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Future students do not sign up for music.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: A previous student spoke about how it's virtually impossible to do it anyway because of the ways that the scheduling conflicts prevent them from actually taking these courses.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: M-Y-E-L-I-N, myelin.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: That is the aspect of the brain, the neurological neuron wrapping that actually makes your brain process information more effectively and more quickly.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: None of the things that you teach in school, none of the things Mr. Rousseau referred to earlier, English, math, science, history, I can't remember what the rest was on his list, none of those things actually improve or increase brain processing speed

[Melanie McLaughlin]: The only thing that does is music.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: By cutting Miss Rello's position, you no longer support the arts.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: You also no longer support the mission of the school because you no longer support the brain health of the students who go here.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: incorporated and so I think I'd like to be a little bit clearer about what the process is and maybe you know I don't think at this hour of the meeting it's a good time to do that but I guess I'll give that some thought but I would just like my the committee members to consider the process so that if we are as a team working together to create subcommittees we should be as a team identifying

[Melanie McLaughlin]: the different subcommittees that are going to exist for the upcoming term.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: collectively decided how that process was going to work.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: you know, really overheated and other students that populations that really need to be considered.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: educators know about.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Not naming individual things I think is clearly important.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I also want to share with the committee and the community some of the gestation really of some of the inclusive playground work as well.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I think I may have shared this, I know I shared this story with the playground committee, I'm not sure I shared it with school committee, but years ago, there was a student here who had significant medical needs and disability and was in a wheelchair and did not communicate with words and was in an out of district residential placement.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: In out of district residential placements, the students do come home during school vacations and on some occasions.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And when that would occur, the student,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: had no opportunity in the community really to be engaged and involved, and was not able to really be part of the community and in the schools and mom in particular shared that story with us, the family was.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: from Brazil initially and had emigrated here.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And mom was a single mom and had done a tremendous job and had shared that at a leadership, disability leadership program that we were in and they were Medford.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: The little girl passed away when she was 15.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Her name is Emily Oliveira.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: She's actually in the Oakland Park Cemetery right next to Crystal and her picture's there.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I think she deserves to be remembered in particular around this inclusive playground

[Melanie McLaughlin]: and in particular around the swings.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Mom really wanted a swing that was accessible for her wheelchair.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I would like some commemoration to Emily and her mom for what I feel like the community should have done for them a long time ago.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I know that mom would be really thrilled to see something like that for Emily.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: A wall.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: A whole wall.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Yeah, I think that I wanna weigh in on some of that just in terms of, yeah, I think the survey, two things, I think we're having two conversations.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: If we're having another survey and we wanna compare it to the base data that we have now, we need to compare apples to apples in terms of a survey, just in terms of statistics and data.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: However, if we think that the survey that we're talking about, the panoramic survey is actually much more expansive

[Melanie McLaughlin]: and at the same time, much more detailed, then there's a different conversation about, okay, maybe we need the panoramic survey, we do that, and then we have a comparison to that as apples to apples for next year.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So this year we do the panoramic survey and then apples to apples for next year, because the panoramic survey, if it's being used by other districts, then we compare, we have some basis of comparison.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: This homemade, if you will, survey,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: for our district only is not going to offer any basis of comparison to another district because it's for this district only.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: That said, there are outliers in this data and the outliers to me are the, you know, certainly about the, you know, the student being able to have some discussion around, you know, their needs and what have you, but, you know, the two of the bigger outliers to me and clearly to the data

[Melanie McLaughlin]: are on the, you know, students in this school are teased or picked on about their real or perceived sexual orientation.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: 32% agree with that, 50% don't.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Students at the school are teased or picked on about their physical or intellectual disability.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: 34% agree about that, 44% don't.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so these are things that are, you know, even in the standard sort of data set at our school, I agree, we want those to be 40%, but clearly in an overall aggregate picture,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: we can see that we have some cultural and climate issues around competency, cultural competency, frankly, both in terms of ableism and sexism and other isms, I'm sure.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I think that that clearly shows us that there's a focus, but I guess that said, the real question here is what are we looking for?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Are we looking to use base data here and have a comparison

[Melanie McLaughlin]: you know, mid-year or are we looking to let's have a standard that other districts are using in the state?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I think that's the difference between the question.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I don't know if that's an agenda item for next time or if there needs to be a motion for that or what, but I think we're trying to answer two different questions in terms of data.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I think we have to be very clear about what it is we want.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I guess to that end, I would make a motion for us to use a panoramic survey as a standard survey for the one coming out in, if it's, you know, at the end of January or what have you, and we'll do our best to make some comparison to this, but with the idea that the following year we'll use the same survey, so.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you for the

[Melanie McLaughlin]: report in fair time tonight.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I had some questions specific to the, I mean, I think we've been talking about the equity issue for some time.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I do agree with my colleague around having some of the narrative of the data, some sort of qualitative narrative of the quantitative data would be really helpful for the community as well.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: in understanding the disparity.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: There's obviously a stark disparity in some of the numbers, especially based at the elementary level.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so I think people would wanna know why.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And then also I think it sort of can help dispel some of the notions that some schools are better than others or what have you, which is not the case.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so really being able to help folks understand that I think would be really helpful

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And it would also be helpful for us as we're thinking about what the budgeting priorities are across the district and what things look like in terms of if we're really talking about equity as a priority.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: As we've said many times before, equity is not that everybody gets the same, it's that everybody gets what they need.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so, with that in mind, really thinking about that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And that was my naivete, ignorance, whatever you want to say.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I feel like if we're providing this, we also want to provide the information on the Office of Civil Rights.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So why would we not also provide that information?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Yeah, I mean, I think we have it on all the other documentation, so why not offer it as, you know, because it's part of the procedural safeguards for families regardless.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I know it's in part of the procedural safeguards for individuals with disabilities, but I think some parents might not understand that PRS

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And, you know, I hadn't thought about that in terms of the procedure.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: They are about procedure.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I could see how it would be.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It could be individuals without disabilities regarding procedure, but it also could fall under Office of Civil Rights.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I think that people need to know that there are both of those options.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So that's what I would ask.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: No, that was six in the, seven in the affirmative.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Sorry.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I had a point of information, Mayor.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I was wondering if I could get some clarity on the motion because- Point of information by Member McLaughlin.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I am hearing, if I'm hearing correctly,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I was at every policy

[Melanie McLaughlin]: subcommittee meeting with the exception of one.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I think I can see both sides in terms of the power differential, but this is a very subjective thing, power differential.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And it's like we had instances with our own family members who were very much being bullied.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: In this situation, there was a power differential.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It was not seen necessarily by the principal because the principal very likely doesn't understand nuances of middle school power dynamics.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And they're very subtle and can be relational as opposed to physical.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: They can be all sorts of things.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I think that's why there's such clarity and why and how you find a

[Melanie McLaughlin]: finding of bullying, and my concern my main concern about this which I think power differentials are an issue, and very much very often are the instances but not only and also it leaves to somebody discretion to determine whether there's a power differential as opposed to the other requirements that are part of state law which I think

[Melanie McLaughlin]: is critical.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I'm a little, I'm a little conflicted around this, which is why I'm having or asking that this be thought out a little bit more to do the chair to member Graham's point I understand what you're saying about wanting to really clarify the conflict bullying and not bullying because believe me, ours was ruled conflict and it, you know,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And many others have been, as I've known, and I think would qualify under this, but it's because it leaves it so subjective to what this is.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I think this even makes it more subjective, frankly, around the power differential.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I don't know how to fix this, and I don't know if it's a state fix or what it is, but I think that maybe there's some middle ground, there's some opportunity for some rewarding or negotiation or something here, because

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I hear both sides of the argument and it's concerning for me, especially around, you know, and it still didn't answer the question is what happens when, you know, two people are in a situation and one is bullying the other, and it's not seen as a power differential, because for whatever reason, because maybe there's not a known power differential there.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: internally it's a power differential because somebody else is scared and the other one's not, but how does that determine?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I mean, it's such nuance, it's, you know, emotions.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: How do you know internally whether there's a power differential or not?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Or, you know, but for all appearances sake, they're both on the football team, you know, one's the quarterback, one's the linebacker, I don't know.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And what, you know, they seem to be equals, they're of the same height, weight, abilities, you know, all of those things, but clearly one is, you know, bullying and,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: the other is not, how do you know that there's a power, you know, what do you do if there's not a power differential, yet there is bullying, which I think is why there's that clarification under the definition.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I hear two competing things here.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Identifying and the difference of conflict bullying and not bullying or conflict, which I think is a tricky bit for everybody.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And then the other is being consistent with our definition.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: and really clarifying what that is of bullying and making sure that we're aligning with what the state standard is.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And, you know, really the cultural broker model is a really important model and something I'm doing in my own work during the day.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I'm actually becoming a certified application Councilor.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Yeah, yeah.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I totally understand that process.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I think that's super important.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I, and especially with the redetermination right now, as you know, and do a lot of work with DPH, Maternal and Child Health Bureau.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Yeah, so with that, I work a lot with the Division of Children, Youth, and Special Healthcare Needs.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So that is one of the populations that I really wanted to ask you about here, especially in terms of when we're talking cultural brokers, we're talking that that's a culture in itself as well.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so where and how are we reaching that community, particular around, you know, there's lots of issues of public health that are intersecting for families and children with youth and children

[Melanie McLaughlin]: with youth with special healthcare needs.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I didn't sort of see that as a subgroup, and I'm really eager to move that forward as I'm sure you know as well, and happy to help any way I can, but I'd like to know what you guys are doing in that realm.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Yeah.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I guess I'm asking that in the DEI realm as well.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So not just about, you know, chronic health care needs, but really about, you know, the connect program and other things that you were talking about, specifically some of the parent ed and some of the things that you're talking about with MFN.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So these are all things that I think are really important to target that community, just as we are with language access and culture access and other communities.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So again, happy to move that forward, but just want to put that out there and put that out there publicly, because I think all too often it's a community that gets dropped off and there's lots of intersectionality.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: There's people who speak other languages that also have disabilities, of course, and that just complicates issues even more.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So again, I feel like I'm always clanging this bell and it does get a little tiresome, I'm sure.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So love everything that's happening here and I'm eager to talk more.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So we're not talking about differentiating the curriculum that typical students are getting.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: You're talking about an entirely different curriculum.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I've been waiting a little bit, a little while.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: which is why I think maybe you can't see me but I wanted to ask as well so there's a few things when I first came on to the school committee, the budget process was very different than it is now and I know that we had a director of finance in the interim, that sort of change things and some of the recommendations

[Melanie McLaughlin]: on recommendations from this committee.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: In the past, just so for folks who are listening or in the audience or watching online, in the past, what would happen is department heads would come before the committee, would sort of describe what happened in their, what happens in their department, would break down what their department did and what they were proposing was needed in the future.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And that process was sort of eliminated in this last iteration.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And it became more of a sort of global look at it at a larger number.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I frankly liked

[Melanie McLaughlin]: the transparency that occurred when department heads were able to come up and we were able to ask them about what was needed and how we were able to get to certain numbers.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I know that the process was longer as a result of that, but personally, I preferred that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I felt like it was more, for me, it helped me better understand the budget and where money was coming and going.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And we were also able to really understand what each school had.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So how many adjustment Councilors were at X school, how many,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: you know, BCBAs, we're at Wise School, we were able to sort of see equity across the district or inequity across the district and how it might be able to be addressed.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And in this iteration, I'm not finding that as much.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I just want to mention that to my colleagues here and to the audience as well, because I think that we always have the opportunity to change the process.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I think the more transparent and simplified the process can be, as much as one can do with a, you know, $70-$80 million budget, the better it is.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I have worked on multi-million dollar budgets in my professional life, and it has been a much different process and one much more similar to what we had seen earlier with sort of department by department, subtotal by subtotal.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: which for me was particularly helpful.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Another real concern I have about this budget is we're talking SEL, we're talking post-pandemic relief, we're talking ARPA and ESSER.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And, you know, I haven't really heard a lot of discussion about our underrepresented subgroups and the increased need of our underrepresented subgroups, particularly we know we have a mental health crisis happening right now, how we're just how we're, you know, thinking about that for our student population, how we're thinking about we just recently to my

[Melanie McLaughlin]: relief passed a resolution, ensuring non discrimination and inclusion and non exclusion from all activities that are school based before school, during school and after school, and yet I continue to hear from families, and I am concerned about particularly summer programming.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And what we're doing around summer programming, for example, the summer fun camp, which has historically been, you know, one or two general education teachers and a lot of high school students.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: More recently, through a lot of work from community members, we were able to get increased services provided there for some students with higher needs, students with disabilities, other students.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: so that they could access that program.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: That doesn't seem clear to me as to whether that's happening this summer, or whether that's happening with any of our summer programming or enrichment programming or after school programming, or any of our programming and I don't know, a lot of times when we asked that question we're told this step that people aren't available, that it's hard difficult to hire folks but if we don't even have them.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: allocated in a budget, or if we're not talking about how they are allocated in the budget, if they are, whether it's through additional special education funding for grants that, again, we don't see on this particular budget sheet, which can be substantive in their money, the IDEA funds, other funds, not knowing where that money is going is really tricky for me, and understanding how that gets teased out is really tricky for me.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And also, I think we talked in the last meeting or the meeting prior,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: specifically about the revolving accounts and what kind of income they generate.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So for example, if the, and this is just an example, I don't have these numbers for real, but if, for example, the summer fund program, which is a summer camp for students in the Medford community that is housed in one of our schools, if for example that, and it's tuition driven,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: If, for example, that program made a profit of say, I don't know $40,000 I don't know that it does but say for example it made a profit of $40,000 yet was unable to accommodate individuals who had additional needs for any number of reasons because budget money wasn't allocated because what have you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: That's not meeting the requirement of reasonable accommodations, for example, and how are we really considering that, particularly when we're talking about SEL for those who folks who don't understand the acronym I would just share it social emotional learning and the importance of belonging, being part of one's community and feeling that and also recruitment of skills so that you start in September.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: with the same skills that you had and regression, preventing regression of skills so that you don't go backwards over the summer, particularly for our more marginalized subgroups.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I just feel like that conversation is being lost here.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So in summary, I have two comments overall.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: You know, those friendships were sustained even after school and through the summer

[Melanie McLaughlin]: students with and without disabilities.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And it was a really great opportunity to the students and for them to interact with each other and really get to know each other and saw great outcomes with that for genuine friendships with, I thought was really remarkable.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so to that end, I think again, another just bug in people's ear to sort of be thinking about because that program was so successful is potentially a peer mentor program.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I think that for either potentially students who have had experience with

[Melanie McLaughlin]: CCSR for students that haven't, particularly if you're looking at recruiting new folks, particularly LPAT, you know, students who English might not be their first language, maybe need a little extra support.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Students with disability, like a peer mentor program where you're cultivating these leaders, potentially thinking about, you know, what that could look like in your leadership institute, I think could be great.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: in the community and in the community engagement.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It's a special ability that's able to do that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I was just gonna say, I'm willing to waive the reading of the non-discrimination policy currently and the Medford School Committee non-discrimination AC policy, if my colleagues agree.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I do, I agree.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So yes, that's what I was going to propose is that that's exactly at that if the event is wheelchair accessible.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Frankly, it's just good practice for all events citywide that if the event is wheelchair accessible that folks let them let let the community know that it is wheelchair accessible because you don't want people coming to the event and in a wheelchair and not having it be accessible and not having noted that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: or omitted that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I think it's important to include it, and I can rephrase it to include it when the event is wheelchair accessible.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I would also just add that because we are getting federal funding, as is the city, situations are generally required to be accessible to wheelchairs as well.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: There are some instances in the city I understand that are

[Melanie McLaughlin]: quote unquote grandfathered based on the status of the building.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I think that Curtis Tufts might fall into that category, although I don't know for sure.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I'm hoping that we're gonna talk more about that as a committee, as a whole, as we move forward.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But in the interim, what we want, what this was proposing is really that the community understands that accommodation requests are required.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I know that we waived the reading, but they are required under several of the laws that are noted in the motion.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: including Title IX, Section 504 Rehabilitation Act, IDEA, I mean, Title I of the Americans with Disabilities Act and Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I'm fine with modifying the motion to say, you know, from we value inclusion to submit it at least five days prior to the event period with a quote, and then separate from that, please add, you know, when event is wheelchair accessible.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Aye.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: the notice.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: This is a meeting of the Special Education Behavioral Health Subcommittee.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I am the chair of the subcommittee along with members Rousseau and Mustone.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So thank you all for coming.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: This meeting is, I'm just gonna read the notice.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Please be advised that on Wednesday, May 3rd from five to 6 p.m.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: there's a special education subcommittee meeting, special education behavioral health subcommittee meeting to be held through remote participation via Zoom.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: The purpose of the subcommittee meeting will be to review and develop a non-discrimination slash inclusion statement for Medford Public Schools outreach slash information.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: The meeting can be viewed through Medford Community Media on Comcast Channel 15 and Verizon Channel 45 at 5 p.m.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Since the meeting will be held remotely, participants can log in or call in by using the following link or call-in number.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: The link is mps02155-org.zoom.us.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Actually, you can see it on the website if you need to go there, which you would if you're going on Zoom.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: and then the call in is 929-205-6099.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Those submitting questions or comments need to include the following information.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Comments or questions can be submitted during the meeting by emailing Melanie McLachlan, M-E-L-A-N-I-E-M-C-L-M-L-A-N-I-E.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: at medford.k12.ma.us, and those submitting questions or comments must include the following information.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: First and last name, Medford Street address, and your question or comment.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So again, thank you all for coming.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: You just said she had a visitor.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: That's okay.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: That's okay.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Member Mustone.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Member McLaughlin here.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Member Ruseau present.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Great, thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So again, this is the purpose is to discuss an inclusion slash equity statement slash accommodation statement for Medford Public Schools.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I'm actually going to share my screen.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I will send this to this document to

[Melanie McLaughlin]: the superintendent's office, Markey, after the meeting to share if needed, but I'll share my screen with folks as well.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I did share it with committee members, with member Bowen, I mean, with Director of Pupil Services, Joan Bowen and Dr. Edouard-Vincent.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So this is a document that sort of helps outline some of the discussion that I'd like to use.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So this is just some research done on some differences in non-discrimination statement versus inclusion statement.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So first of all, I wanna ground us in the work that we're doing right now.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So based on the Medford Public Schools strategic plan,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: which has been approved.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: This is the E in the ACES acronym that Dr. Edouard-Vincent uses in terms of the strategic plan.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And there's a link to that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It's also available on our website.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And in there, within that, there's just a couple of statements that I think are relevant to the meeting today, which are

[Melanie McLaughlin]: You know prioritize systems that support a shared vision for disability awareness anti racism anti bias and cultural proficiency across the district.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: and provide equal access to academic support and enrichment, so I really want to ground us in that part of the strategic plan, which is where we're really feeling like.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: This statement applies and so folks may know that anybody receiving federal funds, of which most public schools do.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: they're required to have what's called a non-discrimination clause in their documentation on their website.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It's supposed to be pretty easy to find, very straightforward.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Ours is not particularly easy to find, and we can talk more about that shortly.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But, you know, I just spent a bit of time just putting in

[Melanie McLaughlin]: words like non-discrimination, disability, gender, sort of those things, and it didn't readily come up.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: There is a statement from the superintendent on the homepage that talks a little bit about it, but it's not an actual non-discrimination clause.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: There are some, both in our policy, school committee policy statement and on some of the

[Melanie McLaughlin]: the ADA requirements on the website.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But again, I definitely think it could be more prominent.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But in any case, the non-discrimination clause is required, and it's, you know, what you typically see, people are probably really familiar with it, meant for public schools or your employment or any other place does not discriminate on the basis of, you know, so on and so forth.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And

[Melanie McLaughlin]: The definition of non-discrimination is the practice of treating people, companies, countries, et cetera, and the same as others in order to be fair.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And then I just wanted to share the definition of inclusion because I don't necessarily think that a non-discrimination statement or clause is also an inclusion clause.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: A well-written one should be, but that's not always the case.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so inclusion by definition is, and again this definition is from, you know, the CDC among others but they, I believe, took it from some of the laws and IDA what have you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But it's that all children regardless of ability or disability.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: have the right to be respected and appreciated as valuable members of the school community, fully participate in all school activities, and interact with peers of all ability levels with opportunities to develop friendships.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So that's a little bit different than non-discrimination.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I'd like to say it's more strength-based, frankly.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I think it's nice.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It doesn't sort of have that, you know, some of the negative language that sometimes people see in the non-discrimination around

[Melanie McLaughlin]: There's some articles that I've referenced in here that folks can link to and check out if they want to just around the differences between the two.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I do want to share an example from the community of one example of an inclusion form, if you will.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And this was something that the Medford Special Education Parent Advisory Council and others, community members, worked with the Medford Recreation Department to include on all of their documentation.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So it's a good example of something within the community.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so on all Medford Recreation

[Melanie McLaughlin]: notices, notification, what have you, they have the statement you see here for participants who wish to request special accommodations for program, please fill out our inclusion services request form.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: and please submit the form to, and you have the email here to submit the form to.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: In a minute, if folks want, I can click on that hyperlink and we can look at an example of the inclusion services request form.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Here are some references to the conversation that I'm having now and sort of the origin of some of the conversation and the requirements for non-discrimination, but also some of them that expand to

[Melanie McLaughlin]: inclusion.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And again, I'm not a lawyer, I'm not gonna get into the legal aspects, but under section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act and ADA, particularly in IDA as well, there are requirements to be inclusive of all persons, including students with disabilities, of course.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Here's some resources I shared with you guys.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: The first is just an article written by a professor that I thought was pretty interesting on how she makes her syllabus more inclusive and the way that it's evolved over time.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I thought that was sort of interesting, particularly having studied inclusive education at the Harvard Graduate School of Education and working with Professor Hare there and him often talking about ways that we're actually

[Melanie McLaughlin]: considering being inclusive and the ways that, you know, he would often let people know they can stand up and stretch if they need to.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: They can sort of, he always made us use a microphone to make sure everyone could hear.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: There were just little different things that, ways to be inclusive beyond, you know, some of the standard

[Melanie McLaughlin]: quote unquote accommodations.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: The Every Student Initiative, I think, is something that you guys, you know, might want to take a look at.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: The link says ensure every student has access to high quality learning, but it's not just that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It's also about life of the school, enrichment activities, athletics, and so, you know, essentially the 504 Rehabilitation Act, ADA, and

[Melanie McLaughlin]: IDEA all apply to the life of the school.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So it's not just the academic day, it is the life of the school.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So any activities that students participate in as a school-based activity, these can include volunteer activities, these can include enrichment activities from outside organizations, what have you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But if they're the life of the school,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: meaning they're attached to the school, everyone in the school has been invited, they're in the school building, not necessarily have to be in the school building, but those sorts of things apply under ADA 504 and IDEA.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I'm happy to go back to some of these documents if folks want to look at them for a second, but I just wanted to share that the purpose really is for us to look at

[Melanie McLaughlin]: a sample inclusion statement or accommodation statement.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Some people call it accommodation statements.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It's interesting because when you look at inclusion statements these days, what's coming up a lot is DEI, DEI statements, which are also really interesting and some people refer to

[Melanie McLaughlin]: disability in their DEI statements and some people don't.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Some people it's strictly anti-racism, which is another conversation that folks have because we all know disability is part of diversity as is culture and language and race and lots of things.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But that was interesting in the search, but we did find some good examples.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I sort of wanted to give you guys that as like a starting point.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So here's an example.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I think this might have been either from Harvard or from.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: University of Virginia, but I can reference it if we need to.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So we value inclusion and access for all participants and are pleased to provide reasonable accommodations for this activity slash event.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Please contact.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And you know, sensibly, this school committee or.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: the superintendent will have to clarify, would have to decide who a contact would be.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It could be potentially an assistant principal, it could be the 504 coordinator, it could be director of pupil services.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Please contact so-and-so to make a reasonable accommodation request, and then a date for a request to be submitted, and then noting that the event is accessible.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Another organization said they recommend using an accommodation statement and publicity materials on all documents to let individuals know how to request accommodations for your event or program if needed, but also that it's accessible, like this event is wheelchair accessible or any of the other accessibility standards that we need to know.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I'm going to stop there for a second.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I want to just show you guys a little bit more further down about

[Melanie McLaughlin]: sort of some of the things that we can look at.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So we're going to look at some examples from Medford Public Schools about what's currently on our website and otherwise, and then some examples from other school districts about what's on their website, and then hopefully have a more robust conversation as well.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But I just want to stop right there for a minute and let my colleagues and others take a breath and see if there are any questions or comments so far.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Well, I would defer to Joan on that, but I would say yes, anything that is the life of the school.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So if they're using school facilities, if it's including all school, all non-disabled students, if there are opportunities for that, then yes, but I want to ask the director of pupil services for perspective.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And each building has a 504 coordinator?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Yes.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Okay, thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I think that's a good question.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And that's something that I really want the group to discuss.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I think, so not only obviously the enrichment activities, the life of the schools, but obviously this applies to field trips, this applies to all things.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And that is a big reason that we wanted to have this meeting today is because it is the fact that a lot of parents don't know that students are entitled to accommodations for life of the school.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And frankly, there are a lot of staff members that might not understand that as well.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so I think it's important that this information goes out to you know any information that is that is a life of the school event so if it's an email going out from the principals about a school based activity if it's a potentially.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: a field trip form, anything, you know, similar to a nondiscrimination.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So, one of the suggestions I had is to include the nondiscrimination statement on documentation and with an additional, you know, sentence or two around, you know, if your student requires accommodations, right, what you can do.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Because really, we're supposed to be doing this.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: This is not like, you know,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: a favor we're asking.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: This is something that the district's really supposed to be doing.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It's just that how is the information actually reaching families and getting to families and getting to staff and it's not quite clear how that is.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I think the difference and again,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Joan, I would defer to you, but I think that a little bit of the difference is the difference potentially in reasonable quote unquote accommodations, right?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So reasonable accommodations, but if it's in the life of the school, there is a, you know, aspect of that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So, you know, there's been some historically some experience and I totally and fully understand that the PTOs are,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: volunteer organizations, right?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And a lot of these events are fundraisers or afterschool enrichment opportunities or what have you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And if they're going to be held in the school and they're going to be offered to all students in the school, students with disabilities cannot be excluded under federal law, among other things.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So the issue is not whether that's

[Melanie McLaughlin]: appropriate or not, in my opinion, the issue is how do we make sure that everybody's informed that students with disabilities and all students need to have access.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so if there are students that require additional accommodations, then we need to create a plan for them to be able to reach out to, again, Ms.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Bowen has said, the ETL or building principal, which I think we should be really clear about.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: to discuss a reasonable accommodation.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And we do, a lot of the reasonable accommodation requests have a date on them.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So for example, with Medford Recreation, they have a reasonable accommodation request.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: If your student, if your child needs, you know, additional support to participate in this activity, please let us know by X date, you know, if say, so that we're not finding out, so that the school's not finding out the day before, you know, that there's a request for accommodations or something like that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: accommodation or inclusion.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so we also have a school committee policy on non-discrimination.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So it's the AC non-discrimination policy, which is part of the MASC boilerplate, if you will.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I think we did have a little bit of changes to this.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I think member Rousseau might remember better, but as a member of the rules policy and equity subcommittee, I believe that we did have some review of this language change, but not

[Melanie McLaughlin]: fully.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And again, it's a little bit different from an accommodation statement.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So a non-discrimination statement is different.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And you can see, you know, it talks about an integrated society, it talks about positive experiences, it talks about

[Melanie McLaughlin]: You know, other things, and it's the policy, not to discriminate and sort of what happens if you do discriminate or could happen if you do discriminate, but it doesn't talk about well what if you need accommodations, what if you need, you know, other things it doesn't sort of take that next step on our policy.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But the other is the school lunch.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: There's also something on non-discrimination under the school lunch because they're required by the USDA federal organization to anyone that gets for federal funding is required to publicly state and have a public facing non-discrimination statement.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I noticed that our school lunch department has one on their page under the USDA requirement.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Just quickly, a sample from Newton Public Schools.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: This is a non-discrimination statement from Newton Public Schools.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It's not necessarily an accommodation statement.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I haven't done a deep dive into other districts to see about that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: One of the things I liked about the Newton Public Schools non-discrimination statement is that as you can see here where I highlight,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Newton Public Schools does not exclude from participation, deny the benefits of Newton Public Schools from or otherwise discriminate against any of these individuals.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So, you know, that exclude from participation is part of it, deny the benefits of, you know, is another part of it.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So they're sort of covering themselves there under

[Melanie McLaughlin]: the being more, you know, broad in terms of making sure that people aren't being excluded, although, again, there's no direct instruction on how to get accommodations or to request accommodations if your student needs to.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Yeah, they talked about, Marblehead I liked, it talked about being proactive allies, fostering belonging and acceptance.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And again, these are more DEI statements, I mean, more non-discrimination statements than they are active accommodation statements, but there's some sort of examples.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But going back to the top now, and again, this document would be available.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: to all, and I would very much recommend that people look at some of these if they're so inclined.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I also just wanted to share there was a recent Supreme Court ruling for a deaf student, which I'm sure Joan is very well aware of this.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: This was a landmark decision that just happened recently, where a student

[Melanie McLaughlin]: who was, you know, not receiving accommodations in his school district, not just related to academics, but to all activities, was able to exhaust all of his efforts, both under IDEA and ADA.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So in some instances, IDEA, you know, it is through the Problem Resolution Service where system or

[Melanie McLaughlin]: yeah, problem resolution system, no, program quality assurance, PQA, sorry.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But in any case, it's through that system.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And ADA, which is the civil rights piece, is through the Office of Civil Rights in terms of people who want to, you know,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: who have a complaint and want the complaint to be explored.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: This ruling was landmark and it just happened like a month or two ago because it said that a student is not limited to one or the other, that they can actually file claims under both.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So they can file claims under both IDEA for some of the academics, the accommodations around that and ADA, which can open districts up potentially to twice as much liability.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And it's an important ruling

[Melanie McLaughlin]: frankly, I think all districts should know about.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I know certainly if I was still in my policy class at the School of Ed, we would be studying this inside and out, because it's a really important decision.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And there are a few, there are probably like a handful, maybe between five and 10 landmark decisions over the years, past 40 years, that have to do with individuals with disabilities in schools, and so they're really important, and that's one.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So getting back to a proposal of a statement.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So one of the things that I had and I can highlight it.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I don't know, I think we're pretty much in an e-world, right, where everything is pretty much transmitted electronically.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so I think sharing that information is relationship building, not sharing that information causes distrust and then a deterioration of relationship.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so that's the thing that I think

[Melanie McLaughlin]: is really the whole genesis of this conversation is about how are we building relationships to ensure that families know what's going on in school and can help support their child and their teacher and the school and vice versa.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So there's that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so to the point of our goals, when we were talking earlier about school committee goals, I think this is a really good example of ways in which we improve communication,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: when we're talking about communications across the district, also about systems and processes, and also about family and community engagement.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I think this is all a really good example of that and something, you know, as I'm moving forward and we're talking about things, I'm really trying to put in, you know, parenthetical notes about, well, what goal does this actually attach to?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: in terms of our district and really, you know, trying to think backwards around that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I think that that is the goal, um, in terms of improving communication, family community engagement and creating systems that are in price.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so to that end, I really, I don't think that we need to make a motion, but if you think we need to make a motion, I'd like to know that particularly around training of families and school brains, because my experience was

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I think probably partially in the system, you know, in middle school, that there was this, you know, school branches being used.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And it was being used at that time, which I'm dating myself, it was probably, you know, six or seven years ago at this point.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But at that time, it was being used by one school and not the other.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And, you know, so now I think there's more uniformity around it, but really ensuring that there's, you know, maybe a, you know, beginning of the year and a big year training.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: around what this is for families and that it's multilingual training so that is really helpful for families.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And then I would ask, do students who are in out-of-district placements and or in the 18 to 22 transition program have school brains?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Okay, so those parents and families obviously need training as well, that they do.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Okay, thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I think that's a great idea.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: resonating point in point in point.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: May I?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I'm Melanie McLaughlin.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I'm a school committee member.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I'm also a parent of three, two Medford high school graduates, one current Medford public school student.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I've lived in Medford for 23 years and I'm here tonight specifically because I want to support the superintendent in her role and because I want to support the school committee and the parents and families and students in the city.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We're all heartbroken about what has happened to our children.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: or the past few months, but it has not been just the past few months.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And there are plenty of people in the community that know that and that understand that it has been years.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We've had a bullying problem.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Most high schools have bullying problems.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: There's a rise in violence.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It's national.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: You can see it all over the country.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It is happening, particularly because of pandemic, but also because of the politicized nature

[Melanie McLaughlin]: of the hatred that exists in communities between polarized sides.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And our children are often mimicking what they're seeing their adults do.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And what I think is really important is what we've heard from city council members who are talking about finding solutions to work together, to collaborate, to change systems for all of our children, not some of our children, all of our children.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: This has been ongoing.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We're talking about not just the past four years of this administration, meaning this particular superintendent.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: This has been an ongoing problem from when other people were on school committee.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: from when people have been around for some time.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I want to clarify for the community and for city Councilors.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I'm not afraid of being yelled at.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I just don't like it.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I think it's inappropriate and unprofessional.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And when we talk about bullying in our community, I have never seen more of an example of bullying in our community that I see in the city council chambers every single week.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I think that everybody in the community would agree with that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I think we both know each other well, George.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We're all neighbors here.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We all know each other.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We all know each other.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Our children play together.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Great choice of support.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So the ongoing bullying is inappropriate and is what our children are seeing.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And that's what I would like to specifically point out.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We wanna figure out how to work, should collaborate together to change outcomes for all children.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And we make sure that this stops in our community and in our schools.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I'm here to do that, and I'm here to roll up my sleeves and help make sure that that happens.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I think we all should be doing that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Similar scenarios.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I think the documents a lot to digest, I will say that it's a lot for a family to sit down and read.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It's a lot for probably an educator or administrator, even though you know we know it's their job to also sit down and read.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I, one of the off the top recommendations that I would have and I want to put out there is that

[Melanie McLaughlin]: you know, me, the visual learner, I talk about this a lot, right?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Having a visual flow chart, you know, sort of image that is shared, what to do if, you know, if this, then that, what happens, what the process is and sort of a visual, you know, one page sort of chart that can help families and everybody understand what this process is and what happens.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: In middle school, we had a similar experience.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I did not know anything about a bullying report form.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Although we had gone to the principal at the time, just not a principal who's here with us any longer, but it was some time ago, but did not know anything about this, except for the fact that our CPAC, our Special Ed Parent Advisory Council, had a training on bullying.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And at the time the special education director Kathy Medaglio came and helped give the training and that was when I learned that there was a bullying report form that was required to be filed in that training.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And that was training for parents to be clear, professional training for parents to understand so that's the other thing I think really needs to happen in terms of I know this professional development.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I'm sure there's professional development that will be coming out as a result of recent events, but also as a result of this document.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I want to ensure that there's also family training around this.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And this was something that we had asked for specifically at the time as well, back in middle school, that there be some sort of, you know, they said there was an annual presentation in the auditorium

[Melanie McLaughlin]: or that they brought outside vendors in around this, but it was not really, you know, that I was aware of really fully understood or explained to parents.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I think it's something that should be happening regularly so that families can understand what their rights are and what the processes are.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So in summary, I would say one, a lot to digest.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Two, I really recommend a visual for also just for our families who have language barriers, a visual support and one that is translated to one page.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: visual support and one that's translated for our families, and three, that there be training offered for our families in addition to our professional development for staff.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thanks.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Oh.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It's Member McLaughlin.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Hi, just as a committee member before we start dialogue with the specific other programming.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I also just wanted to be clear and make sure that we point out that I know that Joan Bowen's not here tonight, understandably, but I also want to make very clear that students with disabilities have requirements in their IEPs.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: that they are given, you know, bullying information, that their families have bullying plans in place, and that the child has been educated regarding bullying.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And, you know, it's unclear how or when or in what ways those are followed, but there's very specific training for students with disabilities and with their families, and also, you know, training around manifestation hearings and whether an incident is related to

[Melanie McLaughlin]: a disability or not, it's very important and very highly legislated.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I just wanna make sure that we're all really clear about that and that as we move forward, folks are provided that training or offered some training around that as well.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I certainly have resources for that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Dr. Edouard-Vincent, if you're interested in them and I'm happy to share them with you offline, but just wanted to put that out there.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thanks.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I appreciate talking about the process.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I think for me, it would be really helpful to have a shared Google Doc that we're editing together, not necessarily during this meeting, but one that we can bring back to the next meeting as opposed to having just elements cut out all together and having a new document that we're working from, because I really want to make sure that it's collaborative, number one, and that we understand what is going and what isn't, because something that may look

[Melanie McLaughlin]: non-essential to me or you might actually be extremely essential in terms of the law.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So what I would recommend is that we have, this is, I love Google Docs, I think this is a great choice.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I think that we can be working on this document, as you know, simultaneously and also be keeping a record of

[Melanie McLaughlin]: sort of the work that we're doing and the comments and what have you that we make as opposed to having one person do the bulk of the work and then coming back to the table with it.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So that would be my recommendation.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I think it's important that it's collaborative and that we really understand

[Melanie McLaughlin]: the edits that you're proposing and being able to take time to absorb how that affects what's left in there and or whether or not there are some legal issues, as I said, because particularly with students with disabilities, there's a lot of legal matters that we have to make sure that we're abiding by.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thanks.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Well, sorry, to be clear, I think what I'm not suggesting that we're editing it simultaneously, unless that's what Howard is saying we need to do.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Howard is our attorney, the school committee's attorney, attorney Greenspan, is suggesting that we need to do that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I'm saying that we would, independent of each other, look at

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I guess the work that you're sharing here and be able to have our own input that potentially we could share at the next meeting so that we're not just cutting things today and not having a reference as to what was cut and why and where.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I think it's important to have documents that we can follow back the thread of thought in terms of what was being done.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But I agree, I think it's worth asking Attorney Greenspan about what the open meeting law requirements are.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: main purpose for speaking up with this is that I'm not comfortable just taking out big chunks of material without knowing and taking time to look at the document as a whole to see how or whether it affects other bits of material, particularly in terms of legal.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so I'm not really clear on what the process would be to do that because it's a 38 page document, but we should consider that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I was first learning about disability and disability advocacy.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It was a mother who was working with a family leadership series as part of a state organization.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: She's a Medford mom.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: She had a teenage daughter at the time, who was in a wheelchair very complex medical needs and about.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: She had a birth injury, and her daughter was about 15 but had sort of the intellectual ability of a less than one year old and very physically not mobile.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: and was in Metro Public Schools, but was in a residential program because of her complex medical needs.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But even in residential programs, our complex medically, complex children with medical needs come home, right, for holidays, vacations, summer vacations, what have you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: This particular little girl, when she would come home with her mom, who did not have access to a vehicle, what have you, to get around as much as she wanted to, had no place to take her daughter.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: She had no playground to go to, and all her daughter wanted to do was swing.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: She loved to swing.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And she was in a wheelchair, and there was no ability for her to swing.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so I knew when this project came about that I really wanted to work on it, and also that I really wanted to make sure that there was an ability for a person with a disability in a wheelchair to be able to get on a swing with their child, who really needed it.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: and you know this is probably the thing I'll be most proud of having worked on as a school committee member and I'm really so you know honored that you guys are part of this and that member Graham and everybody else in the community is part of this and I really want to know in terms of donating sign me up if you need you know I'm happy to donate whatever whatever we need to try to make this happen I think this is really critical so thank you so much.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thanks.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Because I think it would be really interesting.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I know you as educators know that

[Melanie McLaughlin]: data tells a story.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Is there not?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so that can help us really understand better.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Because I think part of the, and I may be mistaken, but I think part of the reason that this is being brought

[Melanie McLaughlin]: to the policy floor.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And part of it is because we didn't have one, but also because as school committee members and as community members, we hear, we do hear stories from families specifically around some of these consequences around recess.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And we want to be able to bring families and schools together and families and administrators together to make sure that we're all coming up with effective solutions.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I would just encourage if that was going to be the case, that data be collected and that somehow that data be disaggregated and shared so that we can understand what that is and what it looks like.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thanks.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Um, yeah, so I guess to that point in terms of the data, um, you know, some families may not know that their Children are not going to recess.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so I'm also thinking about instances where we have, you know, students who are out of district, if it's a non-school day in Medford, but it's a school day in the district that they're in, how are we addressing, you know, that, especially if it's, you know, 7 45 in the morning, you know, folks aren't, you know, is there a protocol that sort of,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: made aware to families either on the website or otherwise, and if there's not, can there be?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Obviously the paraprofessional issue is very concerning.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I know that you and I have talked about this a number of times as well, and I'm mentioning it here publicly because I think folks know that it's an issue as well.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So it was brought to my attention earlier today that even postings for the paraprofessionals, if we could just go across all platforms and any platforms that are out there for postings, and I know every district is sort of looking, but

[Melanie McLaughlin]: The CPAC sort of alerted us tonight that there's not postings in different job listings.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I know a lot of folks go to SchoolSpring, and I forget the other ones, some of the other ones that are more popular for the world of education.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But if we're really trying to cast a wide net, if we're going to places like idealist.org,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: LinkedIn and I mean not LinkedIn, Indeed and some other places, just to make sure that we're casting as wide a net as possible.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I'm very concerned about the obvious potential legal ramifications, especially when there are students requiring paraprofessionals on a one-to-one basis in their classroom.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I know if maybe

[Melanie McLaughlin]: through the chair or through the superintendent, if the Director of Pupil Services wants to address that at all, just for public consumption, that would be really helpful in terms of how that's happening, because I'm getting a lot of questions particular to that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I'm also thinking about our therapeutic learning program in classrooms, a lot of those

[Melanie McLaughlin]: specifically, we talk a lot about our most vulnerable students, and they're also our most vulnerable teachers and paraprofessionals in those classrooms.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So how are we really working to remediate?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I know in some instances, Central's going into the classrooms, which I'm sure that's an extra burden on everybody as well.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So how can we help?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: How can we help spread the word?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: What can we do to get extra help in there?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And also, you know, I'm sure that we're

[Melanie McLaughlin]: meeting legal requirement, but just if you let folks know what that is and what that looks like, it'd be helpful.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Can I follow up?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Can I follow up there?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Just to follow up to that, thank you, Ms.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Bowen, and appreciate that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And obviously, if families have concerns, they can reach out to their ETL at the school, letting them know if there's concerns specifically around paraprofessional coverage.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But obviously, with one-to-one, for compensatory, I know you're talking probably speech, OT, that sort of thing.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: you can't do compensatory for one-to-one in a classroom, so you obviously have to.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Okay, because I know some IEPs have one-to-one for the students specifically, and sometimes with the shortage, if there's a
