[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I would just make that recommendation.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Developing a district wide focus on instruction and assessment.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So the overall score was a 3.69 and comments were would like to see more on differentiated instruction and universal design for learning to include all learners.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We could benefit from the expertise of special educators working with general educators to create a library of sorts of differentiated material instruction.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Don't feel the learning walks are as inclusive of all communities as they could be.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Also wondering how the curriculum frameworks are being met in classrooms like access classrooms and out of district programs.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: The superintendent evaluation primarily mentioned professional development as a means of achieving this goal.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: However, professional development

[Melanie McLaughlin]: is a short duration activity.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We need to see data and accountability on how these professional development topics are actually put into practice.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Mention of the monthly coherent practice with principals, but not of how those leaders that incorporated that learning into their schools.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: If there's data on this, the school committee would welcome it.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Sure, thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I think that in some of this, it would look like general education collaborating with special education and others, so that I know that there's some levels where there's co-teaching happening in some of the classrooms, but not across the district as a whole substantially.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And for example, I know

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Susanna Campbell and Joan Bowen had worked collaboratively with other teachers on differentiated programming and creating a library that's available on our website for some lesson planning that's differentiated, but I'm not sure or it's unclear what's been done in terms of PD for universal design for learning and how that's actually being incorporated into the classrooms.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And then in the learning walk, sort of, you know, looking at

[Melanie McLaughlin]: the curriculum frameworks and how they're being used across the district and also in other districts.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So for example, we know we have certain curriculum at certain levels, so elementary, middle school, high school sort of curriculums, but is it the same curriculum that is being used in the special education classrooms?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: If so, how are they being differentiated?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: If not, what is the curriculum and how does the superintendent know what the curriculum is?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: whether we're having high standards for all children, even children that potentially are taking MCAS ALT and don't affect our data scoring.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Personally, I think that that could look like curriculum meetings with special education and looking at as a whole.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We also have as a responsibility as a district, I understand,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Or I've recently understood that we are required to look at curriculum, particularly for our collaborative, and seeing what our collaborative partnerships are in terms of curriculum.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: That's part of the school committee's responsibility with DESE, from what I understand, but also the superintendent.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I guess I would venture to say, can the superintendent say clearly what curriculum, if any, is being used in these other classrooms?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: how curriculum is being differentiated for all learners.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Again, students with learning differences, but also, you know, students at all different levels, project based learning, what have you, and what that looks like in a variety of programming.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So, you know, from the access classroom to the connections to the EL classrooms to

[Melanie McLaughlin]: to our out of district programs?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So your directors of our collaborative, your directors of our special education, your directors of our EL and looking at how is the curriculum really manifesting across those different strands in terms of really embedding equity.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: and those in having high expectations for everyone.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I hope that was helpful.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: They were

[Melanie McLaughlin]: three paragraphs of comments.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Basically, again, wondering if this is happening with special education and programming curriculum out of district placements, whether all students are in a proximal zone of learning.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: There's much work to be done.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Commitment to math excellence at all levels is clear.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: There remains opportunity at the secondary level to focus on remediation of students in literacy and math in particular.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: where elementary experience was not the same as today's standards.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: There's more action needed to bridge gaps because of the pandemic that existed both before the pandemic and certainly were exacerbated through the pandemic.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: The K-12 health curriculum needs to be a significant focus in the next year.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It's not implemented consistently.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: and pandemic-related gaps are not closed.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: The elementary curriculum is not up to par, and the current curriculum does not adequately reflect focus on all the aspects of health expected from a modern, comprehensive health curriculum.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I would also add, if I could just add the ring here a little bit, maybe we can add it in, is that there's nothing for special education in terms of the health curriculum as well, differentiated health curriculum.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: A focus on instructional leadership needs to branch out from just the core curriculum areas that are covered by MCAS testing.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So again, not just focusing on the MCAS testing curriculum levels, but across all instructional levels.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: A health curriculum that's taught by appropriately certified professionals that covers all areas of health, inclusive of sexual and reproductive education needs to be a focus in the coming year.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Sexual and gender minorities do not appear to be receiving appropriate health curriculums that is inclusive of their needs.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And again, I would add the same for disability and perhaps EL, I'm not sure.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: This topic has been brought up many times, but continues to not receive attention it deserves for the health, safety, and happiness of our students, not covered by the heteronormative health curriculum.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I'll also add DESE just modified their health curriculum frameworks.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It was something like from 1999.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And that's not the way one wants to find out, especially when we want to support our students while they're in school.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: because that seems not to either be an existing policy in the current rules policy and equity listing and or some vagary in the student handbook.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So that's my specific.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Is that helpful?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Mayor?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: CLB incident reports.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I will amend that to the motion.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Yes and also you know just to make matters a little bit more confusing and I know the Director of Pupil Services knows this but not necessarily all educators know

[Melanie McLaughlin]: you know, that the disciplinary referrals for students with disabilities has some requirements and some structure.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so, especially regarding suspension and expulsion and some other issues.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So there's some nuances around this.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I just wanted to mention at the

[Melanie McLaughlin]: CCSR project exposition today, Representative Donato was there as well, but I just wanted to highlight a couple of the projects that the students are doing, because I just do think that for folks who are listening or online, CCSR is the Center for Citizenship and Social Responsibility, and this is a group organization across the middle schools and high schools where students volunteer and they create community-based projects.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: being there today just, you know, it was so inspiring and gives me so much hope for our students and for our district to see what CCSR does and what the students bring to the table.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: There was an English language give back project where students help with interpretation for families who are English learners.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: There was a veterans recognition where they're sharing stories of veterans from the war.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: There's a stand with Ukraine where the students raised, I think, thousands of dollars to support

[Melanie McLaughlin]: folks in Ukraine, the Mystic River Cleanup, Seeds to Feed, Seeds to Feed, they built a garden with food in the quad at the school and they brought the food, the produce to one of the food pantries.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Period Poverty, where they're helping other students who experience period poverty, the CCSR Memorial Garden to recognize those in our community who have passed during COVID.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So much of it was just so inspiring and I just think that our students and Rich Trotter and Michael Skorka and all of the folks at CCSR that do this work should be just lauded for all of this and for the community members for next year when this happens, encourage community members to come and see these projects and see the students that are working on them because they are really inspiring and something that I think can bring us all further together.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: how many families are aware of the voucher program, right?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And how they access the voucher program, particularly when we're talking about grandfathering in people, right?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I would be really reluctant to vote yes on, you know, ending this right now and having the current folks grandfathered in because I want to give people the opportunity to be grandfathered in and get these vouchers through perhaps some, you know, outreach or education to families about the availability of the vouchers.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I guess also because we don't have a clear delineation on what the hardship application that's going to be developed looks like.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: it's all kind of ambiguous.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I know that the intent here is, is really on point in terms of let's get rid of the bureaucracy and the paperwork and make sure that we're getting access to our students and really being there for them.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But in reality, at the same time, the EEC voucher, you know, is created for some reason to be able to get families, you know, access.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So if we can create a comparable sort of system without the bureaucracy, obviously,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I think that that's great, but we haven't yet, and so how do we how do we sort of make that bridge, I guess, is what I'm saying, so I want us to really be thoughtful before just just moving ahead, because I obviously don't want to and I know you don't want to.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: exclude folks who are economically disadvantaged.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I think it is a real disappointment that so many of these families qualify, but they're not actually using the budget program.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And knowing one of the directors at the EEC, I think, you know, she would be horrified to know that that's really what's happening on the ground level.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I'm sure that the data bears that out for them.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So they see that in some way, as we know, with the SNAP gap and other things, why aren't people applying?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Um, I guess I would just say, I would like to be a little bit more thoughtful and just sort of moving ahead with it.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Although I, I, I do appreciate and understand the motive behind it.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I would just love to know, you know, and again, what families want.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So, you know, whether it's a, the community engagement subcommittee or, or what, I don't know, but you know, what does the hardship application look like?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: How will it be developed and implemented with community input so that we're making sure that we're being thoughtful about this, but also really having an outreach program regarding the voucher program so that families know

[Melanie McLaughlin]: that they could be grandfathered in for the rest of their child's stay if they're in fact eligible.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I was wondering if- Actually, I was just gonna see if we could speak to it first, sorry.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: May we speak to it, Mayor?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Is that okay?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Sorry, I just wanna make sure that everybody understands the intent of the motion as well, is that some of these things are currently happening.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So there is an ethics training that we do online.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: There is often an MASC training.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: or there was one that I did in the first term, and I'm assuming that happens regularly for other folks.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It's not happening in January, obviously, or even before for new members.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But our policy, current policy also has this as policy BIA, where the school committee and superintendent will assist each new member to understand the committee's functions, policies, and procedures of the committee.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: as soon after election as possible.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Each new member shall be given the following materials, a copy of the school committee policy manual, a copy of the open meeting law, a copy of the conflict of interest regulations, a copy of the district's budget, collective bargaining agreements and contracts, student and staff handbooks.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So there's actually more in our policy than what is in this school committee orientation motion.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I would ask that we include what's in the policy in the motion as well.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And just that ensuring that this is happening and being scheduled is what the motion is.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So it's really just putting a schedule to the policy that currently exists for orientation of school committee members.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And if member Hays obviously would like to speak on this, mayor, I just wanted to offer that opportunity as well.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Mayor?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Member McLaughlin?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I appreciate member Graham's mentioning the need that's in here because there are several and especially as new members from the last term.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I think we can identify with that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I would say I guess my only concern with this being part of the rules committee of the whole meeting that we're having is again this body has not defined

[Melanie McLaughlin]: what they see as rules and what they see as policy.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We have a current existing policy around making sure that the school committee orientation happens, which we just said was BIA.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And now we're saying that this should be moved to the rules meeting to make it a rule as opposed to a policy.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And again, to be clear around the policy manual,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: our current policy manual says that if we're gonna make a change to policy, we have to put it on our schedule as a policy change so that the community has input and that we are able to have the discussion.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So again, I don't know the difference here.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I'm trying to help me understand the difference you guys are understanding between rules and policy and whether we're superseding the current policy that says to have a policy change, we have to put it on the agenda, not at a committee of the whole rules meeting.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Okay.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I would agree with that, and we can have a conversation in the rules committee of the whole then about the policy for changing the policy after we make a rule.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I'll rescind the motion.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And again, since this is coauthored with member Hays, I just wanna make sure that obviously she's in agreement.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I know we'll take a roll but I'm fine with that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Second.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Aye.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: May I now?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: There was two things that I was looking at in policy around this that I just wanted to bring to my colleagues attention as well.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so one is, you know, the fiscal management goals policy, which is the DA.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And the first part of the fiscal management goals policy is that we engage in thorough advanced planning with staff and community involvement in order to develop budgets and to guide expenditures so as to achieve the greatest educational returns and the greatest contributions.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So, you know, I do feel like this is our fiscal responsibility to put a schedule forward.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I know that assistant superintendent Murphy was talking about a process and sort of having a different process than what we've had in the past, which is understandable as well.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But I do think we need to be able to lay out what that process is and how we're scheduling that so that the community can be involved in knowing what that is.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so the original motion that was approved was, whereas Medford Public Schools has historically conducted the annual budgeting process commencing in April and concluding in June, whereas there's a substantive increase in COVID-related funding for FY2022, whereas hiring practices in many districts are finalized by March-April, be it resolved the Medford Public Schools budgeting process commence in January and conclude in March,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: with budget recommendations presented to the city council in March.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So that was the budget.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I mean, that was approved on 11.8 by this body.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And then I just wanna, again, defer to my colleague, member Kreatz, if she wants.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Motion to approve.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Mayor.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I have a question that I'd like to start with before we really go into the specific rules.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I can put it in the chat if people want.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Policies will be adopted and amended only by the affirmative vote of a majority of the members of the school committee when such action has been scheduled on the agenda of a regular special meeting.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So again, to member Graham's point, to permit time for study of all policies or amendments to policies and to provide an opportunity for interested parties to react,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Proposed policies or amendments will be presented as an agenda item to the committee in the following sequence.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: One, information item, distribution with agenda.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Two, discussion item, first reading of proposed policy or policies, response from superintendent, report from any advisory committee.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It's not long, but I'm happy.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I have a question on 67 and 74 so 67 is motion to rescind which most of it is, I think, probably all of it is according to Robert's rules of order but I think there's some.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: nuance that I wanna make sure that we're understanding is that, so a motion to rescind a previous decision that was adopted by the school committee can happen at any time other than the current meeting, which obviously would be a motion to reconsider, but there's no time limit to rescind the motion, but there is some distinction around whether any portion of the motion has been executed.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And if the motion has already been executed or is in the process of execution, it might not be rescinded.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I just wanna make sure that

[Melanie McLaughlin]: my colleagues are understanding, this number 67.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I don't know why I'm... Yeah, actually, I think, yeah, I don't know.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I have to review it, but there was something about, yeah, for the next... For the next day, I haven't looked at it.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Yeah, so, hold on.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: If the original motion has been acted upon and that action cannot be undone, the motion cannot be rescinded.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So in other words, that will be left up, it sounds like, to the chair to determine whether action has been taken or not, and whether or not the motion can be rescinded.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: A lot of times it's two thirds vote, right?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: For these, for the rescinding?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: This doesn't have that in there either.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So my concern is that people, colleagues take the time to create a motion, you know, they explain it, it gets, you know, the committee approves and it passes, it gets passed and then,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: you know, if it's to be rescinded, you know, that we could sort of be going back and forth on this all the time.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: If, you know, we have folks who, whatever, want to rescind motions on the regular.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: If it's okay, I'd like to go to 74.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Yep.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Member Ruseau?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Motion, I mean, rule number 74, which is to suspend the Roberts Rules of Orders.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: parliamentary rules by a two-thirds vote.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I just feel like Robert's Rules of Orders are really consistent around parliamentary rules.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It's hard enough to learn all the parliamentary rules and procedure as a school committee member, and then finally learning them and being able to implement them is concerning if we're just gonna be able to vote them out.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I have a concern with eliminating Robert's Rules of Order by a two-thirds vote.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: most of these committees and others are run on Robert's Rules.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I guess I would love to hear Member Ruseau's concern with Robert's Rules for 74, please.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But it could be any of the Roberts rules.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So that's my concern.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And, you know, following parliamentary procedure is sort of the way that I understand suspending the rules for certain instances.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I'm just not sure why we have to have it written in that we can suspend the Roberts rules of order by a two thirds vote.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: If folks want to suspend the rules, we can sort of

[Melanie McLaughlin]: figured out then but even with that I would say, you know, if it's, you know, in this, you know, if we do an amendment or something that says, you know, in this one meeting or something like that my concern is you know there's lots of Roberts rules of order and there's a reason that there's Roberts rules of order so that there are rules of order.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And then if we're, you know, having options to suspend the rules of order, it makes me concerned that meetings can become disorderly.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Mayor, can I just make a comment just quickly?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I just wanted to thank Member Ruseau for all the work in putting this document together.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Obviously, did a lot of work, was very involved, so I want to say thank you for that, and I'm looking forward to reconvening on it.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Yep.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you, Mayor.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I did have a question on when the, will be provided with a list of its functions and duties to subcommittee by whom?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Who's gonna provide that?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: The whole committee or is someone being tasked to provide the list of functions?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Right, so I think maybe we can clarify who's going to do that, because I think that would be important as we're giving, you know, if we're tasking somebody with providing a list of functions and duties for the subcommittee, we should have an idea of who's going to provide those.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It's number three, Mayor, the last sentence.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And then, Mayor, I also have a statement from the

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Medford CPAC co-chairs that they asked me to read that they sent about an hour or two ago, because they're in route commuting and they don't want to do that from their car.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So if that's okay.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Oh yeah.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I think that it will be provided with the subcommittees will be provided with a list of its functions and duties, but I don't know by whom.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I don't know if we want to do that as a committee now to decide by whom those functions and duties will be provided.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Not the names, this is a list of its functions and duties through the chair.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So yeah, the names definitely, and the assignments obviously we already have through the chair, but if we want the chair to be providing a list of the subcommittee's functions and duties, I guess is what I'm asking, or somebody else, I don't know.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Yeah, this is from

[Melanie McLaughlin]: The co-chairs of the Medford Special Education Parent Advisory Council, which is tasked through mass law to advise the district on matters pertaining to special education.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Special Education Parent Advisory Council CPAC statement.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We represent and advocate for Medford students with disabilities and their families.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: The CPAC has concerns about the language that is proposed regarding school subcommittee meetings, specifically on how it affects the activity of the special education subcommittee.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: CPAC has advised and advocated with the school committee for many years, a forum needed to be created for a closer collaboration between school committee and CPAC.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: a collaboration which is not optional but mandated by law per MAS statute chapter 71B section 3.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: The parent advisory council duties shall include but are not limited to advising the school committee on matters that pertain to the education and safety of students with a disability, meeting regularly with school officials to participate in the planning and development of the school committee's special education programs.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: As a result of CPAC advocacy, the special education subcommittee was created in 2018 to fulfill this requirement of CPAC advising and collaborating with the school committee.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Back then we had a different mayor, a different superintendent, and a different school committee.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: The special education subcommittee works differently than other subcommittees because it has a different role, that of collaboration between school committee, CPAC, and the special education department.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Part of the assignment of the special education subcommittee is a dialogue with CPAC.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: An agenda set entirely by the school committee is no longer a dialogue.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We are concerned regarding the proposed language that, quote, the subcommittee may only need to carry out business referred to it by a majority vote of the committee.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Subcommittees will not need to conduct business brought to the subcommittee by other means or process.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: end quote.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: By the advising nature of CPAC, our mandated role is to bring business to the attention of the school committee.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We are concerned of a circular situation in which the subcommittee cannot meet because there is no agenda and we have no agenda because we cannot meet.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: In addition, we are concerned by the proposed language that, quote, a subcommittee will be dissolved by the committee upon completion of its assignment, or it may be dissolved by a vote of the subcommittee at any time, end quote.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: The language suggests that a subcommittee can be dissolved for any reason, even if the subcommittee's assignment might be ongoing and still relevant.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So many of you were not part of the history of the special education subcommittee.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: CPAC is asking the members of the school committee to reemphasize and remove the commitment of collaborating with CPAC

[Melanie McLaughlin]: for the benefit of the students and families we are representing.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We hope everyone here agrees with us on the amount of progress that has been made in the district regarding disability-related policies since we started this closer collaboration.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: The impact of this collaboration was recognized and commended by DESE in their most recent special education review.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We're asking that you maintain the role of the special education subcommittee, which is that of a continuous dialogue and collaboration between CPAC and the school committee, not only to fulfill the requirements of the law, but also Medford's recent commitment to family engagement and family school partnership.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you, Tanya Sullivan, co-chair, Alex Lorick, co-chair.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you, Mayor.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I think, you know, part of the discussion, too, is, you know, I guess, you know, what is policy?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And to me, policy is organic.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I have a master's degree in education policy and management from the Harvard Graduate School of Education, and one of the things that I learned there was that policy was participatory.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So we get feedback from our community on how we set policy.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: That is what the subcommittees are intended for, in my opinion.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And there are some things that have been brought to the school committee that were recommendations for policy.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Some of them were adopted, some of them weren't.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Specifically, one of the things that we had asked for for several years as policy was that there be a subcommittee created for special education.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And for three years, the CPAC, of which I was the former co-chair, so full disclosure,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: had asked for a subcommittee and that was being said as policy and that wasn't.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So this is part of the discussion is that, you know, we also have what was created through our discussions and that did not need to go to policy because it was, they were,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: curriculum matters or other matters was a disability-related curriculum was created as a result of the special education subcommittee working with community members and the director of pupil services and Susanna Campbell to create a pilot program for a disability-related curriculum much needed in our district and also something that we had recommended previously as a CPAC to the school committee.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: which was not adopted, but specifically they don't have the purview over curriculum anyway, so this was able to go that way.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We've also, the special education subcommittee also helped create professional development, again, working with community members and

[Melanie McLaughlin]: the school.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And that's the whole point of this.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It's back to family and community engagement and bringing community members together with school personnel, with school committee members to have an organic discussion around what policy should actually be and what should be recommended to the school committee, as opposed to just making our own policy and passing it here among the seven members.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I want to clarify for the record that when I was saying policy is organic, what I'm saying is the process of setting policy is organic.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It requires community engagement and staff engagement

[Melanie McLaughlin]: and administrative staff engagement, and that's part of the process in making policy.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We do roundtable these things to see if policy needs to be set or not set or come before the subcommittee or not.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Our specific goals for subcommittee, our requirements are

[Melanie McLaughlin]: to approve a budget, evaluate the superintendent, and set policy.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So some of the things that are under the setting policy are also ambiguous.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I also feel like when we talk about things being in black and white or this is the way it should be or shouldn't be, those are subjective conversations.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Law is subjective.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It depends on what your priorities are.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: in terms of subcommittee meetings.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And for me, my priority is building community relationships and building relationships with students with disabilities and staff members that are special education staff members and others, non-special education, behavioral health, mental health, sitting together, being able to discuss what is the issues, what are the issues that need to drive policy?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Because how do we know the issues otherwise?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Just by getting phone calls from constituents?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I mean, that doesn't make sense to me.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I don't understand that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And saying a member can put together a motion to ask if we can have a conversation about a specific subject that may or may not lead to policy, that doesn't make any sense to me.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And regarding the buddy system, I mean, the buddy,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: the Best Buddies program, that's only would become before the school committee if there was a cost, a directive cost involved.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: If there was something else that did not require a cost, if there was a donation, except if it was a donation over a certain amount, obviously it would need to be, but it doesn't necessarily have to be approved by the school committee as a policy issue.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Maybe it does, maybe elements of it do, but how do we know that unless we're talking with the Best Buddies constituents, the special education teams that may or may not want Best Buddies in their school,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: the ETLs at the school, the families of persons with disabilities.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And when we say, oh, we don't know about what happens in subcommittees, we have subcommittee minutes that we approve.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Every single time a subcommittee meets that we go through the minutes, read them and see what's on them.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And whether we agree with them or not, we have an opportunity at the next meeting to say that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I just feel like this is more of an organic process and not one that should be dictated by black and white because relationships and relationship building is not dictated by black and white.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you, Mayor.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I would agree that there needs to be guidance on the subcommittees.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: When this was first proposed to the school committee, that's accurate.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We were told initially that there would not be a subcommittee of special education because there were already so many subcommittees and many of them were defunct.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so there was no structure around that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: That was the whole point, that there needed to be a special education subcommittee because there was no structure around the committees that existed in the

[Melanie McLaughlin]: in the school committee prior to that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And, you know, I'm looking back to the letter that the co-chairs wrote and the quote that they said, a dialogue set by the school committee is no longer a dialogue.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I think that's the point is that CPAC came to school committee because they wanted to have an ongoing dialogue with some members of the school committee to be able to move things forward, to have the director of pupil services participate in that process, to have family members participate in that process, to have students with disabilities

[Melanie McLaughlin]: participate in that process so they could see the process of setting policy and come to the school committee at the end of the year and bring policy forward.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: interest and goals and what have you are, but then that's not a conversation.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: you know, motions being moved forward, but by a collaborative process.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: added on is special education and behavioral health, which are obviously two vast and very different topics.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So we decided this year, we would go with every other month going between the topics.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So back to the problem of practice.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: an issue of mental health services and supports being overwhelmed right now with requests with just so many requests, you know, in and around the community.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And that but that the identified resources weren't resources really weren't getting where you wanted.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So going back to the problem of practice and thinking back to what we had said at the at the last meeting about identifying resources for health supports for students and caregivers in our community and working together to propose policy around those resources.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So

[Melanie McLaughlin]: How do you think this could be operationalized as part of the subcommittee in a way that would be useful to the community around behavioral health, mental health supports?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: How can we utilize this group to help identify policy towards this end that would be helpful?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Do you think?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I mean, the discussion that we had before was sort of, you know, starting to have community members sort of, or subcommittee members sort of look at resources and, you know, talk to constituents and, you know, show up and share what resources have been useful to them.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But I think it was also about how to get those resources and information out into the community.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So is it looking at sort of, you know, similar to what your S3LC group is doing around

[Melanie McLaughlin]: you know, best practices in terms of what that looks like for getting supports out into the community and for collaborating around these.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I mean, I know that, I know that Paul Rebel at the Graduate School of Education at Harvard does a lot of work around mental health wraparound services and supports.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I'm sure that there's a lot of research and data around that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I don't know if that's helpful.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Like, I guess I'm trying to wrap my mind around what would be helpful to you and to your team and to the community.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Yeah, I mean, I think it's interesting.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I would love to hear from like, you know, others on the in the meeting, Miss Lucy, Mia, if you have any input that you want to share as well.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But I mean, I think

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It is interesting just even as a school committee member not realizing like again the Boston 25 piece and the in the press release out to the community around this particular project and so I guess, first I would say, you know, maybe it is breaking down what are the methods of communication now, you know, what do families, potentially feel like is working or isn't working so you know I hate to say, you know,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: This subcommittee was started a few years ago at the request of the Special Education Parent Advisory Council.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Our co-chairs here are here tonight for the Medford Special Ed Parent Advisory Council, Tonya Sullivan, hi Tonya, and Alex Lorick.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And again, the subcommittee was started a few years ago with their request in mind to be active participate

[Melanie McLaughlin]: participants in special education concerns and problems of practice to work towards collaborating on policy.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We're glad to have them here tonight.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Our format last year, we had tried during the pandemic to split the meeting.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: The committee was renamed or reconstituted as the Special Education Behavioral Health Subcommittee.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Last year, we were trying to do

[Melanie McLaughlin]: meetings that were divided between those two topics.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And we've decided, based on our meeting last month, we decided to consider a new format for this year, where we are having every other topical meeting.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So in other words, the current meeting is special education, next month meeting will be specific to behavioral health, and then we'll

[Melanie McLaughlin]: stagger each month, every other month for meetings, and that the feeling was that that would give us time in between the meetings to actively work on some of the issues and or concerns that were raised.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so in our last meeting, I can share the screen, my screen, and pull up our minutes from the last meeting.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Can you guys see my screen?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Yes.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Yes.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Okay.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so generally we came to that weren't a lot there was not a lot of participation at that meeting so I just want to go here to highlight sort of what we had been talking about as what we'll look at is the the special education proposed

[Melanie McLaughlin]: of practice to work on, and then I would like to put the proposed problem of practice out for discussion for the subcommittee to see if there's anything additional folks want to add or something altogether different.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But essentially it was identifying ways in which to build community and school friendships among our students with and without disabilities, specifically through recreational programming, after school activities and sports organizations, as well as in school meaningful inclusion.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: along with developing supportive language, recommendations for best practices.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So that last sentence sort of comes across what we're seeing in a number of these different entities, recreation, afterschool, sports organizations, is sort of not universal language and perhaps not, although well-intentioned, perhaps not the most

[Melanie McLaughlin]: thoughtful, I guess, into the disability community.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So we want to be aware of how we can make recommendations around some of the printed language we see and maybe some of the other things.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I would encourage folks to just sort of, you know, unmute themselves or if it gets a little too chaotic, which I doubt, we can

[Melanie McLaughlin]: we can, you know, raise hands.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But if folks want to unmute themselves, and if you do, please introduce yourself.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Again, because I know we all know each other here, but there may be people watching.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So if I might add, we had a meeting last night with Medford Recreation to discuss adaptive and inclusive programming with Medford Recreation.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And there was a community member there, Shanine Pelliquin, who's done a lot of work in this area, as you folks probably know, who talked about other districts and how they have worked with recreation departments and summer fun camps to sort of integrate all of these aspects.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: the students are actually receiving ESY services at the summer fun camp so the kids are getting their ESY service needs met and are also getting their social emotional inclusive needs met and so that was the the basis of the discussion really around you know what what are other communities doing what does it look like how could that look here and I think what we what I heard anyway from that

[Melanie McLaughlin]: that meeting especially was that you know oftentimes even with the progress that we're making in having a recreation department and having an adaptive program at the recreation department and having an adaptive PE teacher that there's still not meaningful inclusion yet but we know that that's the goal around equity especially because there's so many limits to you know what those programs look like and for example that

[Melanie McLaughlin]: The adaptive programming host about 10 students with disabilities, you know, in one given session, because they're, they're locked out after you know they have so much enrollment.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so, at the same time we know that in the past, special education.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: school based special education team has been providing training and support to summer fun to ensure.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Meaningful inclusion, they are so sort of it was it was this popcorn popcorn of ideas of what could this look like across these.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: You know issues, especially because we see the department does need training around inclusive and therapeutic.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: recreation therapeutic is different obviously that's more sort of license specific but inclusive, especially using CCSR volunteers and other volunteers, you know there's it's clear that there's certainly well intentioned.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: volunteers and also there's a need for for training and I know in the past.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Kathy was really open to providing that or and or you know, looking to a marker community to us to.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: do that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: EMARC does not look like they have, or CUNITAS, which is the local ARC, which is an advocacy group for people with disabilities, does not seem to have much going in the way of recreation right now just because of COVID.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I'm sorry.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I'm sorry.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Do you know?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And they are the most fantastic

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Congratulations.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: That's great.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: This is a report that is from an initiative that was created last year in partnership with the Department of Elementary and Secondary Education as a family school partnership initiative, spring of 2021 so partnership with several school districts met for was chosen after we applied to the process.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And they worked with a consultant to give us some feedback on family and community engagement.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I'm gonna be reading from my phone just because it's easier than the small print on this PowerPoint.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But the initiative was again, in June, 2021, an opportunity for districts to look at the family school and community partnership fundamentals, which are available on the DESE website.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It's about building family and community engagement

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so there's some guiding practices that they have around family and community engagement using that partnership fundamental.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And through the process, they created several groups in order to get some feedback on family and community engagement in Medford.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And they had four focus groups specifically that they worked with, which were number one was family members slash caregivers.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Number two was students grades eight to 12.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Three was teachers and frontline staff, and four was school and district leadership.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And they wanted to identify three priorities.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: What was working well in family and community engagement?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: What innovations did we have during the pandemic period?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And what opportunities did we have to build upon family and community engagement?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So the family member caregiver feedback group said that the pandemic really highlighted teamwork among teachers and family members caregivers, because of I imagine remote learning among other things, but that that dropped off substantially after the return to school.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Family caregivers felt there was a huge benefit in knowing what their child was working on.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: They felt listened to they felt like they were partners in the process and would like to see a better approach to orienting parents to the districts initially.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: They also parent and family caregivers have strong ideas about professional development.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: and they felt that they were asked for feedback on a regular basis last year, particularly, but then felt that their feedback was dismissed and they wanted more acknowledgement of diversity in the community.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: The second subgroup, eight through 12 grade students, their feedback generally from the focus group was that they did not feel like there were positive relationships for the students.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: The students felt left out.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: They said multicultural backgrounds were not included from their perspective.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: They want teachers to reach out to their families to say when things are going well, not just when things aren't.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: They wanted to see family training on technology and they felt language translation was an issue because of the overuse of Google for a translation tool.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: They also felt there was a lack of responsiveness from feedback among family and caregivers and students.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: From the teacher group, the teachers said they felt connected with families through tools like Zoom, and they wanted more time to build relationships with families.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: They wanted to see a district-wide effort for family engagement, not through forms, but through a district-wide effort to truly engage families meaningfully.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And they mentioned that they were actually shocked by how few families had access to computers in this past year.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So that was something that was an innovation

[Melanie McLaughlin]: through the pandemic that they were able to learn that and develop compassion around that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: From the leadership group, the school district leadership.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: School district leadership felt too much, there was a lot of information going out, but that it was one way information.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: They wanted relationships and two way communication.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And they said, because of competing priorities, family partnerships often falls to the bottom of the list.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: General observation from the consultant through dusty their sort of general observation summaries was there was a lot of info going out in communication for family and community engagement, but the information is not a two way communication it's a one way communication families engage

[Melanie McLaughlin]: regarding recreation.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: There's a vocal community but limited set of voices in the community.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Families view things with a partnership lens while schools tend to view things with an information lens.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Data on family and community engagement is not generally shared with families and note there were not any non-English speaking family subgroups that were created.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We had intended to do that and it did not work out in terms of scheduling and so

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We wanted to make sure that there was a note that that was not part of the engagement, which I think also speaks volumes.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: They recommended consider focusing on deepening staff district readiness and capacity for family school partnerships, especially around Fundamental Five.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: This partnership fundamentals that's available on DESE has five fundamentals and Fundamental Five is building capacity

[Melanie McLaughlin]: of staff.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So they said they recommend that Medford Public Schools consider focusing on deepening staff slash district readiness and capacity for family school partnerships.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: They think that Fundamental Five is seeing family engagement as a core practice, not a program or an individual or one job, valuing families as assets, a culture that welcomes and responds to constructive criticism,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: providing family voice data through transparency, collaborative data use surveys, et cetera, and more systemic approaches for building partnerships with non-English speaking families.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Those were the recommendations for the report.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: This was a really unique opportunity to partner again with DESE and this outside family and community engagement audit.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: The work can continue this year if the committee is interested in terms of moving those particularly fundamental five

[Melanie McLaughlin]: forward which was considering focusing on deepening staff district readiness and capacity for family and school partnerships, they did say that if we're not going to work on fundamental five really nothing else we do around family and community engagement is going to be effective.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So with that said, I would like to make a motion that we continue the relationship with DESE on the family school partnership initiative so that we can do the next year's work and looking at how to really increase that capacity for staff district readiness.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Well, part of the issue is that this is a grant-funded opportunity that was created last year.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So when it was published in DESE, it was applied for.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So they had to act quickly through reaching out to the community and working with the school administration to have this happen.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: The second part of this is available this year.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It doesn't last for the next year.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I don't know what phase three of the project would be.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I certainly think that the family

[Melanie McLaughlin]: that the community engagement subcommittee should and could be involved.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I believe that there was reach out from Siemens school in Maine to different subgroups some during a pandemic obviously did not respond but some did and there were certainly groups

[Melanie McLaughlin]: and engagement that were involved.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I would love to see the community engagement committee involved in this.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I don't know that moving it to the committee is going to be effective in terms of moving the process forward because School in Maine and DESE are offering the opportunity this year.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I think that there could be a collaborative effort with DESE and School in Maine and the communications subcommittee for sure.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I can check with Desi to confirm.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: They've been pretty open-ended so far, so I appreciate the flexibility, but I would also say that to the superintendent's point, and I can completely appreciate how stressed out we all were in this past term and during the pandemic, but I also feel that as was stated in the report, that there are so many competing priorities all the time, that family and community engagement

[Melanie McLaughlin]: is always one of the last priorities, because it's one that is often pushed back for, you know, more immediate needs, such as leaking roofs, which I can understand.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But at the same time, until we have a district-wide sort of hearts and minds around this issue, I think that it will continue to be pushed back.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And if we didn't see

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I think last year was real evidence of the importance of family and community engagement.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I felt like there were some real steps forward through the pandemic, as we talked about some of the innovation and teachers and families building relationships.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I would just hate to see that put on pause.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I can check on the DESE deadline and I can make a, I can revise my motion or withdraw my motion and make a motion to table until I get the deadline, if that's, if that is amenable.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Yes, there's a motion to table on the floor.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I've got a question.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Okay.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: The agenda for today's meeting is we're asking community members to join us as we determine annual goals for our special ed and behavioral health subcommittee, including proposed problem practice and how we can work together to increase meaningful family and community engagement regarding these proposed concerns.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So folks who don't know a little about the history of the Behavioral Health and Special Education Subcommittee, we were formed three years ago, actually, after multiple requests by the Special Education Parent Advisory Council, CPAC, to school committee to ask for a subcommittee specific to special education needs and issues, as there seem to be many, and these were in multiple annual

[Melanie McLaughlin]: reports to the school committee request for the subcommittee.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It was initially created by Aaron DiBenedetto as school committee while I was chair of CPAC.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So that's how we originated.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And we really decided on a problem of practice for special education was building friendships, is building friendships between students with disabilities and without disabilities in our schools and our community.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And some of the ways that we worked on that last year is looking at

[Melanie McLaughlin]: issues concerning Medford recreation and the creation of an adaptive, I mean, an adaptive, some adaptive programming for Medford recreation and

[Melanie McLaughlin]: an adaptive PE teacher in the schools, as well as unified sports.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So we feel like we're moving things forward a bit, which is nice.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It's nice to see some progress.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And then for special education, you know, the topic that we had addressed last year, problem of practice, if you will, is helping to create trauma-informed schools.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And there was some training and professional development that

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Stacey, you were putting forward regarding that, right?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And we had a few meetings on that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And then we had parents who are also mental health workers, licensed social workers in the community that participated in those meetings and had some really great ideas about engaging and involving family members.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I did reach out to some community members who were not able to attend tonight, but had asked that we put forward some ideas.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I would also just love to hear from

[Melanie McLaughlin]: maybe each of you, and maybe you could talk a little bit about the structure for the meetings for this year, how you requested that it be structured a little bit differently based on just the tight schedule everyone has under the COVID pandemic, everything that you guys are dealing with.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I don't know which one of you wants to begin, but maybe one of you could start to talk about the difference in planning for this year.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Joan, yeah, so what had been originally created as a special education subcommittee with a new administration in the 2019 term.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: additional subcommittees were created and topics were merged.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so we became, we moved from the special education subcommittee to these two really broad topics, behavioral health and special education.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So last year, we tried to do like an hour and a half meeting where we're splitting it 45 minutes for each topic.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I think

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Folks felt like that maybe was a little bit long and perhaps a little disjointed.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I think it'll be interesting to see how that goes and where people feel that's useful.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So that seems concerning.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Just so everybody knows.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So, you know, Joan, I'm sure you've heard people first language, right?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: You sort of heard, which for some people that's appropriate and for some people it's not.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Some people prefer to have their diagnosis before their, you know, so for example, some people in the autism community prefer to be called autistic, but people perhaps in the Down syndrome community,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: People with autism may prefer to be called an autistic person, man, woman, what have you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And people, for example, in the Down syndrome community may prefer not to have Down syndrome kid first, have a child with Down syndrome or something.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So it's sort of thinking about and educating community members and school staff and, you know,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: recreation staff and what have you around like what is and isn't appropriate language.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And, you know, I look to people with disabilities themselves to really drive that conversation.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so I would want to include self-advocates in that conversation and really be able to understand what does that mean.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so I think just in all of our language, in our school, you know, in our community and in our school brochures, but also in our, on our websites, on our, you know,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: just sort of universally sort of looking at what is appropriate language.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So, you know, when we say integrated, what does that mean?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And, you know, inclusive, what does that mean?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So maybe sort of just identifying what some of these terms actually mean to us and how we define them so that we're all sort of creating a primer, if you will, on what is, you know, acceptable and appropriate language in this way.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Because sometimes I think, and what I hear from families is that

[Melanie McLaughlin]: They see something in writing or notice something in a brochure, and it is perfectly well intended it is not meant to hurt or harm by any stretch, but sometimes you don't know what you don't know.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: you know, it can be considered, you know, painful to family members of children with disabilities and to children with disabilities themselves or people with disabilities themselves.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So just how are we being more sensitive around some of that?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I think that's one way to start.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Just around, again, brochures, you know, sports brochures, you know, signups, right?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Like when we talked before about having like, you know, some, you know,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: quote in the signups, for example, that we all know Medford public schools doesn't discriminate based on, you know, race, you know, ability, all those things, but what does that language really look like?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And how do we vet that as the special education subcommittee and make recommendations to the school committee so that this is universal language that's used across the districts and, you know, something that hopefully the city will adapt as well.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Sure.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So one of the things that we're trying to determine tonight, Heather, and thank you, Carmen, for joining, is, and for folks who don't know Carmen, is the superintendent intern in

[Melanie McLaughlin]: working with Dr. Edouard Vincent.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So thank you for joining.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: One of the things that we're working to do tonight is to identify a goal for the year for each of these particular areas.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I know for the behavioral health piece, one of the things that I heard a lot from the community last year for those who participated in our meetings and who were specifically talking about behavioral health

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We heard a lot about community family and community engagement.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So we had several folks who came on board and who wanted to offer support services around like how can we support the schools as professionals, not that we would have, you know, people come in and, you know,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: you know, volunteer in a professional capacity, but they bring professional expertise to the table.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I'm thinking, for example, Heather Rumenak, we know is a licensed mental health worker and, you know, who had identified a number of topics she felt were of concern.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so did it, you know, was it an annual event that we host that's sort of around awareness or, you know, was there some other way that we engage community members and especially around some of the

[Melanie McLaughlin]: behavioral health, mental health stuff.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We also had a family that participated regularly last year and I ran into mom recently who was talking a lot about invisible disability.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I think mental health is often, can often be what's perceived as an invisible disability when somebody has mental health needs and they don't necessarily wear those needs on their face or have an IEP accompanying them or a 504 accompanying them, or they may, but they still don't have those identifiable factors.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And oftentimes what can present, what can be anxiety can present as behavior.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: and can result in negative outcomes for our children in our schools and with our staff.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I think that that's a really interesting aspect as well to consider as a problem of practice, perhaps to explore.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And when we say problem of practice, I think that we think about what this subcommittee can do is offer resources, some research, some ideas

[Melanie McLaughlin]: and then come together to discuss them around how to address this particular problem of practice, hopefully come to some resolution by the end of the year on a couple of recommendations to make to school committee as policy.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I'm wondering if we want to just popcorn some ideas around perhaps, and Joan, I don't want to assume that we have agreed on the

[Melanie McLaughlin]: know, language and friendship sort of community thing yet either, so I'm just putting that out there, but I want to ask folks what they think specific to behavioral health goal, problem, or practice for this year.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Yeah, that's the thing is that I think that sometimes we think parents are aware of these opportunities.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I think oftentimes, maybe we're not communicating as effectively as we think, not you, Stacy, but

[Melanie McLaughlin]: just in terms of family and community engagement.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: the 28th.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So it's going to be next week, which is Thursday at six.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And this is where we'll talk about priorities for the year for a special education and or behavioral health.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So, you know, come to that meeting that'll be posted zoom and we'll ask CPAC to post it as well.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But this is where we can talk more as to about unified sports or expanding programs or, you know, any of these issues that we're talking about now.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So thanks guys.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We will work to improve communication.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I apologize, Jameel, that this continues to be an issue.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I know that, you know, Joan has reached out a number of times.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So, you know, as a school committee member, but also as a parent that's concerned about this, I'll follow up on this too.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And then Jameel and anyone else who's on this call who doesn't already follow your school's Facebook page or PTO page, every school has their own Facebook or PTO page.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: MHS slash MVTHS is the high school's Facebook page.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And they do post a lot of information there.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So definitely join that if you haven't.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And if you don't like to be on Facebook, you can always create an account just for that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But there is information shared there.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And then the superintendent mailings will make sure that you're getting that, Jameel.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I just wanted to add, if I could quickly, the Medford Recreation, we're actually, again, this is part of the Behavioral Health Special Education Subcommittee work because community is part of the life of the school and community for our students.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so we are establishing a meeting with Medford Recreation and the mayor, currently scheduled for November 17th at 5.30 p.m.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: If you can join us, it's gonna be likely via Zoom and or in-person or hybrid.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: If you wanna join us, that would be great to have families there.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We are advocating for additional funding for Medford Recreation to have more inclusive integrative programming, because right now they have pretty much two adaptive classes and about 20 or so other classes.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And the reality is with the Americans with Disabilities Act, students with disabilities are of course entitled to go to any of the classes and there should be supports across all of them.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And the adaptive program is really wonderful and great.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And we want to make sure that that is highlighted.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But you know, we also want to make sure that we're not creating subseparate programming, which further divides our kids instead of being integrated or inclusive, or integrated and inclusive and unified.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So that's part of the work we'll be doing with the mayor November 17.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We have a meeting with Metro rec several families are already coming if you'd like to come please email me and

[Melanie McLaughlin]: we can talk again about how we're moving this work forward.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But I think the exciting thing, and I don't want people to lose sight of the fact that it's happening, right?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: How long have we been wanting this and looking for it?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And it's happening now, right?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We have adaptive programming.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We have a rec department, first of all.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Now we have adaptive programming.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And we'll get to inclusive and integrated.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And we have the unified sports and adaptive PE.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And this is the first year for that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And it just means it's gonna grow and get better.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I'm excited about the change that's afoot.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Super exciting.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And Carla, I guess I just want to add one of the things that I used to be really sort of against like adaptive stuff, because I wanted Gracie to be able to just be able to be with the other kids.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I thought, you know, she has the right to be with the other kids.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And of course she does.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But she also deserves the scaffolding and the supports to be able to teach her how to do that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And that's really a big piece of adaptive PE and adaptive programming.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: was the person that really helped me understand that, that adaptive is about building a bridge to be able to support kids in the community in all kinds of settings.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I think it's really great to be able to look at it that way.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Bowen, just to say, may I, Mayor?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Yes, Member McLaughlin.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you, thank you, Mr. Murphy and I just, I just would respectfully ask my colleagues again to the chair that we recall this information when it comes budget time because it is, in my opinion and from what I've seen talking with families and especially if your child is, you know, not available for an hour or two and you're not really sure where they are and the angst and all the other things that that can cause this can be a full time job.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: for one person, never mind, you know, a family and community engagement coordinator newly hired to really engage families around a number of issues so I think that's really important for us all to consider.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And then I would just also before Miss Bowen responds I just also want to mention that

[Melanie McLaughlin]: You know, my concern around silos as well, Mr. Murphy, and I know you and I have had this conversation before and you've been very gracious in this conversation, but I do want to make sure that we're, you know, that it's not always sort of when there's a special education question and no reflection on you, but that it's deferred to, you know, to Ms.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Bowen, because I, again, want to just remind folks, and I know that it can sound like a beating a drum, but all of our students are general education students.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Some of them are receiving special education services.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I really think we need to be thinking about how we're breaking down these silos so that we're not having.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: different segments.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And that said, Ms.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Bowen, before you speak as well, we also have this out of district element.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so in my instance, I have a child who happens to be out of district on our recent holiday that we had revised our calendar.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Medford didn't have school on this particular day.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: My child is not a district placement.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: They did have school.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: There's confusion around transportation.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: The transportation didn't show up because they were confused that Medford didn't have school, what have you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And in that instance, there's actually no one to call because, you know, Medford's not in school.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So how are we really thinking about a general program across all of our community in terms of dispatch and transportation and being thoughtful about all of these ideas instead of

[Melanie McLaughlin]: still compartmentalizing or making subsections of people's jobs that already have full-time jobs.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So with that said, I guess I would ask Ms.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Bowen, and I know Ms.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Bowen, you and your staff have been remarkably responsive to a number of concerns that families have had, and especially for our more vulnerable students, where the risk can be heightened and the fear can be heightened for families.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I want to thank you for that first.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I just want to make sure that my colleagues are fully aware as we're considering the budget around these issues.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: One, that we're thinking about a person for this position, and two, that we're thinking about how we are breaking down silos to create a more equitable and inclusive school district.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so may I may I just what's the plan for Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: How do what what do families do in that instance?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So even on days when you have off, you guys are sort of also having to work the transportation as well.
