[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you, Superintendent and Dave and the administration for including me in this, because I'm really happy to recognize your leadership, your hard work, your dedication to the staff and students of Medford School Department on the occasion of your well earned retirement.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Six years ago, we became colleagues in protecting the health and well-being of the Medford Schools community.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Whether it was meeting as part of the School Health Advisory Committee, implementing youth risk behavior surveys, tackling behavioral and mental health issues facing our students.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: You remember all the work on the vaping public health crisis?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We thought that was challenging.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Then along came COVID.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: You immediately went from being my colleague to being my partner.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: You jumped in with contact tracing and offered your staff to assist from day one.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: metric meetings, reopening plans to testing, we quickly became attached to the hip.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Your leadership, your support, your counsel on tough positions will never be forgotten.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Most of all, the numerous early morning meetings and late night phone calls where often I just needed a friend to vent to and you were always there and my partner became my friend.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I can't thank you enough.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: When I was wavering, you always reeled me in and you stuck with the science and the data and the facts.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So in closing now, I just wanna mention something that sticks out in my mind still.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: On one of many ridiculously early Saturday morning calls regarding testing results, I remember calling you while I was still in my pajamas, looking at the results coming in.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: You picked up the phone and said,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Let me call you back in two minutes.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I'm just checking out at the grocery store.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I remember thinking, wow, she is amazing.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And you are.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Enjoy your retirement.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: You'll be great in this.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Congratulations.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: personally because you were so gracious taking care of our little girl when she had to have a body cast in a wheelchair for two months and you and your staff with her open wounds and everything else, you just made us feel confident handing her over to you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And we know that you make every family feel that way.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And that has been really special.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So thank you so much.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I felt really, I took that to heart and I have to share with you guys, you know, and I sometimes overshare, I guess,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: whatever, but I was a neglected child.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I was awarded the state and I know what it means to be a neglected child.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I have not neglected the children of this school district.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I have worked really hard for the children in this community and especially the marginalized children in this community having been a marginalized child.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I will continue to do that whether I'm on the school committee or not, I can promise you all that I will do that because that's just my nature.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I am so fortunate to live here.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I have raised my children here.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I've been here 24 years.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: From a behavioral health perspective, we've been working on trauma-informed schools.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Stacey Shulman and several members of the community have been regularly attending these nine meetings over the course of the past 10 months.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And one of the recommendations that the subcommittee had was having annual training on mental health needs slash issues that

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Stacey can be more specific about, but regular two-hour training around suicide prevention, among other things.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And then the special education portion of it, we've been working on building friendships and community for students with and without disabilities and a disability awareness curriculum.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So regarding the building friendships and community,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We've looked at a number of options and we are talking about expanding a high school program and the staff there are looking at how to work with the middle school to extend the program, which is currently a reverse inclusion model where general education students are going into

[Melanie McLaughlin]: for example, access classrooms, but having that as part of a class, as a curriculum, as opposed to every now and then occasion.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And then a disability awareness curriculum.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So they're piloting a disability awareness curriculum with Susanna Campbell, and we're hoping to expand that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: recommendations at this point and as I said we have one more meeting for the year.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So is there a reconciliation process?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So is there a process at which point we see what there actually was an IDEA funding and what there actually was in Circuit Breaker and sort of how that was applied and what the reconciliation of those numbers are?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Yeah, I think a reconciliation process would be great to be able to understand where that money actually goes.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And then I'm assuming one-to-one aids for individuals with IEPs are under the paraprofessional allocation for special education.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Is that right?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Okay, and, you know, our concern is obviously that we're not taking when you're saying building based professionals that, you know, I know that historically what's been happening and I don't know if it's because of the allocation of substitutes or the difficulty in getting

[Melanie McLaughlin]: substitutes that, you know, at least anecdotally, we're hearing that paraprofessionals are being used for substitute positions within the schools, and then, you know, being taken out of specialized programming, which obviously is problematic.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so I wanna, two questions about that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Bowen.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you for that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I know you know that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Right.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: potentially over a two mile radius, or at least at a two mile radius.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And if you think about even the cusp of the two mile radius, which would be, say, for example, students in the, you know, McGlynn vicinity, McGlynn Middle School vicinity, walking to the high school or to have it because they couldn't afford or having to choose to, you know, pay $30 a month for the reduced pass that could very much impact their families.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I think it's just,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: an ethics value it's a statement it's a it's a our budget does reflect what our values are and I think I have been stunned that that has been the case in the history even sitting in school committee on the other side of the podium that that students were having to pay.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: to transport themselves to school and especially having been a student myself who would not have been able to do that and so then you think about what the absentee rates are what the hunger rates are what you know just so many there's so many impacts so to that motion I would you know I would prefer that it's the MBTA passes but I would defer to the finance committee to do it to provide us a

[Melanie McLaughlin]: You were talking about transportation and I'm sorry, but I quoted what you were saying.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Yeah.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I thought that's what you meant, and I wanted some clarification because I'm imagining, for example, vocational students transporting to their site, CCSR volunteers, sort of all of those things.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So it would be interesting to know what the programmatic opportunities are as we're considering this cost analysis for these different options.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And then I know that it's not just Eastern bus that we have is our transportation vendors.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We have multiple transportation vendors and there's been multiple issues across the transportation vendors.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We've personally been experiencing some issues with transportation vendors and I know that it's difficult to maintain or retain staff.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: especially under the current circumstances.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But I'm wondering about a centralized opportunity or almost like a C-click fix, you know, sort of, or option or, you know, complaint line or something where we can collect data on what is actually happening in the community for our transportation, because we are paying a lot of money to our vendors, and I feel like there's no accountability to the vendors.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: There's no sort of consistency around what the vendors are providing, and even in some of the contracts I've seen

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Letters come home to parents saying that if you miss the bus in the morning, you're not going to get picked up in the afternoon, which is a complete violation, right?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: You can't do that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But this is for special education transportation, for example.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But that was a letter that we specifically saw.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So this is what I'm saying.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: There has to be some consistency around the contracts, around the budgets, but also around the sort of complaint process.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Because if

[Melanie McLaughlin]: one administrator's hearing complaints on one section of it and another's hearing another, like who's centralizing these complaints for us to understand as a school committee what the bids are on these vendors and whether they're reasonable.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And just if I may, Mayor, to be clear, the Director of Pupil Services has always been incredibly responsive, but I have also always been a squeaky wheel.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I think about the folks who aren't and how they're being responded to and how they're able to sort of demonstrate that the transportation is working.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I think it's around data collection, frankly.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: and children coming to school late and sort of what that looks like.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But again, looking at our vendors I think is important.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And then lastly, I just wanted to again also laud the superintendent's direction towards more professional development and targeted professional development, both around implicit bias and social emotional learning.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I have heard from staff and community members two points on the professional development that I wanted to sort of raise.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And one is that

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Some of the specialized staff I think is not necessarily feeling as though that there is targeted professional development for, you know, very specific licensing or needs and so I wanted to sort of present that and then also

[Melanie McLaughlin]: you know just concern about ensuring paraprofessional participation and professional development and or that is that is related to paraprofessional and certainly it sounds like the social emotional learning piece will be part of that but I want to ensure that and I know in the past I think that they a lot of times the paraprofessionals have gone where the teachers go.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: they're they're partner teachers, which I understand, you know the reasoning around that, too.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But I think it would be also nice just to be able to let people have some flexibility and choice for the professional development.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So those are not things that I expect any answer to tonight, but I just sort of wanted to bring that up so that you guys are aware.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you all for the presentation.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It's nice to see some clear commitment to diversity and equity across departments.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I can see that there's some cohesiveness around that and, and I want to say that I appreciate that consideration because it's, it's critical and something that our district

[Melanie McLaughlin]: really needs and I think needs to work on.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I wanted to mention the Yale program mentioned and thank Mr. Teixeira.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I think that you've been doing an exceptional job, frankly, and I look to you for a lot of role modeling and leadership.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I think the adaptive literacy program is a really important one and one that I'd like to have

[Melanie McLaughlin]: folks think about sort of in a bigger perspective.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I think we often just tend to put ourselves in these silos and these buckets around, you know, this is this department and that's that department and that's that department.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I remember two years ago going in and sitting with Mr. Tisher and being able to look at some of his material and what that actually looked like and what that meant.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And, you know, universal design for learning is something that goes across every single one of our departments.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so when we're talking about adaptive literacy, you know, and we're thinking about all of the discussions we're having around dyslexia and

[Melanie McLaughlin]: You know, it's important to look at well what is the EL department doing around adaptive literacy, how are they actually collecting data around that, how could this apply somewhere else and and what is being done and I just, I just sort of wanted to put that out there because I think that people often.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: just put themselves in silos and aren't looking at each other necessarily as models.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I think we should.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And especially also around cultural competency.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I really appreciated Mr. Teixeira's request for professional development and cultural competency.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And frankly, I think that's something that we could use across the district.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I know that it's a lot to think about for every department, but I do think it's something that we need pretty much in every department.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Technology, I wanted to ask Ms.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Layden, I know Mr. Murphy mentioned briefly the assistive technology and adaptive technology is sort of, you mentioned microphones and what have you, but I would like to hear a little bit more about that, especially this year with having gone remote, with all of the access that students needed to have, with our population who is

[Melanie McLaughlin]: you know, who does have learning differences and others are English learners are, you know, just folks who struggle with technology in general.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Not that English learners do, I don't mean to imply that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I'm just saying generally that, you know, families, parents that were struggling with technology, like what is being offered to the community around assistive technology and adaptive technology to obviously to students that require that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And additionally, training and development around what this looks like for families trying to figure out, you know, this whole world.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And again, we may or may not be remote in some capacities moving forward, but has there been any sort of

[Melanie McLaughlin]: group development around these things.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you, and just to clarify, I'm not looking for a whole lesson on what technology was purchased for students and accessibility.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It's more sort of just the bigger picture looking at how these things are being presented.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I think it's actually been a blessing in a lot of ways.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We had a lot of students who did need iPads and I think can benefit from that obviously, but I would like to hear Ms.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Bowen just a little bit about how big picture, not micro, just macro sort of you're looking at this, please.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Yeah, thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I just, for example, I just, I guess I wanted to share with, you know, folks in our instance, you know, we have, Grace has a reading disability.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so she has access to Bookshare, right?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And a lot of people, frankly, in the community and in the district don't know what Bookshare is.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And anyone with a reading disability qualifies for Bookshare.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: You can have access to a library with thousands of electronic books.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: for free once you have a diagnosis of a reading disability.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I think that that's something that's just sort of a general understanding that people across the district should know.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I think that unfortunately what happens, it certainly did in our case, is we have to bring that nugget of information that we've learned from parents or from a Federation for Children with Special Needs group or something else to the district in our IEP to sort of share that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I want to make sure that these things are more universal.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And

[Melanie McLaughlin]: know experience across the board for folks and and and I guess I don't necessarily think there's an answer to that tonight I guess I'm just trying to put that out there for everybody that we're thinking about what this looks like from all perspectives and that's part of what I'm seeing tonight and it's refreshing because

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Frankly, I hadn't seen that a lot before.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so I would ask people to continue on that path and to continue thinking about how do each of these departments apply to these marginalized populations.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And same with the math programs.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I appreciated David saying that

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Mr. Murphy saying that it's a multi-tiered summer program and you know I think that that's great it's a multi-tiered summer program and that it's going to be accessible for all students and I think we have to think about what those supports look like obviously and I'm sure as the experts you guys are thinking about that but I just have to put that out to the community as well that you know every student should have access to all of these programs and

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I'm sure that, you know, with our, with our equity as being our driving force that they will and so the unified sports to I think, again, this is something that's been asked for for a while, Malden does a really good job with their challenger team and.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Medford hasn't done this.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And frankly, we have the Special Olympics hosted at Hormel, but it's hosted by Malden, which is ironic.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so it's good to see that this year.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I would really, again, and I'm gonna circle it up with the family engagement position.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I think that having the family engagement position person would have you looking at these things across departments in a macro way about how are you actually involving, especially the marginalized communities that aren't coming to the table is what we really need to

[Melanie McLaughlin]: To be thinking of and I guess Lastly, I want to put out there and I know tomorrow we have a meeting that will discuss some of this but I guess you know all of this comes down to money right we all know that all of these things that are our wants and our different needs in this.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I just want to mention that in the programmatic piece, the language-based definition of the program, the Medford Special Education Programs, in the language-based, it's mentioned that there's grade-level access for the students.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Language-based program uses grade-level content for ELA reading, math, social studies, and science, so on.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I just wanted to clarify,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: the access program says that they use Massachusetts curriculum frameworks.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: The good of the order is a category under Robert's Rules of Orders that we had voted in earlier in the year, essentially at our first meeting of the month.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I think on occasion, it's been dropped, but moving forward, I would ask that it is included on the first meeting of the month.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And generally, it is to check in with the school committee as a group, as a whole, to check in on the good of the order.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Essentially, how are things going?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Are things going well?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Are there things that folks feel we need work on?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: you know, are the meeting scheduling's going fine?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Like, it's an opportunity for the committee to offer up anything they have, both positive or, you know, things that need to be worked on.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So that's the good of the order.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I think these are, you know, both through the chair, my colleagues I think these are both things that have been talked about, certainly, you know, individually or amongst less than a quorum with folks over time so I think these are both items that need to be addressed.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I wanted to ask, so I know that you talked a little bit about the equity in ELA and some of those variants about inclusion and other materials, and I don't know if this is a topic for the subcommittee or whether it should be a report or what have you, but I'm curious about

[Melanie McLaughlin]: An update on a disability curriculum and an update on the anti-racism curriculum, both of which have been discussions for this year.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I don't know if that's going to be happening later in the year or if that's been a topic.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: English learners.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And when we were in school, you know, in elementary school, we were unaware of that until about third grade.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so, you know, I want to make sure that there are supplements for special education and EL and that families and teachers are aware that there are supplements.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: The class offices represent all students, but I think it would be nice to see a mix too.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So yes, so that's my point member or so.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: You know, when we talk about subgroups and, you know, the classism,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: and ableism, frankly, that exists in our culture and in our community.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I think that that's really important.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I know for me, even last year, going to the

[Melanie McLaughlin]: To the curriculum night, there were a number of experiences I had where there were comparisons made at curriculum night to standard classes and students versus honor and AP students.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: They were talking about sort of, well, our standards class sort of

[Melanie McLaughlin]: doesn't, you know, may not listen or may have behavior or whatever, just sort of, and it was really right in the presentations.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I thought that was really interesting.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so I appreciate you naming that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And just backing it up a little bit.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So they had another group, whether it was their own, you know, school committee themselves.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I forget what they called it.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And he was an excellent school committee representative and we enjoyed him and listening to him and his perspective.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And he was also on the superintendent hiring committee.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I think that when students realize how valuable their voice is and when they realize that their voice is heard and does have a lot of social capital, then they really start to, I think,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: come to the table right and rise to the occasion and your voice is so critical, it's the most critical voice in my opinion.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And when you guys really, you know, can articulate that and express that then I think that's, that's really the key and figuring out how to do that right.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: working around, if you will, the legislature, right?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Because this is the law, we have to follow the law, but what other options do we have, right?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So if we have a representative, you guys meet with your schools, you come back with a statement from this organization to us, any of those things that you can think about as workarounds.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And we're all, I'm sure, happy to talk to you about

[Melanie McLaughlin]: any of these things.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so to the superintendent's point as well, superintendent respectfully, I love the idea of liaison to the students.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: The only thing about that is I think all seven members, maybe six members would be clamoring to be the liaison to the students because we all very much care.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: about of course about your opinion and your perspective.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I think that there could be a way that you know maybe we think about liaisons per class or liaisons per school or sort of anything like that so that every member can be included and have a voice a conversation with the student but also you should know many of us have office hours

[Melanie McLaughlin]: that are open, obviously, but also will meet for coffee anytime with any constituent yourselves included, because you are constituents.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Even for those who are not voting age yet, but I think you know you guys are either 18 or coming up on 18 right.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Yeah, so there you go, you're constituents.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And the other, anybody else are pre-constituents.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So we work for you, right?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We're elected, we work for you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And remembering that is super important.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I want your voice to be heard.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And there's a lot of ways to, I don't wanna say skin a cat, cause I don't like that image, but I guess that's sort of what I'm talking about.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: There's a lot of ways to get things done.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Yeah, thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Yeah, also it was something that was noticed in chambers because I'm assuming at some point will we be back in chambers and this was something that I had mentioned last year to.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: the tech people is that it would be nice for the student to have a microphone.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So that would be something else that I would add.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Instead of having to saddle up to one of the members and squish over and speak through their microphone and feel awkward about everything, they should have their own microphone.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I like the idea of the,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: of the advisory and sort of going back to your constituents, which are your students, your cohort and the other grades.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Our subgroups and how are you, you know, are you, you know, either through the CCSR, are you part of the Common Ground Program?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And then I don't know if it's the law or not, but I was actually wondering this myself, Member Ruseau, about the voting order, because I, as the Secretary, I'm always like, as you can see, the past couple of times I stumble until I write it down in my Excel spreadsheet and do my tally and all that stuff.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Is there anything that says it has to be alphabetical?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Because, you know, I'm smack in the middle, which is convenient, frankly.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I don't mind being in the middle.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And why should people always be put in that position?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Yeah, I was just gonna say, would it be too much to ask that we think about a schedule just right now that we can I would like to see, you know, since Colin and David and you sort of, you know, came up with this idea in this process, it would be nice for them to be able to have

[Melanie McLaughlin]: participate in this process before graduating.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So in some context, so could we give ourselves a deadline of say, you know, beginning May that were and last meeting in April or whatever, that we have this recommendation to come before the school committee as a whole to vote.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And then, you know, there will be still some opportunity for Colin and David to participate in the process.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I didn't realize that this was from MASC, but I think it's interesting that there's nothing in here about IEPs or IERs, the individual emergency response or individual education plan.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I would obviously assume if it's on a student IEP that they are not wearing a mask or that they are working on wearing a mask, because some students have mask wearing as part of their,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: individualized education process and some students, you know, are not there yet.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I understand it says has trouble breathing, is unconscious, is incapacitated, cannot remove the mask or face covering without assistance.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So that says nothing about, you know, has a disability or has an IEP that sort of suggests that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I'm wondering why that might be.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Did you have, yeah.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Okay, so it is the state mandate for a student with a disability on an IEP who's not able to wear a mask has a doctor's note that they cannot wear a mask.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Is that right?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: That's interesting because I would imagine that

[Melanie McLaughlin]: you know, um, therapists or others, but I guess if they're an MD, they can get it from their, um, From their medical doctor.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So that's important, but I know that they say challenge.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I just, I'm just in, so this language is from who this is from Desi.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Mass association of school committee.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Okay.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So we can let mass association of school committees.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Now, if we have any issue or concern with the language, is that what I'm hearing?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I guess I would like to make a motion that we include a sentence that says something to the effect of, you know, is a student with a disability, you know, where an IEP indicates is unable to wear a mask, and if we want to put in parathetical notation, doctor's note required or something, that's fine, but I think it's an important

[Melanie McLaughlin]: point both for families of students with disabilities and for self advocates and others to understand that category so a student with a disability may look at this and say, you know, especially someone who takes things quite literally might look at this and say I don't have a problem breathing I'm not unconscious.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I'm not incapacitated, I can take the mask on or off, but I can't because I feel like whatever, I have a stimulus, I have a sensory thing, I can't, whatever, any number of things that happen for individuals with disabilities.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So not being classified in that, I think is important.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I would respectfully request that we include the individual as a student with a disability who has a doctor's note or IEP notation

[Melanie McLaughlin]: that, you know, precludes them from being able to wear a mask, right?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So we want to remember about that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Sure, I would be happy to do that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I would be happy to consult with the Director of Pupil Services regarding that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I fully understand that people with disabilities aren't on IEPs necessarily, but IEPs can also drive training around wearing masks.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so that's sort of part of the issue that I'm discussing right now.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so that's the nuance around some of this.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So, but I'm sure the Director of Pupil Services and I can come up with something that will feel appropriate.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So sure, I'm happy to do that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: to help students in those environments.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: They ended up having to go with like an administrative room that they created as sort of a cool down room for the kids because they were just getting super overheated.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: My daughter has Down syndrome and gets overheated more quickly than neurotypical children, but still, and I would go into the building to pick her up or drop her off.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And the, I don't know what it is along the building, along the community school sort of aisle, but I did bring it to

[Melanie McLaughlin]: the assistant superintendent's attention at the time, there were these look like radiators.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I don't know if that's what they are, but they were just like blowing heat.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: know in 90 100 degree weather and hot air was just coming out of them as well um but the administrative offices obviously were all air conditioned so the kids were just in this state of like real it was a couple of summers ago when we had that really bad heat wave so to remember russo's point i guess you know especially when we're you know having

[Melanie McLaughlin]: know, younger vulnerable kids or any kids really sort of in that setting, especially when it's so hot.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I know that I've spoken with teachers in the past who have said that they can barely teach with the heat in their room and trying to figure out fans and what have you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I guess, again, to remember Rousseau's point, sort of

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Is this on the radar?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And if so, how?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I know that, again, the HVAC stuff was primarily to assist with airflow for COVID, but this other issue has been a longstanding issue.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: it was just unbearable in the past.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Member Ruseau.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Excuse me, Member Graham?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Member McLaughlin, yes.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Member Mustone?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Yes.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Member Ruseau?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Yes.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Member Van der Kloot?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Mayor Long-Klein?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Yes.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you, Mayor.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We met on March 18th.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: As people may know, we divide the meetings 45 minutes each.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: One topic is behavioral health and specifically trauma-informed schools.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And then the latter half of the meeting is special education specifically.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: building friendships in school and community among individuals with and without disabilities.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And then we swap the order each month.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So this month behavioral health was first.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And the question that we really were asking our director of guidance Stacey Shulman in this meeting was, how are we addressing the social emotional needs of our students and families as we are having a return to school to full, you know, full

[Melanie McLaughlin]: in-person school and remote for those who choose to have remote.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so Stacey shared with us that there's increased group counseling, there's pushing counseling in some classes, supportive groups in middle school, more individual in sixth grade.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We did talk with some parents that were in the meeting that were really concerned about the social emotional needs of our children, especially as compared to academic recruitment.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And people are feeling like,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: social emotional needs to be addressed in order for academic recruitment to even begin to happen.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so Ms.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Schulman shared that the Sandy Hook Promise campaign is starting up again and Medford has signed on to that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And that's a program that we've had in the past and their slogan is start with hello.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It begins in the first week of April, I believe in the middle schools.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We asked that families or school committee members be invited to see what that actually looks like, the Sandy Hook Promise Campaign.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And there were some more comments about like just what is it gonna look like for our kids being overwhelmed?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: What about kids who have anxiety in the six feet to three feet?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: How are we addressing this?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Stacey talked about group for anxiety.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: There were families, specifically a parent who is a licensed social worker as well.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: has been really committed to these meetings and she was just really sharing as the parent of two students currently in the Medford public schools and you know sort of as a message that she's been hearing from a lot of students and families is the real need for for our children to have some social interaction, our students have some social interaction with each other.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And how can we do that?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Like, you know, what are the opportunities, whether it's, you know, being able to go for a hike in the fells as a group or, you know, teaching on the field or, you know, and we had one day, I guess, last week of not having homework and, you know, just sort of thinking about what their social and emotional needs are.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And next month we will be doing, we'll be reviewing what policy recommendations the subcommittee wants to make for our May presentation.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So there was also, you know, rethinking homework was another question around sort of, again, this these these academic requirements when people are still trying to catch up to the social emotional so that was the crux of the behavioral health and then building friendships and community in schools.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We talked with Susanna Campbell, who is the Director of Speech and Language and who has built a really great reserve with our colleagues of resources on Google Doc around social stories for families and teachers and others to use in returning to school, social stories for a number of different situations and books and what have you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So anyone interested in the link to that Google Doc can reach out to

[Melanie McLaughlin]: That Google folder I'm sure can reach out to Susanna Campbell and she's also partnering at our request or collaborating, I should say, with Paul Teixeira from our Director of English Language to work on identifying social stories that can be translated into other languages for students that

[Melanie McLaughlin]: need those.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So that was really exciting.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I was happy about that opportunity.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We talked about the Universal Safety Committee website.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: This is the website we're talking about on the social stories.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Update on Common Ground.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We're hoping to expand the Common Ground program that's at the high school to build friendships.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Among students with and without disabilities.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It's a proven program that's existed at the high school would like to see it expand or they would like you know the committee wants is interested in seeing expand to an elective, and we're exploring options on what that might look like.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: CCSR is having a disability awareness focus on the 27th, April 27th.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Historically, the diversity week for Medford public schools has not included disability, interestingly.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So this is the first year that disability will be included

[Melanie McLaughlin]: in diversity week and we think that that's a really important note not to point out what hasn't been done but to remind people that disability is diversity and that obviously they should be included in any conversation around diversity.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And then an update on Medford Recreation, there was conversation around adaptive versus inclusive programming and right now we're really happy that we're starting to see some adaptive programming at the recreation level

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And again, there was discussion about what peer-to-peer relationships look like and that they're horizontal, not vertical.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And adaptive programs, it's often the individual with disability being served by the peer as opposed to having a unique and authentic relationship with them.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So we're eager and looking forward to helping Medford Recreation with the support of community members and stakeholders that attend these meetings and others to move into adaptive and inclusive programming.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And then we did an update on the inclusive playground.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So for folks who are not aware, there's a playground restructure that will be happening at the McGlynn Elementary School Playground, which is a central location in the city and accessible to many members of our community outside of just our school community at the McGlynn.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So that playground is being restructured with a real eye towards inclusive

[Melanie McLaughlin]: play space and expertise in that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so we're lucky we have some community members that offer unique expertise in that area, and we're excited to move that project forward.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So our next meeting is Thursday, April 15th, where we'll be talking about policy recommendations, and the following meeting is May 20th.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So April 15th, we hope you'll join us, 5 to 6.30, and obviously these will be posted online.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Second.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Member Graham.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: If you have not submitted a request for public participation, you can speak on any topic for up to three minutes one time, just for clarification, because I don't want people to think that if you didn't submit a request for public participation the Wednesday before the meeting that you cannot participate.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It's just if you want more minutes to speak about something in particular, you would submit that the Wednesday before.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: whether there's going to be what the homework situation is going to be with more kids going into school so for the remote learners a lot of stuff has been able to be done during the day in the classroom and you know if they're getting more computer time at night it can be really problematic so wondering about that consistency as well, thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And then I also just wanted to add for the emergency preparedness event that is Wednesday at six o'clock that is being hosted by the Universal Safety Committee

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Although it is being presented by the Mass Office on Disability, to be clear, it is open and available for everyone.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It's emergency preparedness in all situations for anyone, for example, with young children, elderly parents or grandparents, individuals with disabilities, any of those needs.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We found it exceptional in the past, and everyone that has gone to it has been really impressed and moved by it in terms of their own preparation in terms of emergencies.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And if the pandemic has taught us anything,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: the importance of being prepared.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So thank you for sharing that information.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And students produced that show, I executive produced it, but I walked away from that show feeling really concerned and upset and really actually also moved that our students were willing to be so forthcoming and sharing their feelings with us, right?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And what they've been going through.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And this senior class is unique from any other senior class.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: The previous senior class had, not that we're diminishing what was taken from them, of course, but they had from,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: you know, September through March.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: This class didn't have their junior prom and did not have this year at all.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: They've been extremely isolated as I know that you all know, and really feeling forgotten as they shared in their conversation in the ed talk and lonely and a number of other things.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I think we're all to some degree feeling that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: adults yet, right?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: They're still children and they're still developmentally, you know, figuring things out.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And it's been a really, really tough year for them.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I want to know how we're addressing the social emotional needs of our kids, of our seniors specifically.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We have nine weeks left with these kids until they're gone for good from our district.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And, you know, we, many of them have been here since, you know, preschool or kindergarten.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It's been

[Melanie McLaughlin]: You know 12 years that we've you know that you've taken care of them nurture them brought them this far and then we were all gobsmacked by this pandemic right but we literally have nine weeks left and.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I think it's great.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I mean, it's so important that they have a prom and that we have a date for graduation and we can get excited about that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: signage congratulating our class of 2021 and those sorts of things.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I know my son does.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Present.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Three present, zero absent.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you for being here, Member Van der Kloot.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I'm Melanie McLaughlin, for folks who don't know me.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And this is the Behavioral Health Special Education Subcommittee meeting.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: The co-chairs for this meeting, I mean,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Yeah, other members that are part of the subcommittee are Member Paul Rousseau and Member Miama Stone.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Tonight, we're having Member Van der Kloot stand in for Mia.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So thank you, Member Van der Kloot.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I am just going to read from our agenda with our introduction.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So please be advised that on Thursday, March 18, 2021, from 5 to 6.30, there is a behavioral health and special education subcommittee meeting held through remote participation via Zoom.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: The purpose of the Thursday, March 18, 2021 Behavioral Health and Special Ed Subcommittee is to address best practices and policies for creating trauma-informed schools under the behavioral health category and building community and school-based friendships for students with disabilities under the special education category.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12, 2020 order suspending certain provisions of the Open Meeting Law,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: and the governor's March 15th, 2020 order imposing strict limitations on the number of people that may gather in one place.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: This meeting of the Medford School Subcommittee will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Specific information in the general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and or parties with a right and or requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the city of Medford website at medfordma.org.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: For this meeting, members of the public who wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein, accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: No in-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings in real time via technological means.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: In the event that we are unable to do so, despite best efforts, we will post on the City of Medford or Medford Community Media websites an audio or video recording transcript

[Melanie McLaughlin]: or other comprehensive record of proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: The meeting can be viewed through Medford Community Media on Comcast channel 22 and Verizon channel 43 at 5 p.m.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So a map of our agenda today, you can expect from roughly 5 to 5.45, we'll be focusing on behavioral health and trauma-informed schools.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Director of Guidance, Stacey Shulman,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We'll talk with us regarding mental health and behavioral health and returning students to school, including immediate need for trauma-informed care, social-emotional health in comparison to academic recoupment, school counseling and mental health considerations for revamping the system.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And then 545 to 630, we will discuss

[Melanie McLaughlin]: with the Director of Speech and Language, Susanna Campbell.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: She had shared some, or we had shared some online resources for use by general education, special education, English learners, and families that we'll share a little bit on.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We'll have an update on the Common Ground program that we've been talking about in previous meetings, an update on Medford Recreation and some conversations we've been having around building friendships and inclusive recreation.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: and an update on the inclusive playground that's in the process.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So that's our agenda, and we'll finish at 6.30.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I'd like to start, if I could, let me just see for a second.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Sorry, I have to go between screens.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: How many folks we have on?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I think everyone here recognizes and knows each other, so we're not gonna do,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: introductions again if that's okay with everybody.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Is that okay?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thumbs up?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Yeah?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Okay, great.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I'd like to have Stacey Shulman maybe start the conversation, if you would, Stacey, on what is happening for being trauma-informed as we're returning students to school, please.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you, Stacey.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I guess I wanted to ask, I did have the opportunity to speak with a parent today who is interested in being engaged on the matter of sort of mental health and behavioral health and was asking just sort of about some of the

[Melanie McLaughlin]: social, emotional needs of our students right now and how, you know, how they might be addressed, not just through school adjustment Councilors necessarily, or even guidance, but even more so sort of just collectively in the school setting around social engagement and being able to sort of interact with each other in some ways.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I know, I don't know if any of you had the opportunity to see the ed talk recently with the seniors, some of the seniors sharing their experience.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: and feelings of isolation.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I mean, it was a really poignant, I thought, presentation by the students.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I think that they, you know, being the age they are and the grade they are, they're able to articulate a lot better than maybe younger kids would be.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so certainly from families, we're hearing a lot of this isolation and loneliness and sort of need for community and engagement.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: as a group, not just Stacey, obviously, because Stacey, I know it's not just your job, but as a group, how are we thinking about the social and emotional needs of our students and being able to sort of address that for them?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So for example, somebody was saying, like, can we not do like a barbecue in the, you know, in the parking lot or just anything to sort of have them get to be able to have some social engagement with each other?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I thought, you know, obviously it's an interesting idea.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I know everybody's super swamped right now with the return to school.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But I think the family engagement piece is a really important piece of it, because I think that there's a lot of community members that have some great ideas and probably would be also willing to volunteer in those projects.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I guess I just want to put that out there for folks and see what the response is on that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: That's really good to hear.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And will that be offered or will the families or school committee members or others be invited to be part of that or?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Yeah, I think that would be great.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I should also say that I think probably a lot of you know if you're in the school committee meeting, you know that Medford is one of four districts that is partnering with the Department of Elementary and Secondary Education on a family and community engagement project.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So we put an application in for that, and we were one of the four districts across the state chosen.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So that's really exciting.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And we're working with a group called School in Maine.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: think school and main streets and the convergence of community and school, that's sort of how they're named, school in Maine, and that's why they're named that way.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And as consultants for really helping us build our family and community engagement and outreach.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And one of the things that I certainly want to continue to be putting on the table as part of the planning is the mental health component and the social emotional health component on that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So we'll definitely be able to

[Melanie McLaughlin]: include that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And that's why I'm looking for sort of some recommendations or some discussion around this here.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: If other folks want to chime in, you can unmute yourself if you like.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Yes, Paulette, member of NDQ.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Heather, thank you for that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I also think that like, as we're thinking about, you know, again, you know, looking out for these signs of social anxiety and loneliness among our students, you know, there's also, there are also our students who can't communicate with words and communicate with behavior.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so really being able to train staff to understand that, you know, behavior is a form of communication as well.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And, you know, I know for us this morning, just getting ready this morning, getting, helping our daughter, our 13 year old daughter, Gracie, get ready this morning.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And she burst into tears quite unexpectedly.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I was like, you know, what's going on?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And, you know, trying to start talking with her about it.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And then she said, you know, she was able to articulate and it was so moving, she said,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: know, I want COVID to go away.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: You know, and it was so sad, because it was like, oh, you know, yeah, of course you do, like we all do.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And, you know, it's getting better or whatever else.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But I think that the community as a whole, especially maybe with the one year mark, you know, the anniversary, I think a lot of people, I mean, everyone I'm talking to right now is feeling overwhelmed.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And, you know, just out of sorts.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so I think especially as we're thinking about bringing our

[Melanie McLaughlin]: are kids who are our most vulnerable population, whether they have, you know, a disability or don't, I mean, children are our most vulnerable population community.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so thinking about that, in a broader context, I think is so important.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I, I guess, having listened to one of our community members yesterday, too, and I hear that, you know, the social anxiety and the isolation and also sort of maybe introducing it in in

[Melanie McLaughlin]: scaffolding right like if you think about special education, you can sort of scaffold steps to before you get to the step that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: You know you're hoping to achieve, but even scaffolding some of the the social and emotional around the relationships like somebody was you know, suggesting.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Like why not offer hikes right instead of like even like, and this is to the next subject in our agenda, I guess, transitioning to the next subject in our agenda, which is.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: social emotional health versus academic recruitment, right?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And sort of how those two are pulling at each other and what we're doing around that, right?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Because if we're, everybody's so hyper-focused on academic recruitment, and we're not really looking at the social emotional and mental health, like our kids can't show up to learn if they don't have the first, you know, Maslow hierarchy of needs, right?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: If we don't have our basic needs taken care of, we're not gonna be able to show up for higher learning.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I think that that's a really important piece.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I know there was a community member who said like, why not like have a class or, you know, instead of having the class remote, which is, you know, the kids are so tired of anyway in school, um, reverse remote, like why not have an opportunity to, I don't know, make a hike in the fells or what have you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I know that's thinking outside of the conventional box of education, but I think that these are extraordinary times.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I'm wondering sort of what people think of that idea.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you, Heather.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I think that's really

[Melanie McLaughlin]: important for us to be thinking about the social emotional and the kids are telling us that this is what they need.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I mean, it's not like it's just that the families that are saying this, but.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Sorry, you're muted.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Introduce yourself and sort of, you know, your role here, if you would.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you, Shanine.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so Mr. Skorka and Ms.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Andre were not able to join us today, but I wanted to share just a little bit of an update on some of the things that we have been discussing.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So for folks that may not have been in previous meetings, we have been talking about, you know, a program that could be created or exist in our school that is really being mindful in terms of fostering friendships

[Melanie McLaughlin]: between students with and without disabilities.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Because again, while they were talking earlier about play and the importance of having individualized or free play, it is also important to be able to have some guidance around building friendships for students, especially for whom that can be a little bit more difficult.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so I did send you all a copy of the toolkit that the Arc of Mass created.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It's a friendship.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: um, building toolkit that I really want to think about as a foundational sort of, um, document as we're thinking about what this looks like.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so we, we had a couple of parents, um, reach out to us from the autism support group, um, Heather and, um, Marissa, uh, a year or more ago, pre COVID anyway.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So another lifetime ago, actually, we, um, met with, um, best buddies.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And we had a conversation around what that could look like in schools.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And then, you know, COVID happened.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And then sons have been talking about programs that already exist in our schools and what those look like.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so Common Ground is a program at the high school that Ms.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Andre, who is a special education teacher, and Mr. Skorka, who is a general education teacher, have been working on together in a co-taught sort of way.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: where they do reverse inclusion, essentially, which is bringing students without disabilities into the classroom with students with disabilities and having them foster friendships among themselves and, you know, with the syllabus and, I mean, with a goal and a sort of more coordinated effort.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And Mr. Skorka and Ms.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Andre and others have been talking about really incorporating this as not just

[Melanie McLaughlin]: HAB-Charlotte Pittsburgh.:

[Melanie McLaughlin]: : An option, you know, something fun or interesting for kids to do, but actually HAB-Charlotte Pittsburgh.:

[Melanie McLaughlin]: : As a course and looking at, you know, potential syllabus.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So, Joan, I know that you are from our last meeting notes.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I know you said you were going to HAB-Charlotte Pittsburgh.:

[Melanie McLaughlin]: : Speak with Mr. delay.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But if you want to talk about that in a moment.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I can also share when you're done Joan HAB-Charlotte Pittsburgh.:

[Melanie McLaughlin]: : Conversations I've had at the middle school level because we were talking about we have this at the high school.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So maybe expanding it beyond, you know, just an optional sort of thing into a course option and then

[Melanie McLaughlin]: piloting a similar idea slash program at the middle school, a common ground.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: That's really exciting.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you, guys.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I'm really, isn't it, Tonya?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you, Tonya.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And the thing about it is that, you know, first I just sort of want to add that

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Obviously, disability is diversity, right?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And these are all equity issues.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so thinking about, you know, building friendships.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And one of the things that I feel like the pandemic has really given us, if you will, is the understanding of loneliness, right?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so really, you know, for neurotypical people to really understand the loneliness too of kids with disabilities who don't have friends.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: and making sure that we bridge that gap for them because it's our responsibility and it's the right thing to do.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: That is really lovely, Charlotte.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you for sharing that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I think the natural course of the friendship is really sort of thinking about what it looks like.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It's not a client-based model where the students with disabilities are clients and the students without disabilities are giving a service.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It's authentic friendships and really fostering those, which is the goal here.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I appreciate.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: you sharing those stories.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: The next item on our agenda is to talk about an update on Medford Recreation.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I'll share that Gracie started going to the adaptive bowling on Wednesday nights through Medford Recreation, and she is having a lot of fun with that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Terry's been taking her, so I haven't had the benefit of actually seeing her yet.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: He's taken some pictures and shared some of the bowling with us and it's been really neat.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And it's a high school student that is her sort of partner in that experience.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And that is an adaptive program.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And one of the things that we really want to do, I see Kate Quinn from Medford Recreation is in the meeting as well.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: One of the things that we really wanna do is in addition to adaptive programming for recreation, we wanna ensure that there's inclusive programming for recreation.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: For those who might not know, the difference adaptive is sort of modifying the recreation aspect.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But again, it sort of might be more like a client based model where students are delivering a service and the kids with disabilities are receiving a service.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so inclusive recreation is sort of along the line.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Shanine was sort of helping me with this definition a little bit.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you, Shanine.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: is along the lines of the same thing that we're talking about in authentic friendships.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So that, you know, each partner in the relationship is gaining something from the other.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I really liked, I just wanted to share this quote, and then I'm gonna open it up to you guys to talk about Medford Recreation a little bit.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But I wanted to share this quote from the Arc of Masses book on friendship.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And, you know, I liked that they defined what friendship is.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: You know, despite its universal nature, friendship may mean different things to different people.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So it's important that we start with a common definition.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Friendship is a voluntary and reciprocal relationship in which two students exhibit mutual attachment to one another, frequent proximity and companionship, and evidence of enjoyment or affection.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I thought that was really important as we talk about, you know, a reciprocal relationship, especially in terms of recreation as well.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so I think we're well on our way with our adaptive programming.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I'm excited about that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I'm excited that our hearts are there.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So that's really exciting.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you, Shanine.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And you know, Shanine actually used to also work at EMARC, which is now Communitas, which is the North, our regions,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: um, that provide services to, um, children and, uh, individuals with disabilities.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And it was really interesting because I know that many of you know me and know that, um, I am and had been a really hardcore inclusionist.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Um, and I remember, um, way back when Gracie was a baby, um, she was, yeah, she was little, but not wanting her in.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: you know, adaptive swim programming, right?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Because I was like, no, she needs to go to full inclusion and that's, you know, her right and everything else.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And the reality was like Shanine shared with me and it was very important.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: She's like, you know, and with adaptive programming, we can get her to the point where she can get to full inclusion, right?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So it was like the scaffolding piece of it as well, really helpful.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so that was, you know, that was like an epiphany for me, Shanine, to understand like, oh, and you know, and I also was denying her the right

[Melanie McLaughlin]: to have friendships really with and without kids with disabilities.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So it doesn't mean just with kids without disabilities, they, you know, need friendships with kids with disabilities, right?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Like, and so thinking about that is really important too.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So thank you, Shanine.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I don't know.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I know that we do.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: was in a residential school and would come home for weekends and during school vacation weeks.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And mom would literally have nowhere to take her because there was no place that was accessible for her.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: There was no playground that she could go to.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: There was no place that she could take her.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And this beautiful little girl passed away actually when she was 15 years old and she was her mom's only daughter.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: her mom had dedicated really her life to taking care of her and advocating for her and remained an advocate in the disability community is quite a remarkable woman.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And, you know, I've thought a lot about this little girl over the years, and the fact that, you know, we didn't have a place for her to play.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: we can change that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I'm hearing often, you know, why aren't we having a community meeting on this?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I am asking

[Melanie McLaughlin]: because I'm confused here.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: What is this?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: This is a community meeting.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: People are saying we've been talking for over four hours and we have been talking for over four hours.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And we've also had previous meetings that were talking for over four hours about the same issue.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I don't understand when people are saying, why aren't we having a community meeting?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: That's exactly what this is tonight.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: When people are saying, slow it down, I also feel like we voted on this in June, 2020.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It's March 2021, a year almost has gone by.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I don't know how people don't think that that was a slowed down process, frankly, with everything that had been happening.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I think if people remember from back then, the question was, if not now, when?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And that was over a year ago.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And the other question is, if not us, who?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I think that that's a legitimate question.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Budget will be part of the advisory committee.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Having people participate in the name change, that's also part of the advisory committee, which is why we chose an advisory committee.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Again, the vote was already approved.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: When people keep talking about whether or not we should do this, I think that, again, we have to note this was already approved a year ago.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And then what was the other thing?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Oh, and again, the administration is working very hard and has been working very hard this past year to get our children back to school.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And they're continuing to do that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And we are involved in the process, but we are not the people who choose the process.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Again, our role as school committee members is to decide policy, to approve a budget, and to evaluate the superintendent.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It is not to do the daily work of getting our kids back into school, although I believe it is also very much a priority in our community and has been a focus.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And the administration has been working very hard on that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I hope that was an answer to some of the questions.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I think it's just really helpful for people to see that we value the work they've already put in and that we've heard them and we have really summary of that information.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So we haven't forgotten about that because I feel like if I was a constituent and I was being asked to come to this again, I'd be like,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: you know haven't we done this like a couple times already like we you know and and although this is different um and it's you know post a year's long pandemic um i want to see that we that that we we've been heard and that you know the constituents feel like they've been heard so i'm happy to reach out to jackie or the mayor for that um round table for the mayor's uh specific to education if you guys want so we could see those

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you, Mayor.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: a good number of parent participants and staff members participating.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We had some conversation about the EPIC Leaders Presentation with the Common Ground Program at the high school.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And the EPIC Leaders Program is about disability, civil rights, ableism, and person first language.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And we further discussed the Common Ground Program that currently exists at the high school.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: The Common Ground is currently a reverse inclusion program where general education, non-disabled students, for lack of a better word,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: join disabled students in their classroom, which fosters friendships and continued community relationships.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It's a program that has been very successful at the high school and we are having discussion about expanding this program to the middle school.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We have been engaging the middle school principals and other staff members at the middle school to find, to garner interest there.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It was suggested by the director of people's services and others that, and educators, teachers, both special education and general education, that we look at this as a potential elective course.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And we look at what a syllabus would look like.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And Susanna Campbell, who is the, I believe, Director of Speech and Language, has been presenting a disability awareness course and shared her syllabus with us to be thinking about what a syllabus might look like for a course like this.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We had several staff members that had been part of the disability awareness curriculum and raved about it and said how important they think this is at a middle school level.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So that was really good to hear.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And then from the behavioral health component, we had a parent who was a lot of parents who are very concerned, of course, about social, emotional needs of our children, particularly through the pandemic.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: and there was a parent who was asking specifically about art therapy for the district.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We shared that there was a music therapy grant that had existed at preschool that was driven by a parent and that we believe that that was not available currently, but asking about how we might pursue that and whether there was even also potentially community members that might be able to or interested in providing art or music therapy

[Melanie McLaughlin]: within our district and what that would look like.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Dr. Cushon talked about initial stages of planning some summer work and hoping to build more outside activities through nature.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Let's see, sorry.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We are going to do more research into the art therapy and social emotional piece, Stacey Shulman talked about Lesley University's art therapy program and how excellent they are.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We also had a parent who was very concerned about behavior supports for children in our schools and

[Melanie McLaughlin]: how that really alienates our children who are struggling with social emotional needs and exhibit that struggle through communicating by behavior.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We noted that there are four behavior specialists in the program in a district of 4,000 students, which was very concerning, understandably.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So we will be continuing this conversation and recommending policy by the year end.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Our next meeting is March 18th from 5 to 6.30.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: we will do behavioral health first, 5 to 545, and special ed will be 545 to 630.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.
