[Melanie McLaughlin]: Member Mustone?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: hear you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Yes, number McLaughlin present three present we have a quorum.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Again, welcome to the behavioral health special education.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I mean, special education behavioral health subcommittee.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It's 504pm.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Please be advised that on Thursday, February 11, from five to 630, there'll be a behavioral health and special ed subcommittee meeting held through remote participation via Zoom.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: The purpose of this meeting is to address best practices and policies for creating trauma-informed schools, behavioral health, and building community and school-based friendships for students with disabilities, special education.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12, 2020 order suspending certain provisions of the open meeting law,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: and Governor's March 15, 2020 order imposing strict limitations on the number of people that may gather in one place.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: This meeting of the Medford School Committee will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Specific information and the general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and our parties with the right and or requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the City of Medford website.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: at medfordma.org.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: For this meeting, members of the public who wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: No in-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings in real time via technological means.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: In the event that we are unable to do so, despite best efforts, we will post on the City of Medford or Medford Community Media website

[Melanie McLaughlin]: audio or video recording, transcript or other comprehensive recording of proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: The meeting can be viewed through Medford Community Media on Comcast channel 22 and Verizon channel 43 at 5 o'clock p.m.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So if additionally any questions or comments can be submitted during the

[Melanie McLaughlin]: meeting by emailing Melanie McLaughlin at medfordk12ma.ma.us.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Those submitting must include the following information, your first and last name, Medford Street address, and your question or comment.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Where our agenda is, we'll do a brief welcome and introduction to folks from roughly 5 to 545.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We'll discuss where we're at with our special education,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: process of informing friendships for students with disabilities in our community and schools with an eye towards likely an end of April, early May report out to the committee of the whole and roughly 545 to 630 for behavioral health trauma informed schools.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Our next meeting is Thursday, March 18th.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: One is Charlotte, maybe could you talk a little bit about the EPIC presentation that you had?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And maybe, do you want to share what ableism and person first language is just for folks who may not know?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Charlotte, would you mind?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Yeah, a lot of times that there was a big sort of person first movement for a while.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And then a lot of the folks in the autism community definitely said, you know, they preferred autistic.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So it's always good to obviously defer to the person with the disability.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: is the, Tom Hare taught me, is the idea that it is better to see than not see, hear than not hear, walk than roll.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: That's not his quote, it's one of his colleagues that sort of started the idea of ableism, or founded the word, but ableism is essentially believing that it is better to live without a disability than with a disability, so inheriting discrimination against individuals with disabilities.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I was at that presentation.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It was really nice to see.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And what a great class Carla and Mr. Skorka have with the common ground.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And Epic was a really great organization for them to be part of and listen to.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So it was just nice to be able to see that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And what I really liked about my observation anyway, and I'm sure that Mr. Skorka and Carla have extended the invitation to folks here to observe the common ground.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: was just the natural friendships that exist without having to really be facilitated so much by the adults.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And that's really the goal in all of our schools.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So it was a good model for being able to start.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Nice.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: That's great.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Well, I'd love to put them in touch if they want with Dr. Tom Hare, who, you know, he's retired from Harvard now, but he always also taught us disability is natural, that we are all disabled at some point.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So again, whether it's by COVID, you know, pregnancy, Alzheimer's, anything, ultimately old age, whatever, we're all disabled at some point.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So disability is really natural.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And Tom,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I know he wouldn't mind me sharing because he's been sharing himself publicly.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Tom was actually just diagnosed, he retired last January and he was just diagnosed last month with ALS.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So again, disability is natural and Tom, if anybody is, you know, is prepared for a life with disability for the remainder of his life.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Um, hard diagnosis for sure, but I'm so glad he's, um, he has a great community surrounding him.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So, um, but I'm sure he would love to talk to your student about ableism.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So if they're interested, um, Tom's Tom's their guy.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So great.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I'm in touch.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So one of the things that we've done, we've had this evolution of this conversation around how to build friendships.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: with students with disabilities in our community and schools for all the obvious reasons, both related to equity, related to student achievement.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Both students with and without disabilities do better academically when they're integrated, as the research has shown, among other things.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So that's part of the initiative.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so Common Ground has been a really great model at the high school level.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And we have had some parents from the autism support group and also

[Melanie McLaughlin]: from C pack that had been exploring best buddies and I believe that exploration kit is continuing.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: you know, the teachers in a lot of ways as well, with the remote learning, especially, and that to really good leaders are gonna capitalize on that family and community engagement, and they're gonna really figure out how to move that forward.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And then thinking back to

[Melanie McLaughlin]: my policy class, you know, from graduate school a couple of years ago too, it's sort of tackling this in the, in the, in the trifold, if you will, sort of, what are the, what are the barriers to this happening?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So schedule certainly always, you know, financial and organizing and resources.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so if we're looking at that sort of triangle of how we answer those three pieces, then it's sort of a way in which these can be tackled.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But I appreciate hearing, especially the listening sessions, but I also appreciate hearing what's happening

[Melanie McLaughlin]: In-house, I think what I'm also hearing from Claire and from others is how we integrate the family and community engagement piece into it so that the communication is, again, really loud and turned up, and they feel like they're being involved in the process.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But again, I'd love to hear what other folks think.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: That's just my perspective.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Is everybody talked out now?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Pretty much right before vacation.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I feel Yeah, I gotta go.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Galussi.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I am wondering if there's going to be consideration specific to the Cohort A model because it's more than

[Melanie McLaughlin]: sort of a hybrid or remote situation.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It's our most vulnerable students, as you know, and four days in person, one day remote.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So is there gonna be any listening sessions specific to those populations?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Yeah, I think that I'd like to see more specifically because I think, again, the most vulnerable students have different sort of subset.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so instead of them having to attend necessarily two meetings, going to both, whether there's an individual meeting specific to that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So just a thought, food for thought, again, with the time constraints that our families have, as you can imagine, having to go to

[Melanie McLaughlin]: one general session and then one individualized session might be a little bit tricky, but I will defer to administration, but would love to be kept into the loop as to what you all decide that will be most meaningful for the most vulnerable cohort A population.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I appreciate that very much, Superintendent Edward-Vincent, and I know that your inclination is to be inclusive and kind, and I do appreciate that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I do also think that is why I'm raising the matter, because as we're thinking about

[Melanie McLaughlin]: different subgroups and, you know, cohorting, but, you know, according to hybrid and remote, and then further by middle school, elementary school, and high school, I think as a parent of a child with a significant disability, oftentimes being in those meetings, there's a lot of time that is spent talking about things that do not relate to my child.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I think that there's a lot of times that parents have to sit in that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And also, you know, in instances where even when you said everyone is included, you know, also to ensure that our out of district families, our English learners and our students, families with disabilities do feel included, that there is some sort of forethought about how that's being addressed, I think is really important.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: That's conscious in terms of the thought, because I do know that there are

[Melanie McLaughlin]: are families who have children with significant needs who would not go to, say, a two-hour, if you will, meeting of a listening session for elementary school if they're in a very different place.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so maybe there's just the opportunity to offer something that is smaller and more appropriate for that cohort.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so I, again, in the interest of inclusion, that is why I'm bringing that up.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I appreciate the fact that you are always willing to listen.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Mayor Lungo-Koehn.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Yes, thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We met on January 21st for behavioral health.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We talked with Stacey Shulman, director of school counseling and behavioral health.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Our goal for this year is to address trauma-informed schools and stress and to make recommendations, policy recommendations to the school committee in a presentation in April or May of this year.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Stacey Shulman talked about the NAN project, which is a partnership through Elliott Health and Human Services created as a way to talk about mental health and behavioral health and their sort of mentor partnerships for students who have been through some mental health challenges and come out the other side to support students who are currently going through mental health challenges.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And there was also talk of a homework survey

[Melanie McLaughlin]: that Stacey Shulman did a presentation on.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: There were 781 student respondents to the survey around how many, whether there's a hypothesis that students were feeling that they were having a lot of homework.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: but that perhaps it's actually a carryover of asynchronous work and so the survey was created to sort of look at that hypothesis and what it did discover was that there was a divide between students and faculty.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Students did feel as though they were having more homework and teachers were feeling as though it was the same or

[Melanie McLaughlin]: as in prior pre-pandemic.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So there was some question around clarity for students around what is asynchronous work and what is actually classified as homework.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So that discussion will be continued in our next meeting on February 11th.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And then the latter half of our meeting was on special education and our question of our policy, our question of practice is how can we facilitate meaningful inclusion, inclusionary friendships for students within school and community?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So we've been talking about best buddies programs, sibling support groups and participating in community activities like Metro Recreation.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Metro Recreation was on the call as well as many other parents and individuals and teachers.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And we talked about inclusive recreation activities and how we can support them, building a volunteer list.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So Metro Recreation is looking for volunteers to support students with disabilities and form friendships and

[Melanie McLaughlin]: support the Recreation Center for Inclusive Recreation, and we're building an Excel spreadsheet around that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: If people are interested in supporting that, they can email me at melaniemclaughlin at medford.k12.ma.us, and we can get you on a list to get to Kate Quinn over at the Recreation Center.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And then teachers Carla Andre and Michael Skorka at the high school shared with us their Common Ground program, which is really

[Melanie McLaughlin]: about building horizontal friendships.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Those are friendships that are equal footing between students with and without disabilities and how that might be achieved in a thoughtful, meaningful way district-wide.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so that conversation will continue as well on February 11th.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So if you are interested in any of those topics, please join us February 11th from 5 to 6.30.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Sure, I actually we had asked Stacey Shulman.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I don't know if she's on the call if she would if she could do that, but I can certainly send an email again to share that it was a good presentation.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It was useful information and a lot to be said around defining sort of the terms of the survey.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So sure.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Mr. Murphy, during the testing for COVID test, don't we as parents get results from our children's tests within 24 hours, a notification of their results so that we would therefore know whether they were tested or not?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And if we don't get the results, then we can assume that they had not been tested?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Right, so that was confusing for me.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So then we do know who is and who is not getting tested.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you to Member Ruseau and to Superintendent and to my colleagues.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I actually am, you know, as tired as I am, I'm actually really enjoying this conversation.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I think it's a nice, healthy conversation to be having, to be listening to other perspectives about sort of even perfectionism and sort of, you know, lack of and all of the all of these other aspects.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And it had me thinking even earlier, and I

[Melanie McLaughlin]: didn't speak up then, but this seems like an opportunity to do so now is thinking about, again, the concept of ableism.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so, you know, so much of what we do as a district is often centered around as well, you know, not just perfect attendance, but, you know, spelling bees and reading contests and poetry contest and, you know, just all sorts of things that people who are fiercely competitive and

[Melanie McLaughlin]: all of those things, and I think we really need to be thinking outside of the box about how all of our children are feeling valued and receiving accolades for any number of things, whether it's perfect attendance or, you know, I would love to see the poetry competition be in either another language, I was saying, or, you know, somebody using a

[Melanie McLaughlin]: a device who doesn't communicate with words or you know just really thinking outside of the box on how we're doing these things so I think this is important and I don't think it's either or I think it's both and which is something I've been saying a lot of lately I think it's how do we figure out how to make the student who maybe has nothing else but the ability to come into school every single day because that's their safe place and they've been able to do it for 180 years and they really like being there and they get that award and it's the only little

[Melanie McLaughlin]: you know, plaque that they have at home and that they're sharing or whatever.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And it's something really substantive to them.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Or maybe it's, you know, we don't know all these different scenarios.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But I think how we are thinking outside the box is really where I want to see our district going and how we're thinking about how are we really valuing every child in these situations.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And, you know, not just perfect attendance and not just spelling bees or reading contests, like, how can we think about all of the children in these cases.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so I appreciate Member Ruseau and Superintendent and

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Um, and my colleagues for doing that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So, um, thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Yes.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Okay, thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Again, would not stop kids who are sick from coming to school I think.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: dramatic statement and one that I would like to explore more in subcommittee.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I'm also going to put a call, a call to action.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: for folks that might be interested in participating, I think we'll be surprised by the number of folks that would actually be interested in this sort of opportunity.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And again, what I really liked earlier today, I was talking with a staff member who was talking about authentic friendships and, you know, not, and she, the way she described it was horizontal friendships, which I really liked instead of vertical friendships.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: which they're not, you know, horizontal friendships are friendships on equal footing and they're friends because we're authentic friends.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We're not friends because we're doing somebody a favor or we think, you know, we're getting our volunteer hours or any of those sorts of things.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So we really are thinking about how are we building authentic friendships.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And Kate, yeah, Paul, remember what you said?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But yeah, I could do that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I didn't yet because we had said that we would still and I will do that if that's what we decide we want to do as a subcommittee.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And it was because in our last meeting in our meeting minute notes, we were still trying to figure out how that was going to be coordinated.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I don't know, maybe it's, you know, periodic presentations for school committee.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So because a report, you know, falls under a presentation as well, but a presentation isn't necessarily a report.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So just, yeah, I know it's sort of, you know, just wordsmithing a little bit, but maybe that would be.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I want to thank my co-chairs, Paul Rousseau and Mia Mostow for the Behavioral Health and Special Education Subcommittee.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We met, as you said, on the 19th

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Um, and we have identified, um, uh, this committee is a, is a, it has been a little bit tricky this year because it's behavioral health and special education, which are both very broad topics, as you can imagine, and very big topics.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Um, but we have the attendance, uh, regular attendance of the director of guidance, um, Stacey Shulman and the director of pupil services, Joan Bowen, um, and then several constituents from the community and, um,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: ongoing parent involvement and family engagement specific to those two topics.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We have identified trauma in trauma-informed schools as being our behavioral health

[Melanie McLaughlin]: topic of support for the year and thinking about ways to improve our school system around trauma informed schools.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And right now we're really in this sort of collective research phase where we're meeting with each other, getting information and research and resources from

[Melanie McLaughlin]: community members and folks that are attending and having discussion around what's currently happening in our schools regarding trauma-informed schools and what we would like to see happen.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Our goal is to probably in April of this year to have a presentation for the school committee with policy recommendations on those items.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: In the meantime, Stacey is working on

[Melanie McLaughlin]: trauma-informed practice with the school district around mindfulness and training about best practices in trauma-informed schools.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And again, we're building research and resources for the community at large, teachers, staff, and family members.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And then regarding special education, we're working on

[Melanie McLaughlin]: identifying ways in which we are building friendships for students with disabilities in our school to make it a priority, both for our our school committee, because we are, I think, representative of what we value and friendships are important in our schools.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It's an important social emotional component and can be

[Melanie McLaughlin]: more difficult for students with disabilities so we're focusing specifically on fostering friendships in our both in our school programs that are wraparound services for example our morning programs are after school programs and our athletic programs.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And out of school but community school based services so, and again we're collecting research and data right now on who's doing what and other districts, what we had acquired a friendship toolkit from an organization called the Arc of Massachusetts.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: which is a self-advocacy or advocacy organization that provides resources and support.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So we are looking at that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We have a couple of parents that are very interested in exploring a Best Buddies program.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We had formerly had a Best Buddies program in our schools.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: middle schools and so we're looking at piloting a best buddies program or something similar in our schools and we are looking at building a volunteer base for our recreation services among others for students who need it's again it could it could intersect with the friendship piece as well but it's for students who may need additional support say for example in recreation settings or

[Melanie McLaughlin]: you know, Metro Recreation is certainly looking for volunteers.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And we know that there are siblings out there that could additionally use some support, siblings of students with disabilities who could use support, but also could be a really great frontline for potential volunteers.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So we're excited about the work we're doing, and we'll continue with recommendations coming in the spring.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And our next meeting is the 17th,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: of December at five o'clock, from five to 6.30.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And if you find any of these topics interesting, we would welcome your attendance.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We welcome everyone's attendance, but specifically if you're interested in trauma-informed schools and building friendships for students with disabilities, please join us on the 19th.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I mean, it seems like we have some latitude in that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: for criminal charges.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Correct.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Yeah, I guess so.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But I mean, for me, it doesn't sound like that's very, you know, if somebody has to do three incidents to one person in order to be classified as, you know, having been a bully in this context, I mean, I think, you know, the harm that's done by the time you get to three incidents is pretty significant, potentially.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So, you know, that doesn't,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I mean, I understand that that's Massachusetts law but I think that I guess my question is, is there a latitude with our school committee, and maybe it's something that we refer to the policy subcommittee, where we have some flexibility around, you know, what, what that constitutes because it seems to me to wait till there's three times.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I don't know, that seems excessive to me, but I have more questions, so if you could bear with me.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: On page 25, Ms.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Bowen, PRS, Problem Resolution System, I'm assuming that's for all students, not just students with disabilities?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Oh, that's really interesting.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So as a parent of a student with a disability who has been familiar with PRS over the years, and as the CPAC co-chair would have you, I didn't realize that PRS will take complaints that are outside of the scope of students with disabilities.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Okay, that's good to know.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And then I assume they do the same thing that they do with students with disabilities.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: They sort of start their own.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Right.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And just to clarify, that is the step that's, and again, this is where a flowchart I think is helpful, that is the step that a family, caregiver, student, other individual could take.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: in the event that they felt dissatisfied with what was happening with the school's response to the bullying, not in the event, that's not the first place you go to, it's the place that you go if you feel like it's not right.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And then, so that's great that you guys included that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I'm wondering, was there a reason that you didn't also include the civil rights piece if it's a civil rights issue?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: violation.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So, you know, under like a 504, you can go, obviously, you wouldn't go, you don't necessarily go to PRS, you might go to the Office of Civil Rights, you go to OCR, whereas, you know, under IEP, you would go to PRS.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so in this context, it seems like it could potentially be PRS or OCR, depending on where you're at, right?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so DESI provided, did DESI put PRS on theirs?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Yes.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Oh, good.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Okay.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And then let me see process by which, oh yeah.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So two final questions.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And then I guess I'll put it to my colleagues to consider if they have questions as well to consider whether this is something that's further refined to the policy subcommittee.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But the other questions are, last two questions are, I thought this document was really helpful, although again, really dense because there's so much to convey around if a student is feeling bullied by a student, but it didn't, unless I missed it, again, I could very well have missed it.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I didn't necessarily see anything in the documentation that was

[Melanie McLaughlin]: addressing whether a student or if a student felt bullied by a staff member or an administrator or a teacher or anything to that degree.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Am I wrong?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Yeah.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I think that that's, if we could be a little more explicit about that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So in terms of the guidance around, you know,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Because for the way that it reads for me, for a lot of it, it's student on student.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And obviously, that's terrible.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But I do think that there's instances, certainly, where there can be, unfortunately, adult on student and perhaps student on adult.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I don't know.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So thinking about these other contexts are ways that

[Melanie McLaughlin]: maybe it's in the narrative or in the flow charter, both, where we're making it really explicit that, you know, bullying can happen to any degree.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I don't think people generally think of that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But certainly, I think if we reflect on our own

[Melanie McLaughlin]: perhaps if we reflect on our own experience, we might recall some examples where, you know, that was outside of the, the bullying was outside of the sort of standard application, I guess.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I would just encourage some, some explicitness around that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And then what is the process by which school, this is my last question.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So what is the process by which school committee is made aware of bullying investigations?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I guess incident reports, I guess both incident reports and investigation, because it would be interesting to know, you know, if we have, for example, say, you know, 20 incident reports at a particular school or 50 for that matter, at a particular school and never an investigation report, that could be interesting data, right?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I guess, is there a process by which

[Melanie McLaughlin]: there's either annual or biannual data updating the school committee.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Yeah, I mean, I think that would be really helpful.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And again, I'm not looking to, you know, dig deep into any data that would be

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Revealing of anybody's identity, we wouldn't want that, but certainly we can get numbers per school so that we're getting some identification of, you know, of that data.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And then I know the training that you were saying in terms of, yeah, oh, and I would also just encourage that

[Melanie McLaughlin]: every school has consistently in their handbook, you know, that there's bullying, obviously there's bullying information and perhaps the link to the full 30 page document.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But also I think part of, I know historically what I've seen as an issue for families is that they're not aware that an incident report is supposed to be filed when there's an allegation and even at an allegation level, not at an investigation level, but even at an allegation level.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: and that they should be aware of that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so I think that thinking about how are we actually making family caregivers aware that that should happen is really critical and not that they have to go to a 30-page document on our website to find out or even the one-page document cover on the website to find out, but that this information is being pushed to them, I think would be really important.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Absolutely.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And then if that could be applied to each of the student handbooks for each of the schools and or websites, even the one page with a link would be really helpful.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I really appreciate it.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Melanie McLaughlin, Halston Street and Bedford Mass.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you for the opportunity to speak.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I want to thank Councilor Caraviello and Councilor Morell and Bears and Scarpelli for bringing this matter forward.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Some of you may know that this is very personal to me.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I was the childhood friend of Andy Puglisi, who disappeared from Lawrence, Massachusetts on August 21st, 1976.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Wayne Chapman was convicted of raping two of my childhood friends from the same pool where Andy disappeared a year prior.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Chapman was arrested just 10 days after Andy vanished and was identified by several people as being at the pool the day that Andy disappeared.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: This has been a community trauma and a childhood trauma that we have all lived with for a long time.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: the past 45 years, frankly.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It was shocking to learn that this individual who I had been, frankly, researching and know far too much about for the past 20 years had actually, you know, been moved into a facility less than a quarter of a mile away from my home.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Sometimes life is stranger than fiction.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I really appreciate the chief and other folks who reached out and acted quickly.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: The mayor, for the letter that she wrote to the executive office of public safety and to Tom Turco, who also has been involved in this story for a long time.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Mass State Police have known this story for a long time.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It goes way back.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: and this is a very dangerous person that was in our nursing home around the corner.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And as you have said, there are two other level threes and one other level two that are placed in this facility.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And as Councilor Caraviello or Councilor Marks mentioned, there are very strict laws and Councilor Knight mentioned there are very strict laws around.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: level three sex offenders.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: There are communities that tried to set some parameters and were overruled by the Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: One of the things that I would really encourage is for community members to let their local police know if they see violations of level threes.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But indeed, you have to know who the level threes are and level twos are.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: for that matter, to be able to report anything to the police.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So it's very important that folks do go on to the sex offender registry and look at who in the community is a registered sex offender.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: To be a registered sex offender, you do have to be among the most dangerous, ruled by

[Melanie McLaughlin]: the Department of Corrections and by community members.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So these are the most dangerous and the most likely to re-offend.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And while I do understand that they also have rights, there are ways in which that the community can be notified, like the website on the city, the link to SOAR, the Sex Offender Registry Board, on the city and school websites, and potentially photographs of individuals like you see at City Hall in some of the public buildings that are also

[Melanie McLaughlin]: The one thing about the facility I do want to say is that there are a few facilities that agree to take level three sex offenders for a number of reasons.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So when they do find facilities that are willing to take them, they're often lumped together in that scenario so that you do have clusters of individuals.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so I think it's very valid to ask, you know, who the ownership of this facility is and what their

[Melanie McLaughlin]: requirements are around, you know, level three and level two sex offenders in the facility.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So again, I would appreciate that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I just, I also just want to say from, you know, a sentiment, if I, if I can be sentimental, how much I appreciate, excuse me, the community standing up in this matter.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It really does still affect the entire community that lost Andy 45 years ago.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So very much appreciate you folks standing up in this matter.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: just, you know, quickly introduce ourselves that could be helpful.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so the other piece that I think is really, really, really important is that we're not checking in with the kids to see what it is they want and what it is they need and how they're handling.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And that was one of the best experiences that I've had

[Melanie McLaughlin]: doing the Ed Talk show and Medford Community Media was getting the opportunity to spend some time with some, you know, juniors, 17, 18 year olds, 16, 17, 18 year olds that were not my own children, just sort of in a general, in a more general way, and I'll never forget we were doing a show on vaping, right, and they were talking about

[Melanie McLaughlin]: you know, we had several guests on that were talking about, you know, the dangers of vaping or whatever.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I was just so moved by one of the young men there who was a student and talking about like, when I said, well, what would you wanna say to parents or something to that degree?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And he said, well, I just wanna tell you that if you do find that you're, if you don't think that your child is vaping, you're wrong, right?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Because most of them are.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And he said, and if you do find that your child is vaping,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: that, you know, basically don't take it personally, don't make it about you, don't think that it's some failure of yours, right?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Don't make it, you know, don't sort of catastrophize it, but more so like talk to the student and listen to them.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: right?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: About what's going on and what they, and, and I thought about that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Cause I thought, I remember back in middle school when my, my kids who are now ones, a sophomore in college and one's a senior in high school, but back in middle school, they would come home.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I swear to God, they came home for like at least a good month, every single day telling me about vaping.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And they would be like, Oh my mom, you know, there's this thing vaping and it, you know, blah, blah, blah.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And they would tell me about it.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I would just sort of be like, Oh really?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: No, that's interesting.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But I never really explored it with them more because I just automatically assume like, well, they're not doing it.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Cause they're,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Number one, they're telling me about it.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And number two, it sounds horrible and blah, blah, blah.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But I wasn't exploring it more with them and listening to them.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I think that that's one of the biggest issues that I'm seeing with the mental health staff or that I feel like with the mental health staff, even in our own home, is that we're not checking in with the kids to see what it is they want, what it is is going to help them in this situation right now.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: You know, I think we have these family surveys that we're doing across the district or that we've done across the district for data collection, right?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But we're not doing it with the students at all.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And they're so, they're so, they're so techno-friendly.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Like we could probably get out, you know, a Google, a survey monkey to them or something, you know, whatever to them and their platform.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And we'd probably have more responses than we've ever gotten from parents.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: because they're so, you know, prone to that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I sort of think about that a little bit too, like even like a texted survey monkey or something where they could let us know what it is they really want for mental health support and what it is they really need around behavioral health and mental health support.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We're gonna switch our mindset here, because we have this sort of dueling actually agenda of these two topics, behavioral health and special education.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And as again, we've said before, behavioral health, we're really focusing on trauma informed schools and looking at what our community is going through currently and how we can support our students, teachers and staff.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And then for the special education component, we have identified

[Melanie McLaughlin]: the need for building community and school-based friendships.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And part of the reason that that was identified, the genesis sort of of this committee was the special education subcommittee was created last year.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I think it was a full year last year, or maybe it was a year and a half.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Yeah, I think it was a year and a half.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So not with Erin DiBenedetto from the school committee created the special education subcommittee as a result of recommendations from the Medford CPAC

[Melanie McLaughlin]: special education parent advisory council around issues and concerns that they had and wanting to be able to have some closer connection with school committee to address those issues and concerns.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: CPAC put out a survey last year as they do generally every year for a report that they also do to the school committee or present to the school committee at the end of the year with recommendations.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: One of the recommendations previously was that this subcommittee be started.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So thank you to Medford CPAC for that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And in the most recent iteration of the survey of our parents of students with disabilities, probably the biggest component

[Melanie McLaughlin]: that we found that they wanted to talk about, to ask about, to foster was building friendships in community and building connections to each other.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I think that we're all feeling isolated during these COVID times, but I think that, and I think that parents of children with disabilities have a unique isolation and certainly experienced that long before COVID.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: and have always tried to work to find their place in the community and to figure out how they could involve both their children and themselves more when they're already feeling marginalized.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So in a way, I feel like we sort of have a little bit of expertise on sort of some of this.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And in another way, you know, you deal with double the isolation in these sort of situations as well.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so I think it has even more, we have even more need for building

[Melanie McLaughlin]: community relationships and friendships for our more marginalized students.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so with that, I am going to turn it over to Joan for a moment, if you don't mind, Joan or Charlotte, to talk a little bit about what we've been discussing, and maybe some aspects of policy that we can consider.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I also want to let folks know that we got a really great email from

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Sheneen Peliquin, who was formerly recreation with the EMARC, which is now Communitas, which is the local DDS-funded organization for parents of children with disabilities.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And Sheneen specializes in recreation and friendship building.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And she sent us an attachment from the Arc of Mass, where I used to work, actually, that was a project based on building friendships that we can look at

[Melanie McLaughlin]: as we're moving forward.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I'm sure folks didn't have time to look at it in the short time that we had received it.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I'll make sure that central administration also has a copy of it.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It's a really great project that the ARC put together about how to build friendships for students with disabilities in schools and in communities, and adults, frankly, as well.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Yeah, no, 100%.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And it was done by both folks out on the South Shore, but also Dr. Zach Rossetti at Boston University.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I've done a lot of presentations with Zach, and he's a great presenter, and he's also a sibling.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Actually, his brother passed away this past year, but he was an adult.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: His brother was an adult, and they had a long sibling relationship, and it has driven

[Melanie McLaughlin]: a lot of Zach's study and research around disability and friendships and awareness.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I know that Zach would certainly be able and willing and interested in presenting for PD as well.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: He's a great presenter, so that could be something that we could be thinking of.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I couldn't agree more with the paraprofessional piece of it, especially as the children get to the middle school level and even at the fifth grade level.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: You know, even I remember with my typically developing daughter having that we, we hosted the Girl Scout dance, we did an 80s dance back in the day.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And, you know, it had been a lot of fun.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And just, you know, probably months earlier, she would have been happy to dance with me on the dance floor with all of her friends.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: That night, I learned a hard lesson as I was trying as I was dressed as Madonna trying to dance with them.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: that I was not welcome in that situation.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And, you know, a lot of times with our students with, you know, disabilities and explicitly in our students with intellectual and developmental disabilities, they aren't always able to tell me that, tell us that, right?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So my daughter, my fifth grade typical daughter didn't actually tell me either.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: They just sort of all gave me the cold shoulder and walked away.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But my child with the intellectual and developmental disability might not even be able to say that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And just even recently she was telling me that my voice was annoying and to stop talking.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So she was able to say it in those instances.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But I think that you're right.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: No fifth grader, middle schooler, high schooler wants the adults around at this stage.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So when kids are trying to develop friendships, and it's tricky because, you know, for our kids too, sometimes we have to facilitate the conversation, right?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Like, especially the reciprocal conversation, right?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So, you know, if somebody's asking you a question and you're just sort of sitting there not responding or trying to process or whatever, it's the prompting to say, you can ask that, you know, and thinking about how to fade that back.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I think that that's a really tricky, tricky piece, but I did like the book as well.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Tanya, you were talking about some things that you really liked about the book,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: share a little bit?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Right.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And we have stories, I think that's in a book that I've seen too, those stories where the parent, you know, sent a note back in to thank the parent for the drawing, right?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Because it was very clear that the child hadn't done the drawing.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It was, you know, a really well done and it was nice.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I mean, they would, they would sort of, you know, this joking around with it, but it's true.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It's sort of the wanting that line between the helpfulness, but also I think

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Tanya, as you were saying, you know, mentioning the authentic friendships too, it's like one of those things where, you know, we've had a number of friendships in school.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And, you know, they've been really great friends and, you know, really felt genuine in terms of the friendship.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But then the reality was, were we really getting phone calls to come over to the house for a play date?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Or were we really getting the invitations to the birthday party?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And if you're not, just in the adult relationships that we've had, or frankly, even in the school, the younger relationships we've had in our own life, if the relationship is one way, then is it really an authentic friendship?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Yeah, and that's exactly, I'm missing Carla in this conversation right now, but that's exactly some of the things that Carla has been talking about in these previous meetings.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so again, getting to the policy piece of it, it is what does that actually translate into in terms of school committee driving some policy around that?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And, you know, to that point, I think it's really important when you're talking about, you know, friendships, community, when we're talking about friendships in the community, it's, I think for so long, I was really, you know, sort of pushing friendships for my own daughter with non-disabled children.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Right.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I was never really thinking about fostering friendships for her with disabled children.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I just hadn't, you know, I was working so hard in inclusion that I wasn't thinking about that yet.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I was benefiting from my friendships.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: with people in the disability community and parents of people with a disability community.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It wasn't sort of giving her that opportunity.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so it's really about building friendships between and with students with and without disabilities for all of the obvious reasons.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: we don't have a partner, and I'm not in the school to facilitate a partnership for her, so then who is actually going to be doing that so that students with disabilities can participate in these enrichment programs?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: across all of our entities.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: reasonable accommodations to make sure that every person can access the life of the school and the enrichment that's involved in the school.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I guess as I'm thinking about the student testing, I'm thinking about, you know, my own child with a developmental disability and, you know, her responsiveness to testing and even frankly, myself, you know, I've had, I guess, five different tests now at this point.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I've only done one, the original one was the, you know,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I don't know what else to call it, but was the really long sort of brain probe, if you will, which was particularly painful, uncomfortable, you know, not pleasant at all, and has progressively, you know, gotten better in terms of, you know, also because I make it really clear that I'm not doing that one again.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So, you know, to the superintendent's point when she was talking earlier about the stop the spread sites, I do want to say, you know,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: several members of my family have been to the Suffolk Downs Stop the Spread site, and I can tell you from a personal experience, that is a site where it's a very non-invasive, if you will, nasal swab that you administer yourself.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: They give you the Q-tip or what have you, and then you hand it back.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So it was probably of all the experiences, it was the most reasonable.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But I'm thinking about this for our

[Melanie McLaughlin]: is, you know, for all of our children, our younger children, but also, you know, cohort A in terms of, you know, their ability, I guess, or, you know, my concern around the presentation of the testing and ensuring that the testing is the

[Melanie McLaughlin]: the, I guess, least non-invasive one, particularly for children who might not be that willing in the first place, so.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: That's fantastic.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I guess I would just say, you know, to Joan and Susanna and yourself, that I would not limit those social stories to students with disabilities.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: helpful to the community.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I think that with the metrics changing from the state level and with all of these unknowns, I mean, I'm going back again to my graduate level stats class and it's like, you can't compare apples to oranges and sort of, or change the data midway and sort of have these comparisons.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I think it would be really helpful.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I would also though concur with member Graham that I think we need notice.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I think an emergency meeting

[Melanie McLaughlin]: with is probably not as essential as it is to have notice to the community that this is what the meeting would be discussing, especially as we're thinking about, I mean, we're seeing every time I turn on the news, it's more, you know, dread and danger and mayhem.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And it's concerning as we're seeing the numbers rise.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And again, if you do a comparison, minus the COVID fatigue to the spring, we were all inside at this point, we weren't interacting with each other.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And then you're dealing with this COVID fatigue and people are

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Interacting more and more and to the point of, you know, this, we keep hearing this data that this is not happening in schools, or that the shares not happening in schools or exposures not happening in schools but there's these unknowns as Member Graham and Member Ruseau were discussing.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Yeah, I think that I appreciate member Graham's wanting to have a clear contingency plan for this population.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I also think that, you know, having been involved in special education for the past 12 years and on a number of different levels is that,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: you know, it's such a highly litigated field, number one.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Number two, it is very much at the individual level.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so every single time, believe me, I have gone both to the state and national level trying to create some systemic consistency around some of these bigger issues and have always gotten the response that,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: The catch 22 it here is that it is very individualized.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so, in, you know, to the director of people services perspective if you're looking at 300 or 800 or whatever students 300 in the.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: in the current cohort A, but if you're looking at 800 students and you're thinking about the contingency plan for the 800 at an individualized level, it's just like sort of an impossible question to ask.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So that's what I'm saying is if you can maybe help clarify with Ms.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Bowen, either offline or in this situation or whatever,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: some maybe specific questions that you want answers to, that could be a little bit more helpful.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But otherwise, it's sort of like throwing the whole thing up there and saying, give me a contingency plan for 800 different scenarios for each different student in every different setting.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And that's just impossible.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: You can't.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So if maybe we could be a little bit more specific in some of the formulations of the questions, that could be a little bit more helpful.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But to the legal aspect point,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: you know, Joan Bowen's responsibility as the Director of Pupil Services is to meet every single one of those students individualized education needs.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Through the chair, if I may.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Member McLaughlin, then Member Ruseau.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I would just say that's very helpful.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I think that that is a very helpful clarification because the reality is that is our legal obligation, period.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So it's not an option.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I'm sure that the staff can support what that is.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: supports and services, even in a global pandemic, they have to be provided.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So there are those nuances, but yeah, that's our responsibility.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I think that's perfectly reasonable.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So looking at the 62%

[Melanie McLaughlin]: persons of color and more than 80% or 80% high needs.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so what is the intersectionality around addressing the social emotional component of this?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I know that Stacey Shulman has her hand raised.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I'll be curious to hear that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But as we're addressing trauma, as we're addressing social emotional needs of children, and again, getting back to some of that implicit bias around that, what that looks like.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And, you know, a student who is experiencing a lot of aggression at home and then comes into school and

[Melanie McLaughlin]: you know, maybe has a teacher or someone that is, seems threatening or aggressive to them and they explode, you know, we understand that that can be a root cause of trauma.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So, but the data does speak volumes in that 80% of our students that are getting disciplined are high needs.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so I would love for folks to talk about that as well.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: 84 out of 112?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Except it's not because it's 11.5 plus 15 plus 11.5 for the high need, well it depends on the students with disabilities

[Melanie McLaughlin]: and the economically disadvantaged are also in the high needs 11.5.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So the 15.8 and the 12.3 are the equivalent of the 11.5.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: That's the way I'm looking at it right now.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Well, then how can it, if it's students disciplined and 84 of them are high needs and the total students disciplined are 112, that's not 11%.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you, Jenny.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I was saying approximately 80, looking at 84 to the 112.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Right.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But it's actually 75% because Jenny, you know, used her calculator or her brain and did the math.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Calculator.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I was like, I assume calculator, but I didn't want to.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So that's a really, that's an important point.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: 75% of them are high needs of the students who are being disciplined.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And again, it goes to the same point that member Rousseau is saying, you know, are we saying that students who have high needs are, you know, require discipline more than students who don't?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Maybe, and maybe again, you know, Stacey Shulman can speak to that, but maybe suspension isn't the way to address that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I'm done now, but I wanted to just point out that data.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And then I am going to ask if everyone's okay, Paul, that you stop sharing the screen just so I can go back to my Word document to take notes.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I was listening and I just sort of wanted to ask folks or have folks think about a few things.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: One is, I don't think that this is suggesting that we're taking away discipline.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I think it's

[Melanie McLaughlin]: suggesting that we're taking a closer look at what the disciplinary measures that have been being used are, how effective they've been, and whether or not color has played or race has played a role.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I think the data shows, I don't think, I know the data shows us that race clearly has played a role.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So we were just listening to a student speaking the other day talking about wearing headphones in the hallway at the high school.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And she, and this wasn't recent, so I don't want anybody to think that this was them.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: but she talked about walking in the hallway and she's a black woman student and being yelled at and disciplined for having her headphones on in the hallway as a white student was walking by her doing the exact same thing and did not get yelled at, did not get disciplined.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And that is part of the problem.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And that is where the implicit bias comes in.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I think that people don't realize that we don't realize that we are built with this implicit bias because we are

[Melanie McLaughlin]: part of a system that we were brought up in and have been part of our entire lives where we see things as threats related to color, unfortunately.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And we see them as more threatening when they're related to color.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And that's why we see disproportionality and discipline.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I mean, disproportionality and discipline is a national issue in the United States.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It's not something that's specific to Medford.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It's a national issue.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: People of color are disproportionately disciplined.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: in our schools and that, I think, is what Member Ruseau is trying to address in this subcommittee and in this resolution.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And that's what I would like us to really take a look at.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And the discussion that we're not hearing right now, I feel like, is, you know, I appreciated what Stacey Shulman was saying as well about, you know, going back and looking at the events and what sort of triggers the suspension.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I think that's important, too, to look at the backstories and the data and the information.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But the fact still remains that we are still disproportionately disciplining

[Melanie McLaughlin]: students of color and that is regardless of the instances or the you know what happened or whatever that is a direct result of our own bias and you know

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I can share sort of one of my own stories, you know, as a mother of a white male student who, you know, in high school, I mean, in middle school, certainly was disciplined, but might have got a phone call home first.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And again, as the co-chair of the CPAC and someone who's involved in the schools and someone who has maybe some means and has a relationship with the administration and all those other things, got phone calls home

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Um, from them to address any sort of discipline issues and also, you know, a student on a, on an ed plan.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Um, so the disability certainly was a factor in this role, but also in this situation, but also got the benefit of a phone call home.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Um, when another parent may not have gotten that, um, maybe because they didn't have a relationship or maybe because they weren't white, or maybe because we don't realize that we do those things.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: They're not intentional, but they, we do do them.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so we have to pay attention to those.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I think that's really.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: an important piece, and as much as I wish color wasn't a part of this, it clearly is because the data shows us that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Um, member Graham, can you send me those two additions in the chat just for the notes?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Um, I got the first one, but not the second.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And then, um, thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: One is people are asking a lot about IEP timelines.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So how are we addressing initial evaluations, re-evaluations, and expired IEPs?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Two is the guidance from the report is saying children should work independently or teachers should be able to provide work for children to work independently.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: As we know, there are a lot of children in our community, in the disability community, that are not able to work independently.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And what are we doing in those instances?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Also drilling down with that a little bit more, how are we addressing children who have had one-to-one paraprofessionals?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Next question is paraprofessionals and computers, whether they have access, how are they getting them?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Are paras attending the staff meetings that are being scheduled regularly so that they're being included in part of the conversation?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We talked a little bit about this ourselves, Joan, but I want to point out to the community

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We have a lot of families that are really struggling right now with children who may have been in out of district placements or elsewhere with mental health issues, self injurious behavior, things that, you know, in addition to what we're all dealing with on a pandemic level and being in social isolation at home are just so much more exacerbated with these particular families and how are we supporting them?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: and their families.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so to the point what you were saying about Stacey Shulman a little while ago, but also how that addresses families and not just students.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So how are we handling compensatory services for therapies?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So for people who don't know a lot about special education, students may get therapies like speech and language, occupational therapy, physical therapy.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: DESE is not requiring, as the guidance said,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: not requiring those therapies to occur during this time.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: However, they are part of IEPs.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so how do we address compensatory services?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So if children aren't provided their IEP services, typically there's compensatory services.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Special education is also very legally dense.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So it's hard to answer a lot of these questions, but just sort of putting them in people's minds to be thinking about.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: What social emotional connections?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I'm almost done, two more.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: What social-emotional connections are we providing to our out-of-district students?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So for our out-of-district students who are, you know, sometimes sent to Lexington or Belmont or, you know, Beverly or what have you, who don't have necessarily connections to their out-of-district placements because those students are all from other areas as well, how are we connecting our out-of-district students to the community

[Melanie McLaughlin]: in this social isolation time?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So for example, we know that every student is assigned to a school because that's the way out of district placement works.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So even if you're out of district, you're still part of a school, you're able to take extracurricular activities at that school, you're supposed to be a part of the life of the school.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So is there a way that we can be connecting these children, these students to social opportunities, meetings, online meetings, recess, morning meetings, what have you?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Extended school year is another big question.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And are we posting and sharing resources for remote learning?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So again, these Google level, I mean, these Google folders grade level where we're sharing information amongst people.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I know that's a long list for you, Joan, and we'll answer more on Wednesday.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I hope so.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Correct, yes.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I just want to point out to the mayor and to, I don't know if Christine's still on here, but those compensatory services and ESY costs are real.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I know that the guidance from DESE was to provide as many services as we can now so that we're not dealing with all those compensatory services and compensatory service costs later.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But they're really something that needs to be considered.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And also toward that end and around gathering data for staff, families can also be gathering data at home just in terms of showing and documenting any

[Melanie McLaughlin]: regression if there is any, because as we're seeing from our survey, the two biggest concerns right now in the CPAC survey is regression and social isolation.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: OK.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I just want to say thank you and I'm assuming Mayor Lungo-Koehn that these will all be available for the public on the website?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: represent them and to be updated.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Unfortunately, those aren't shared with the community, and they're feeling a need for updates as well.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I think we need to think as a group, and I'm asking our colleagues to be thinking as a group, as how we can make this work for everybody so that we're getting updates, the community's getting updates, and we're able to

[Melanie McLaughlin]: feel like it's more regular because with all that you're doing, I do hear from our voting members that they are feeling that there needs to be more in terms of community update and family and community engagement.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And that's what's so important about this meeting is that we now have, we have 60 people on this call.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We started with 80.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So 60 have held through for three hours as well.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I'm sure there's lots of other things they would like to be doing too.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I hear you, but I am also asking, and I am also asking our colleagues for some creative solutions around this.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I move a motion to move the meeting on Monday to 4 o'clock.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Yes.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I think that we should be asking, if we're not prepared to do that, which I would say, I'd venture to say, 10 days is not meaningful family engagement, then we should be asking for an extension on this report.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: have to say that, you know, when we're talking on the other side of the budget and we're talking about $130,000, everybody's talking about how much money that is.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I have to say,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: you know, that I don't find this meaningfully engaging families.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: brown and black and disengaged families who aren't around the table.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I don't feel comfortable doing that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I do feel like we really should be thinking about how this is affecting our families and whether it's, and I understand it's, you know, robbing Peter to pay Paul, if you will, in terms of moving money around and what have you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But this Student Opportunity Act is explicitly requiring us to have those engagements.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And even if it's in this one paragraph

[Melanie McLaughlin]: where we're talking about reaching out to CPAC, or we're talking about reaching out to the LPAC, which the LPAC is barely existing, is existent at this point.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Is there anything on the registration form or on the behavior contract that makes any note of if you have a disability or need accommodations, a process or procedure for letting folks know?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And if not, maybe I need to make it.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And making sure that the families know, obviously, so that they can be able to prepare in advance.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: For some parents, it's hard to be able to let your child go on these trips.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But if you feel like there's support there, then it makes all the difference.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I'd like to make a motion then that the field trip materials have a line item for individuals with disabilities letting folks know.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: that if they need accommodations that they, you know, that there's an avenue to pursue to let folks know what those accommodations are.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I make a motion to include materials on the field trip, any, you know, this particular field trip, but obviously, you know, we'll move forward in future field trips, that if families need accommodations for students with disabilities that they just need let us know.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Certainly.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Looks like another great trip.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Same point, just if you could include on the forms that if there's any requirements for any accommodations for students with disabilities

[Melanie McLaughlin]: That would be appreciated.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And again, the same with the behavior.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It's unclear to me, and maybe it's a longer conversation with superintendent.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: The behavior agreement is included on this one.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So thank you for that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Yeah, so maybe it's a longer conversation with superintendent Edouard-Vincent about how

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It's addressed if there's behavior that are manifestations of a student's disability.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So maybe we can talk more about that, but have some language that would be helpful for people that need accommodations.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you so much.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: You're welcome.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Enjoy.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I wanted to thank you and Mia for introducing me to the Food Security Task Force and Shira and Carol and Sarah Klugisch and all the folks in Medford who are working on this really important issue.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I learned two very important things from the Food Security Task Force when I attended their meeting.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And one was that I said, you know, why don't you just call it hunger?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And you know, why do you keep calling it food insecurity?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: What does that actually mean?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And they shared with me that we're all hungry every day, but food insecurity is very different than being hungry.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Hungry, we know when our next meal is coming.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Food insecurity is when you don't know where your next meal is coming from and how you'll get it.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And that really stood out to me.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And also where they were sharing the one in nine Medford households experience food insecurity.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And one of the things that the food,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: task force really wanted to work on was de-stigmatizing food insecurity because often it's the case that we know people that are experiencing food insecurity and they're not sharing that with us because of the stigma attached to

[Melanie McLaughlin]: having food insecurity and being hungry.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I really applaud the work of the Food Security Task Force.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And thank you, Mia, and all for bringing it forward.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I would encourage community members to attend the meetings and get involved as much as you can, because I know that none of us want to see a child hungry.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.
