[Melanie McLaughlin]: I do have some questions around the equitable piece of it, and I appreciate you acknowledging that we're doing the best we can with what we have in terms of the programmatic elements.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: You had said that

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We have to ensure that the children are going to the school that's most appropriate for their needs, which I think begs a bigger question in our district around equity.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: All of our schools should be able to deliver for each of our children's needs.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I know that that's a process that we're working towards and that I hope that the school committee continues to work towards.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But I have questions in that realm.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And we get a lot of these questions.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So getting back to what was happening last year with the

[Melanie McLaughlin]: with the audit.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Some of our schools have disproportionately more high-need students, whether they be English learners, students with disabilities, economically disadvantaged students.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so if you're coming from a pool of elementary school students that have a higher population of high-need students, and then they're rounding out the number, or everyone's getting the same amount of students that are in the lottery.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: One school has a disproportionate amount of

[Melanie McLaughlin]: English learners or students with disabilities, and then their numbers are skewed because they are going to a particular environment.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so how is that being adjusted for is one question that I have.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Another is we talk about sibling preference.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: What happens if you have a sibling that is a student with a disability that's going to a programmatic piece?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Or if you have a sibling who you've aged out of the

[Melanie McLaughlin]: specific English learner program that might be applied for that program or for that school and you're going to another.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So how are we addressing sibling preference for our students with high needs or that have siblings with high needs.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And then the third is what if students are identified after the fact.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: What if you know the lottery happens and they're enrolled into a school and then they're subsequently identified as having a particular disability or they enroll into our schools initially and they're in one school

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And then they're subsequently identified.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: How are we addressing that?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Are we taking them out of a school mid-year to deal with programmatic elements?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Or how is that being addressed?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Oh, it was just how are we going to address the equity for students with high needs so that if we're being random and trying to be equitable across the schools, that we're not addressing all of the students in terms of the equity for the lottery because of the programmatic elements.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But I think that's probably a much bigger question than you can address tonight, Dr. O'Keefe.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So then equity is not that everybody gets the same, it's that everybody gets what they need, right?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I want to thank you all for looking at the equity and balance across the middle schools.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I'm also the co-chair of the Special Education Parent Advisory Council and have been for the past six years.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: One of the things that we're concerned about is equity across the district for every child.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so it's about, we understand that there's some programmatic elements regarding EL and special education, but I think those visuals were very helpful and supportive.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I'm a visual learner.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I thought those were really great.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I would love to see those visuals for special education in English language and what that looks like at the middle schools and to be able to see if there's a disparity there.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Is one middle school getting more of those students and another not?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And what that actually looks like for us.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Because I think as I said from the podium last year, as we're thinking about equity, we have to think about it for all of our students.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I think that the socioeconomic piece here is really compelling.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But again, there's a big piece that we feel is missing, which is the special education and English learner.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: population piece as well, and I know that there have been a lot of families that have been frustrated and have given me feedback about that, either being automatic.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I know that you're saying, part of the problem is that the IEP does drive the process and the team decisions, but a lot of times the

[Melanie McLaughlin]: families don't know what the expectations are, the programming might be or why the McGlynn is different than the Andrews or what the programmatic elements are.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so I think it's also worth doing a comparison when we're saying everybody sort of dismisses what we can't have similar programs at these schools.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I think that I would like to say, let's think out of the box a little bit more around that and say, well, what would that look like?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: What does that actually mean?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: How does that really break down into numbers?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And since the schools are only a few hundred feet away from each other, is that actually

[Melanie McLaughlin]: realistic, can we not have people transporting, you know, between the schools, whether it's, you know, staff on different days or what, I don't know.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But I think thinking outside of the box for our EL students and our special education students as well so that they feel like they're having equity across the district is really important because we're not feeling that right now and I think that we need to be.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So, but I appreciate the courageous conversations that we're having.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I think this is really important around equity.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I also really appreciate that it's been done at the middle school level.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I know and I hope that we'll be looking in the future at the elementary school levels as well, because I think that these visuals and these demographics are really important to create the conversation that you're starting here.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So we appreciate that you're doing that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Do you think we might have a visual for the special education EL?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I think the visual would be really helpful, and then just also understanding the programmatic elements at the school so that people can understand what this actually breaks down to and not have this ambiguity around, you know, all the EL students are going here, some of the kids with disabilities are there, some are there, and it's not making people want to be at one school or another, you know, because then it creates another level of inequity and conversation.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Yeah.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you for being patient.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I'm Melanie McLaughlin, and I am from Austin Street in Medford.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And we are the co-chairs for the Medford CPAC.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So thank you for letting us present to you annually what we accomplish throughout the year.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So CPAC is the Special Education Parent Advisory Council for Medford.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And our logo is where everyone belongs.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We are happy to have been of service to the 888 or so families that are receiving special education services and supports in Medford.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Most of you folks know that the CPAC is required under the Massachusetts General Law.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So every school district is required to have a special education parent advisory council.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And our role is to advise the district on matters pertaining to special education.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: services and programs, and safety of individuals with disabilities.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We look for input from parents, guardians, family members, and we meet regularly with school officials.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We participate in the planning of programming and the evaluation process of the special education programming as well.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We plan workshops and seminars for families and community engagement.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We field lots of phone calls from parents as they're navigating the special education system.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We host family-friendly events and

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It's really been a joy to serve the community for the past several years.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Our board members are myself and Tanya Sullivan.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Treasurer is Jameel Webb Davis, who's with us tonight.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And our secretary is Anne Russo.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We have lots of people who help out with the Medford CPAC.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And for folks that are watching tonight, we want to say thank you all for all your help and participation in coming to our seminars and workshops over the years, and for being there to not only support the CPAC, but to support each other, because we're stronger as a community together.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Membership includes students and families who have IEPs or 504 plans and other interested parties.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So when we say where everyone belongs, it's where everyone belongs.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So you're all included to attend and be part of, and we welcome.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: My apologies for the little alignment here.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We uploaded to Google Drive just a few minutes ago.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you, Emily, for your help with that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So our goals, we advocate for every child in our community, and we promote equity in our schools for all children, regardless of race, color, ability, national origin, immigration status, sexual orientation, or race.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We really want to provide mentorship, support, resources, and expertise to families and community members on issues of inclusion and exclusion, and offer equality of opportunity, civil and human rights, and legislative advocacy, especially on behalf of our marginalized children.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: When we talk about equality of opportunity, a lot of people might not know what that means.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And essentially, we don't believe that every child should get the same.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We believe that every child should get what they need.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Next.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Oh, we actually updated this a little bit.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Kathy Medaglio just gave us a little bit of an update.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So at the beginning of the year, we had 770 students on IEPs.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And it's actually gone up over the year because of new enrollments, what have you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We're roughly at about 888 right now.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But the percentages are roughly the same.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So 18.8% of our student population.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So almost 20% of our students are receiving special education supports and services.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We have actually about 32 out of district.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It's a little bit higher than the state average, but Kathy can talk a little bit about that as well if folks are interested.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But out of district families are folks who are placed in other outside schools for varying reasons.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And one of our goals for the upcoming year

[Melanie McLaughlin]: help those families feel more involved and part of our community.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I think our out-of-district families especially need to feel that they're a part of a community when they're not in our schools.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We have a lower full inclusion rate than the state, but we have a higher partial inclusion rate in our special education classrooms, and we have a lower subseparate rate.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So the difference between those, our full inclusion is 80 percent or more in general education setting.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Partial inclusion is between 79 and 40 percent, so that's a

[Melanie McLaughlin]: wide range for partial inclusion.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And then subseparate would be 40% or less time spent in general education.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Some of our accomplishments for the past year is we host multiple seminars.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We meet the second Wednesday of every month.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Principal Downs has been so generous in offering the Andrews Middle School to us every month, as Paul DeLeva did before.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And we're so happy to have that venue.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: They've always been so welcoming to us.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Second Wednesday of every month from 7 to 9 we meet, and we host workshops.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: This year we had workshops on anxiety in schools, dyslexia, ELL, disability rights as human rights, executive functioning, and we've also hosted coffee with the principals.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We should note for the anxiety, dyslexia, and ELL presentations, we've worked with administration and our central administration to bring in speakers from our schools.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So we've had our ELL director,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We've had guidance Councilors come in.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It's been a really nice collaboration between families and administration and teachers working together to help our families across the district.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We've also presented workshops at Bridgewater State, the Mass Down Syndrome Congress, and Federation for Children with Special Needs.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We helped create and participated in a universal design for emergency preparedness safety in our school subcommittee with national recognition of our efforts featured on NPR.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: There's a link to that that we're happy to share.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: The NPR recognition was really nice.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We've worked really hard on that committee over the past year, and we've had about seven committee members, again, administrators, parents, a number of folks looking at safety in our schools and how we think about emergency preparedness for all our students using universal design.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So essentially the idea that if you design something for everyone with everyone in mind, then everyone will benefit.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so our safety in schools, you know that we did a presentation to you folks last month on that, and we're going to continue that committee.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It's been very effective, and we've really enjoyed working on that as well.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Next page.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We also helped launch and participated in a special education subcommittee this year.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you to the subcommittee members here, the school committee.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We really appreciated that happening, and we've been focusing on disability awareness and out-of-school time.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: including after school and recreational program for students with disabilities.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So again, we spent the year meeting with school committee members and administrators and folks from community stakeholders, talking about how we can improve access to our after school and recreational program for students with disabilities, for all students really, and also how we could improve disability awareness.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So one of the things that came out of that that's been really great is the Director of Speech and Language

[Melanie McLaughlin]: along with others, created a disability awareness course in the district.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And about, I think, 44 teachers and staff enrolled in that disability course.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I had the pleasure of presenting at the first course on disability rights as human rights.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: The class was really well received.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And it was just really nice to see people asking questions and really understanding what disability awareness is and how disability is another aspect of diversity, and having disability pride and celebrating that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: They also had a panel where they included siblings and family members and a self-advocate.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: The course was wonderful.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I assume that they're going to teach it again next year.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It was really well received.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: They're talking about also maybe people were asking for a 2.0, so that was exciting.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We partnered with community organizations for family outreach, including the West Medford Community Center, Medford Family Network, community schools, and CCSR.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Oh, you can skip that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: That's repeat.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And then our recommendations for the year.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So we have just about five recommendations.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And one of the things that was really effective about the subcommittee, special education subcommittee this year was we felt like we focused on two issues and we could really move those issues forward when we can focus on just a few.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so we're respectfully asking the school committee, the mayor, the superintendent to look at these five topics and think about how we can move these

[Melanie McLaughlin]: forward, even if we pick a few of them over the next year to work on so that we can see some progress.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: One is that we would recommend creating a district-wide survey slash inclusion report.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And what we're recommending for this is that we survey general education teachers, special education, paraprofessional, administrators, and families on the current culture in our schools for inclusive practice and what improvements are needed.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We'd also obviously like to hear what's working.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So we can continue to improve, to continue to implement that, but also to think about what we can do to move things forward for more inclusion for every student.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We also would like to recommend offering professional, meaningful professional development on differentiated instruction and supplemental curriculum for teachers, paraprofessionals, and families in partnership with the CPAC.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: One of the reasons we talk about that specifically in partnership with the CPAC

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We had a very personal experience where we didn't understand until I think third grade or the end of third grade that there's actually a supplement to our curriculum for students with disabilities.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so we found that out through the ELL department because we understood that there's a supplement for English language learners.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And then we were able to explore a little bit more and understand that you folks had voted on a supplement for special education, which was really wonderful.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I felt like if I didn't know that, that there's probably a lot of folks out there that don't know that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so we want to make sure that folks do know that and that that's a real stepping stone for differentiated instruction for everyone in the community.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so the professional development would be around how to use that supplemental curriculum and how to, you know, show parents what that is and how they can use that at home as well.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We would also recommend implementing a co-teaching model at the elementary level.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We know that there's some co-teaching at the elementary level.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It's just not systemized and sort of, yeah, systemized, I guess, as it is at the high school level.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And we think it's been a really good model, and we know that it's a proven effective model for being able to work in general education settings for students with and without disabilities to be effective in teaching all of our children.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: This is a low-hanging fruit, if you will.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Replace and create consistent language for school missions, websites, school-to-home forms, et cetera, to be inclusive.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: This is one of the things that we talked about at the subcommittee for the school committee as well, is just how are we looking at our language across the district?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And we did a preliminary study, nothing sort of expansive, but we just started to poke around on our websites.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: look for the language on each of the school websites.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And some of the schools had school improvement plans.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Some didn't.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Some had missions.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Most all of them had missions, I believe.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Not all of them mentioned inclusion or equity or students with disabilities.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And we just think that it would be nice to have a language that would be inclusive, because we know that Medford is an inclusive community and wants everybody to feel welcome.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And we are one Medford.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And just thinking about how we're thinking about our messaging of that, if you think about the four frames of Bowman and Diehl,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: and the symbolic frame, how we're messaging that across the district.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Publishing school improvement plans on all school websites.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So like I said, there was just probably one or two that didn't have the school improvement plans.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And seeing them are really helpful, but also seeing what the plans are for almost 20% of students with disabilities in the schools would be really helpful.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And then expand inclusive communities for children with and without disabilities.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So we would recommend providing training for inclusive community schools.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: athletic and after school program.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So one of the things that we worked on in the subcommittee was the after school and out of school time.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And we talked about some of the language and making some of that language more uniform.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And there's going to be a training provided for the summer fun camp and the Councilors there.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We think that's a really great first start.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We want to expand on that to make sure that our community school programs, athletic programs, recreation programs, what have you, all have experience in working

[Melanie McLaughlin]: and embracing children with disabilities.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: An example of that is we were in the swim program this year.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And it was interesting for me to see there was a little bit of disconnect in the swim program.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And we went, I think, to the second or third swim lesson.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And it just occurred to me that nobody had ever taught the swim instructor in the pool with our daughter just something really basic, which is just, first of all, it might be difficult to hear because of the acoustic, especially if the child has a hearing deficiency.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: but the acoustics in the pool can be really hard to hear.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So sometimes just, you know, motioning or, you know, saying swim or, you know, so using some, you know, basic sign language can be really helpful, but also just the first then.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Like first you're going to swim, then we're going to jump or whatever, just some basic, you know, and it was really, it wasn't fair.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I realized in that setting that it wasn't fair to the person that was in the pool, nor was it fair to the child just to not have that basic communication that we as parents

[Melanie McLaughlin]: just sort of take for granted.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And maybe some of the administration takes for granted, too, because they're so used to doing that with our children.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So just some basic training.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We would love to see a Best Buddies program within our district.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We used to have one at the McGlynn Middle School, or a Best Buddies-like program, if the Best Buddies program is too expensive.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But we could potentially create a friendship program, a mentoring program.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And all of these recommendations, we want to assure you,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We're ready to roll up our sleeves and work with you on these.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: These are nothing that we're asking other people to do.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We want to work with you to make them happen and offer written guidelines on requirements of ADA, the Americans with Disabilities Act, and building inclusive communities.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So in some experiences, our families have inadvertently, mostly because it's just people who maybe don't experience life with disabilities themselves and just don't understand that

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Accessibility is an important part of our community, but also it is part of the law and helping people understand what the Americans with Disabilities Act is, even if it's just in basic, you know, writing that, you know, folks need to provide reasonable accommodations when children are accessing programs within the district.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And then, of course, we want to know how we can help and what next steps can be taken.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And for folks who want to know what that sign is, that's the sign for I love you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: That's my daughter, and she has a t-shirt on it that says, keep calm, it's only an extra chromosome.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So we want to know how we can help, and we'd be happy to take any questions if anyone has any.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I don't have them with me, but I can certainly get them to you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: OK.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But we are, you know, they're right on the DESE website.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So if you do school district profiles.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Yeah, I checked.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Yeah, no, I can email it to you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I'm sure we can have it our way.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Small difference for the

[Melanie McLaughlin]: higher for partial inclusion.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We're very high for the partial inclusion.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: For the full inclusion, I think it's a smaller, but the range for the... One of the difficulties is, you know, with DESE as well, that the range for partial inclusion, like we said, is 79 to 40.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I mean, that's a pretty big stretch, right?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So what does that really mean and what does that translate into?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I think that's when you start to look into the programs and see what's happening around our schools.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But again, you know, as was said in the school committee meeting for the last session, I think it's really valuable to go into the classrooms

[Melanie McLaughlin]: and see what's happening in our classrooms here.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I had that experience this year where I was able to sort of observe some of the classrooms and some of the programming.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I really encourage the school committee to do that and to see for themselves what's happening in our subseparate classrooms.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So in our partial inclusion classrooms and our full inclusion classrooms, because we should be looking at every classroom and seeing how we can help and how we can support every child.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We really enjoyed that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And it wasn't obviously just the CPAC.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Central Administration, Kathy Medaglio, lots of folks really helped out with that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And one of the things that's really exciting about that is we created what we're calling an IER, which was an

[Melanie McLaughlin]: individual emergency response, much like an IEP, an individual emergency response form so that families who need extra planning in their IEP for emergency response have this form that can be looked at and they can review if your child needs extra help in an evacuation center or a fire alarm or whatever.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It can be part of the legal document, part of the IEP.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So the IER is something that we're actually going to present at a state level as well to the Committee on Education because we think it should be something that should be not only

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It's statewide but national, so once again, Medford's leading the way.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We're really happy to be part of that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Not that I'm aware of.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Well, so actually Megan came to the subcommittee meetings for the special education committee, so out of school time and after school.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so Anthony Petrellis is working with the Summer Fund Camp to have training.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so Megan was just saying at our last meeting that she would like to implement the same training that they're happening at the Summer Fund.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So yes, that's going to start.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It hadn't in the past, but it's going to happen this year.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So we're really excited about that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Yeah, thank you for asking about them.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: That's really exciting.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: No, I know, really important.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: You're welcome.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Kathy can talk about that if you want her to, but it's really just

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Yeah.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Yeah.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So we just have one more thing that we wanted to do.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Yes, we appreciate that very much, Erin.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And it has been a real joy working with our special ed administration and our administration and teachers across the district.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I think one of the things that people don't realize is that when we have these events, I think oftentimes people think, oh, that's for families of children with disabilities or that's for students with disabilities.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And these events are for everyone.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: In fact, they benefit everyone.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: The school safety thing was for anybody, elderly, preschoolers,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: anyone.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And they're really helpful.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Anxiety, lots of folks have homework anxiety.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: You're not necessarily diagnosed as disabled.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So the other thing that we really want to remind people is disability is natural.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We're all disabled at some point.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So you could be temporarily disabled, or you could get hit by a car and be disabled for the rest of your life.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: You could be disabled through pregnancy, what have you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So disability is natural.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And really, no one questions anybody that walks through that door or why they come.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We're just happy to have you there.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And we also have good snacks.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And the next actually slide that we wanted to share is that we have our CPAC award, our 2019 CPAC award.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So the CPAC award, we give an award every year in recognition of a community member who exemplifies the CPAC mission of equity, diversity and inclusion for every child.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And this year we want to give the award to, drumroll,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We just want to take a picture for one minute if you don't mind indulging us.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I want to be in that picture.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Get the whole crowd in the picture, I know.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Isn't that pretty?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Yeah, come on, thank you guys.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Yeah.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Hi, Melanie McLaughlin, Alston Street.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I think this is amazing, $142,000.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I think that's just amazing.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I think that's great.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And speaking on behalf of the Special Education Parent Advisory Council as well, oftentimes I feel like

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Maybe we're not necessarily included in some of the conversations and we want to make sure that we're able to help out as well.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So we would love to be a part of this and especially when we're thinking about the, I think it was the, was it Columbus School you guys were talking about for the buses and some of the concerns around accessibility for students with disabilities.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And that's really our role as a CPAC to help advise the district and help family members as well.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And we want to roll up our sleeves and get in there and help folks as well.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So in any way that we can, we would like to be included.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: My name is Melanie McLaughlin, and I live on Alston Street in West Medford.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I've had three children that have attended the Brooks Elementary School.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: One at the Andrews, one at the McGlynn, and then ultimately the high school.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I just wanted to add, I could not get up in this scenario.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I had to, for those of you who know me.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: know that I do care very much about social justice and equity and equality of opportunity for all children.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I did have to get up and say, when people were talking about how do we talk about this, I think, you know, as in all situations with education, the data tells a story, the data speaks for itself.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Look at the data.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Take a moment.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We were looking at the data in the audience and there are people in the audience that frankly are stunned by this data.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It does tell a story and it tells a very important story.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: This is a segregated system and it's not a socially just system.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I would also ask that the school committee consider taking it a step further in terms of thinking about students with disabilities in this scenario as well.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Because, you know, I understand the programmatic elements.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I understand the budgeting concerns.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: when we're talking about programmatic elements.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But all means all.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Every student should have, you know, the opportunity to have the randomization and the experience of being at any of the schools, not one or the other.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: You know, that's the school that the kids with the disabilities go to.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: This is not.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: That's not okay either.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I'm sorry, but when we talk about inclusive classrooms, what does that mean for the other classrooms?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Are they exclusive?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: When we talk about even segregated,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: classrooms, what does even mean?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I mean, I really do think we need to take this another step and really be looking at this as a whole.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I appreciate the opportunity for you to let me speak.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: One of the things I just wanted to add as well is that, as Kathy was speaking earlier around students with disabilities, the other piece is that you don't know when you might be a student with a disability or an individual with a disability.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So one day you might be fine, and the next day you trip off the curb, and suddenly you've got a boot on your foot, and you're not going to be able to exit the building as easily as anybody else either.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so this is an ongoing process that people need to be thinking about for also, like Kathy was saying earlier, our adults in the building as well.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We have teachers who might have needs, other staff who might have needs that we should be thinking about.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So some of the recommendations that were on earlier pages were things that we started working on.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: These are some of the ones that we want to continue working on, and we'll get to how in a moment.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But communicating emergency preparedness plans specific to students with disabilities and families.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: and update those students and families and the community on an annual basis.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We recommend convening a district-wide emergency preparedness committee with representative membership from each school to ensure consistency across the district.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So right now, we do have people at each of the schools, from what I understand, that are addressing and talking about these issues.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But we recommend having one person that's a representative from each of the schools, so essentially creating a community-wide committee, almost like what folks are talking around around the community-wide PTO.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: A community-wide committee where we're hearing from each of the schools, you know, so that we're understanding consistency and what the needs are across the district.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Ensuring communication between school and first responders specific to students with disabilities.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So some examples of that would be, you know, having our first responders understand what the layout of the special education classrooms are in our school.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And also from a school perspective, to think about what the layout of our special education classrooms are.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Is it really, you know, wise to have a special education classroom, say, on the

[Melanie McLaughlin]: you know, third floor in the far corner if you've got kids with physical disabilities and you need to get them out of the building quickly.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Who's thinking about that?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Who's addressing that?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Both from the first responders understanding where those are and from the district administration thinking about that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: understanding of children and also an understanding just of the culture.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Not all children with disabilities are going to be in the special education classrooms, right?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So thinking about that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Specific training for first responders and assisting students and others with disabilities.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So around some of this ALEC programming that we talked about, but others and sort of just a cultural competency piece.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: One of the things that

[Melanie McLaughlin]: The Department of Education said when we included them on our security and safety panel last year, we invited them and asked them to come.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: They said, you know, Ann Gilligan was the representative there from DESE, and she said, you know, it's not going to be a conversation unless you have a triangle of people at the table.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And it's got to be school, fire, and police, you know, all at the table.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I would say obviously in the center of that would be the family and the children involved in that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I think that that's really important that you have all three pieces at that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And then folks might have noted, I think just a month or two ago, Medford Public Schools was featured on NPR with our work to improve emergency plans for students with disabilities.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It was a really nice program.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: That happened because there was discussion around new budgeting with Governor Baker.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And he was talking about budgeting plans for mental health.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And he had a convening in Burlington.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I happened to be at the convening.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I got up and I asked, what about students with disabilities?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And there was an NPR reporter there who said, that's a really good point.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Nobody's talking about that and wanted to talk with us about it.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I said, hey, we're doing this subcommittee, and here's how Medford's working.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So we think that this is a real opportunity for Medford to be a leader in the state around what we're doing in this community.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And we would encourage, certainly I will be reaching out, but we would encourage the district as well,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: to be reaching out with us to state level committee on education, other folks that we know in the community as we're talking about this.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Because this is a nationwide problem.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It's not just a problem in our schools.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But Medford has an opportunity here, especially with these dedicated people who have spent so many hours researching this for you already.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And then the next page is some resources that we came across here.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: The Mass Office on Disability is what Kathy was talking about a few minutes ago, their emergency preparedness program that they have already in place.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I found the teacher's guide, Supporting Students with Disabilities During School Crisis, a teacher guide, to be particularly effective.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: There's some other links there.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: They're hot links.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so when we share the PowerPoint with you electronically, you can also click on those and access those.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But what we would talk about is next steps.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Kathy, do you want to talk about that?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so with that, we would sort of look for some concrete next steps and some of the recommendations that we have for you folks.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And we would put that out to you as what would you recommend for next steps as a result of the presentation.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Right, and specific to students with disabilities.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So some of the other recommendations that are embedded in that are that you have people at the table that have some expertise around students with disabilities.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So if there is this citywide committee that is considering this, you have representatives from each of the schools.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But clearly, it would make sense to have some of the people that are on this committee to be part of that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Like we would send somebody from our committee to the district committee.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I would also add that the emergency response plan, the individualized emergency response plan that Susanna did such great research on,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: can be used for anyone.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I mean, that's the point, is that we were looking at universal design for everybody.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So that's what's so great about disability.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: When you consider disability, you're considering everybody as a result.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Everybody benefits.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We've been talking about that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Yeah.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We very much agree that having a self-advocate at the table is really critical.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And in fact, at the last meeting, you heard Leslie was sort of agreeing, and we can see how much value is added by our student here and how much they're appreciated.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I think that's a really good point.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I just would want to add, Erin, thank you for that, but also thinking about trauma, students who have experienced trauma, and our English language learners as well in this scenario.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So same thing, it's about universal design.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Hi, Melanie McLaughlin, 152 Alston Street in Medford.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Welcome, Dr. Vincent.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you for being here.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I wanted to say thank you all for your concern around air conditioning in the high school.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We appreciate the response and the water and the advice to wear light clothing and drink water.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But I do also want to share that I'm sure many of you know that, or I'm sure all of you know that I'm the co-chair of the Special Education Parent Advisory Council in Medford as well.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And we have children with special needs who spend time at the high school, especially over the summer months in the summer fun camp and in the ESY camps and what have you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And my daughter was among them this summer.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: This is something that will include in our PowerPoint presentation soon for Special Education Parent Advisory Council.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But our daughter had to come home several times, especially the last week of the summer fun camp, last two weeks of summer fun camp, because it was just too hot and just unbearable.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: we sort of put the information out there because we want to always offer solution.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so we had asked individuals if maybe there was an air conditioning campaign we could create or there was a fundraising drive we could do or figuring out how we might be able to help with the community.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And we've been getting a mix of information from whether or not window units can be used, whether the windows can accommodate them.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: The CPAC donated two years ago a floor unit

[Melanie McLaughlin]: to the camp that, last we knew anyway, it had been misplaced for some of the kids that needed it there.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So we've had folks reach out to us from staff, students, teachers, all reach out explaining and sharing their circumstances and their stories that have been very concerning.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Some of whom have talked about migraine headaches, nausea, having to leave the school.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: There's been some community conversation around, you know, sort of, well, that's how it's been done all these years, and suck it up and get used to it, and that's our grandfather's school, and what have you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And, you know, it's getting hotter over time.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And, you know, the heat index, I think, yesterday was 103.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And, you know, I don't know about you guys, but I couldn't bear that, and certainly couldn't ask to be tested.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: while I was going through that or asked to be actually learning.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It's basic, you know, Maslow's Heurich of Needs.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: If you're not having your basic needs met, you can't do that higher level stuff.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Yeah.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I think that's a great approach and that's a good start, but also I know that this is a bigger issue in a multi-million dollar project and what have you for the high school, but I think it's just something that we need to keep circling back to and asking about in terms of safety.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So thank you for what's been done so far, but please let's not leave that off the table.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Hello school committee members, Madam Mayor, community.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: My name is Melanie Perkins McLaughlin and I live on Alston Street in Medford.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So we wanted to come before you folks and before the community to ask some questions that we had and concerns that we had.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I know that you know Angela and I as regular attendees of the school committee meetings.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We've been coming for several years.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Also have children in the school district.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I have two high schoolers and a elementary schooler.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I'm also the co-chair of the Medford Special Education Parent Advisory Council, representing approximately 800 families in the district.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And one of the things we wanted to talk about was it was really, really interesting to watch tonight's events because so much of what I feel like we all watch tonight is family and community engagement.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And it's an important part of what we really need to have as Medford moves forward.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I hope that Dr. Edouard-Vincent watches these archival meetings to understand what it is we are looking for and what we need.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And everyone knows that we had a very unfortunate event and we had an unfortunate meeting that occurred in February where there was a lot of heated emotions and where there was a lot of

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And people talked about that for a long time in the community afterwards.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And they talked about how terrible that meeting was in so many different ways.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And what wasn't talked about, unfortunately, in my opinion, was what brought that about.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Not so much the incident itself, but the lack of family and community engagement in our community.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Even this context where you have to be willing to stand up at a podium and speak into a microphone.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: with your back turned to the rest of the community to be able to converse and express what your feelings are.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I mean, I went on to the website earlier today to just sort of look at what the protocol is.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I understand protocol and the need for protocol.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: You have to get the business part of it going and the meeting moving along.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: You know, but the website is you have to submit in writing your request.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: You have to do it a week ahead of time.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: You have exactly three minutes.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: You can come up to the podium and you can talk to us.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: That's not family and community engagement.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I had the benefit last year of going to graduate school, and I really enjoyed my time there.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I had a great teacher who helped write for the Department of Education at the federal level the family and community engagement guidelines and some material there.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And one of the things they talk about is family and community.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We're all part of the community.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So the teachers that came up tonight are the community.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: The school committee members are the community.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Our shop owners are the community.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: The parents are the community.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We're not just families.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: or teachers or people that don't have children.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We're all a community together.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I had this really great experience last week where

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I set up an appointment to talk with our new EL director, Paul Texera, and we had the best conversation.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We sat in his office for just about an hour, and I learned a little bit about him, he learned a little bit about me, and we both walked away from that experience wanting to work together and really wanting to collaborate with each other.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I thought, you know, what would have happened if we hadn't built those relationships with each other, if we didn't know each other?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And that's what family and community engagement is.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It's about building relationships and about knowing each other.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Folks might recall when this all happened a few months ago, there was a post on social media where one of Mr. Belson's family members talked about who Mr. Belson is as a man.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And we heard from his friend earlier talking about who Mr. Belson is as a man.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And personalizing Mr. Belson and personalizing each one of us is what builds community and relationship.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I think people are able to relate much better to who he was as a man because we learned about who you are as a man.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Tonight, seeing you apologize, we learned about who you are as a man.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And that's the important piece of family and community engagement.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It's collaboration and communication.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We're not doing it enough.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And we can't say enough about that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And that's why I stand before you tonight

[Melanie McLaughlin]: for more family and community collaboration.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Bring people to the table.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I was watching Justin tonight.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I'm so glad Justin's here.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: That's a relatively new thing.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: That's a great thing.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: More roundtable discussion, not having to come up to the podium and ask and talk.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Or you guys were inundated with emails.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I'm glad you were inundated with emails.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I say to anybody watching tonight, keep them coming.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Keep communicating, please, because we need you to communicate to make a difference and to make things transparent.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So getting to the transparent piece, even in the past few months with everything that's been going on, there's still been sort of concerns around some of the transparency.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And what you saw the night in February and what I witnessed, which was, frankly, traumatizing for me.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I don't know about other people, but I was sort of shell-shocked when I left there at the anger and the vitriol that was there that night.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But I was also really very clear what the message was.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And it was, we don't feel like we're being heard.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And in any relationship, as people can attest in their marriage or their relationship with their children or what have you, when you feel like you're not being heard, what typically happens?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: You yell.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: You're angry.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: You get out of control.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But when you're being heard, you're collaborating.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: You're working together.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So that's what we need to do.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So in the most recent Committee of the Whole meeting, when we found out by social media that the decision to extend the superintendent's contract went from

[Melanie McLaughlin]: April to June, that was not family and community engagement.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: That was a really bad example of the lack of family and community engagement.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And again, none of this is personal for me around Mr. Bellson.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We've had everybody knows we've had our differences, Mr. Bellson, but we've always been very professional and respectful with each other.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It's never been personal and it never will be.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But in terms of having community transparency to find out on social media that this decision was reversed was so unfortunate.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It was like, oh, it felt like we were moving forward

[Melanie McLaughlin]: and we were gaining some momentum and some trust, and then this happened, and you could see it in the response on social media, the way so many community members felt about that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But if they had just been consulted with ahead of time, if people had just had an idea, even the notice was, you know, that there's a committee of the whole meeting and that there was going to be some discussion, which frankly was at the same time as the National Honor Society meeting, which is what I was attending,

[Melanie McLaughlin]: that there was going to be some discussion that this might even be the case, you would have had a much larger turnout, I have no doubt.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And people would have felt like they were invested in that decision and had some momentum and part of that decision.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I guess what I want to ask as we're talking about transparency and moving forward and, you know, hoping that you folks will hear us, and I know that we've done presentations in the past as a CPAC talking about family and community engagement and the need for it.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I think that this is really a fascinating study, frankly, in family and community engagement this past year that we've had here.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But I guess the questions I have is, I have a few questions.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: One is how, also I want to mention that we also had a public records request in a few months ago that has not been responded to.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And when we try to submit the public records request through the website, we get a mail or DM back that says the public records request is not accessible.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And again, I just kind of feel like it's a metaphor for the scenario.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so I'd love for folks to look into that as well, because if a community member has a public records request, it shouldn't be a mail-or-demon back.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And once we've notified the community, the school, that it is a mail-or-demon, hopefully it's fixed and people respond to that constituent.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So questions we have.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: How is the community made aware that the vote would be to continue the superintendent contract from

[Melanie McLaughlin]: April 30th to June 30th, effectively reversing the February decision.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I'm wondering how the community was made aware that that was going to be the vote.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: That's the first question.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: The second is, did any school committee members let their community or constituents know

[Melanie McLaughlin]: this would be a consideration.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: If so, how was that done?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And if not, I'm wondering why.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And then also we're wondering about the survey results for the superintendent and how or whether they were shared from the community survey that was done, asking folks what they would like.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And Madam Mayor, respectfully, I agree.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I think that I didn't go to the meeting myself because I thought that it was a sort of procedural interim, you know, what we were going to do, which I thought was pretty clear that it would likely be deputies.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Obviously, I was uninformed, but it didn't say specifically about Mr. Belson.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Had it, I would have been at the meeting.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So I think that that's the point.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I'm sorry.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Right.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I understand.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I totally understand that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: But I guess what I'm saying in the interest of family and community engagement, we didn't hear that and we didn't hear what we needed to hear to be at the meeting.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so from a family perspective, it wasn't communicated effectively.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I think that you look, there can be something as simple as handheld microphones and people could stand at either end and address all of you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It's simple if you think outside of the box a little bit about, well, what feels welcoming and this is not welcoming.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It's intimidating.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And so what do we do to make somebody feel less intimidated?

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I couldn't agree more.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I think Dr. Edouard-Vincent is going to be all over that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I'm really happy and very pleased.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And thank you all very much for your hard work on that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I know how hard you worked on that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And thank you for the privilege of being on the superintendent search committee.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It was a great privilege.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Yeah.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Very eloquent, Justin.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I want to add, I do just feel like I need to add in this situation.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I was at the school committee meeting two years ago when Angela came up to the podium and asked very respectfully what the plan was.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And it was embarrassing.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I think there was only probably one or two other people in the audience, but there were lots of people watching at home.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And it was embarrassing and humiliating.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I felt terribly for Angela in that experience.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I remember writing an email to

[Melanie McLaughlin]: the school committee after that meeting.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I actually befriended Angela as a result of that meeting.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It was entirely unfortunate and it was two years ago.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Ms.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And thank you for everyone out there tonight that's still here.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And for folks that are watching at home, we really want to encourage you to remember to come to the school committee meetings.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Let your voice be heard.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Your voice matters, and your vote matters.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It was a great privilege.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Yeah.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Very eloquent, Justin, thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And I want to add, I do just feel like I need to add in this situation, I was at the school committee meeting two years ago when Angela came up to the podium and asked very respectfully what the plan was, and it was embarrassing, and I think there was only probably one or two other people in the audience, but there were lots of people watching at home, and it was embarrassing and humiliating, and I felt terribly for Angela in that experience.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I remember writing an email to

[Melanie McLaughlin]: the school committee after that meeting.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I actually befriended Angela as a result of that meeting.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It was entirely unfortunate, and it was two years ago.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Ms.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you, and thank you for everyone out there tonight that's still here, and for folks that are watching at home, we really want to encourage you to remember to come to the school committee meetings.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Let your voice be heard.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Your voice matters, and your vote matters.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Hello, thank you, Melanie McLaughlin, Austin Street in Medford, and co-chair Tanya Sullivan for Medford CPAC.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thanks for hearing us out tonight.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: First, we wanted to just sort of share what the Medford CPAC directive is, so folks who are watching tonight know.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: The CPAC's purpose is to fill the directive stated in Chapter 71B.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: of the Massachusetts General Laws, which requires school districts to establish a Parent Advisory Council and assign both an advisory and participatory function to the PAC.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: In meeting this requirement, the mission of the Medford Special Education Parent Advisory Council is to

[Melanie McLaughlin]: advise the district on matters that pertain to the education and safety of students with disabilities by seeking input from the special education parent members, meet regularly with school officials, participate in the planning, development, and evaluation of the school district's special education programs, participate in planning workshops and activities as prioritized by the CPAC board.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So that's our directive.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We want to first start tonight with saying thank you for all of the responses from committee members this past week.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: who emailed us or called us, and any responses to questions that we had.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We also noticed that you're honoring or thanking Mr. Petrales tonight for the camp.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And personally, my daughter attended the camp last week, and it was really great.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: He did a great job, so we're happy.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: To see that that's happening and that it's inclusive as well We met with the Disability Council this week as well to discuss some concerns and also The Recreation Department representative was there and he talked quite a bit about inclusivity in the Recreation Department as well So we're very happy about that

[Melanie McLaughlin]: want to say thank you about that too.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We wanted to share that last week that Tanya and I worked on an advisory report and PowerPoint available on our Facebook page and also shared with the school committee members and the mayor having to do with safety protocols in schools, CPAC advisory and CPAC PowerPoint.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We also shared that with the Department of Education, elementary and secondary education, our

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Joint Committee on Education at the state level and our representatives and senators.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And we spoke with DESE last week.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We're happy to report that next week during the Special Education Advisory Council to the commissioner.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We will be working on drafting a letter for recommendations for all schools on safety protocols in our schools, particularly to our population.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: which we're very pleased with.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And we also met with our representative this week and are going to be exploring additional issues around that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So we wanted folks to know.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We have an upcoming meeting a week from this Wednesday, so March 14th, 7 and 9 p.m.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: on emergency preparedness in schools.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And we want to make sure that folks know that this is for everyone in the district.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It's an inclusive event.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It is not specific to any incident.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: It is instead about emergency preparedness in our schools.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We were able to secure so far a DESI emergency preparedness expert, Ann Gilligan, who's going to come and speak with us as part of a panel, the Medford Police Department, Medford Fire Department, and a first responder who deals specifically with ALEC training, which is regarding autism and law enforcement training.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And that first responder has also been doing trainings for mental health and first aid.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So for folks who have mental health needs and first aid concerns, so they'll be a part of the panel.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We're respectfully requesting that the school has someone on the panel as well, and hopefully maybe someone from the Disability Council or someone from the city on the panel as well, just to create a positive conversation around some of these needs in our district and across the state.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Also wanted to let folks know that we have elections coming up in May, and in June we typically do

[Melanie McLaughlin]: our end of the year PowerPoint presentation, where we present to the school committee.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And also, we give out awards for folks in the community who have demonstrated inclusivity and equity.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So we're looking forward to that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We have two concerns that we wanted to represent to the school committee.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: One is that we requested a subcommittee last year as part of our presentation, our end of year PowerPoint presentation.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And it was advised that we join a subcommittee that already existed, a curriculum subcommittee.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Unfortunately, that subcommittee, as far as we know, did not meet, or at least we weren't invited to part of a meeting for a subcommittee.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We respectfully request, once again, that we have a subcommittee regarding special education and high-need students.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: So our high-need students population, for those who are unsure, are students who are receiving special education supports and services, students who are economically disadvantaged, and our English learner students.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And as you can imagine, there's intersectionality with all of those.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We'd love a subcommittee regarding that.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And then it has been brought to our attention over the past, I don't know, probably a year or more, that there's been some concerns of disciplinary action at the McGlynn Preschool level in terms of inclusivity and activity at the McGlynn Preschool.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We want to ensure that the McGlynn Preschool staff has the appropriate supports in place to be able to attend to students of all needs.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: They receive an inclusive preschool learning environment grant.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: which requires a minimum of three and not more than five students with disabilities in the classroom.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And some students, we're getting reports of some students spending an extensive amount of time at the principal's office in terms of behavior and discipline.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And we wanted to bring that to folks' attention, because that's a concern.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We want to make sure that the McGlynn Preschool has what they need to be inclusive, especially in light of the fact that they're receiving a state grant for inclusivity.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: And that's it.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: I don't think we need to see the e-mails, but I do appreciate your response, and it's just that it's been almost a year, so we're very concerned.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: We requested it last January.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Well, we had respectfully requested that it be a separate committee, but we were told that there was so many committees that we had to go under another committee, and that was part of our concern is that we actually do feel that it should be a distinct committee.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Correct.

[Melanie McLaughlin]: Thank you very much.
